replies_ddqual:
stay our of their airspace?  maybe an Emerson education campaign? \\ it would be good to hear from some of the smokers--what do you think?  \\ I don't smoke myself, but I know it is a big issue trying to find an appropriate place for it. After all, the state/city (I don't remember which) just passed this law saying that it is illegal to smoke in public parks so now smokers don't even have the option of crossing the street...\\ My grad school, Simmons recently went smoke-free. All businesses went smoke free years ago in Boston and as Julie P. points out, public parks have too. 



There IS no appropriate place for it. None. Emerson ought to encourage and support (including financially) students in smoking-cessation. \\ So I agree that smoking is unhealthy. Nevertheless, some of our community smokes, and it is a hard habit to break. Is there a way to accommodate smokers' need to smoke, while simultaneously trying to help them quit?

Response_ddqual: We are working hard to increase the diversity of faculty, staff, and students.  People ask: "when do we know when we are diverse enough?".  What do you think?  What's your answer for that?
replies_ddqual: hmmm . . . this is a tough question, because if you look at "diversity" in a narrow sense--thinking of gender, race, culture--you can probably come up with an "enough" based on population statistics.  But to achieve academic excellence, I feel we should work to include diversity in more categories:  class, certainly, abilities and age--but even further, in temperament, points of view, and perspectives. Looked at that way, the possibilities are infinite.\\ I'm not sure there is such a thing as "diverse enough." I think there are an infanate number of types of people from different walks if life and with different perspectives. Just like we are never done learning and growing, I believe we are never done working to surround ourselves with a diversity of people and perspectives. And it is WORK, because as rewarding as it is to experience diversity, it can also be uncomfortable to see new perspectives and experience the world in a new way.\\ Perhaps one of the ERGs can help answer that question (once we get off the ground!)

Hello Maria and WELCOME to Emerson College!



You have most of what you need already -- the materials will come easily so don't worry about that so much. What you will need is an open mind and the ability to not judge a person or situation without all the facts. The next four years will be a time in your life that will help define your character and integrity for the rest of your life. You can finally SHOW who you are as a person, as a family member, as a student, friend, confidante and citizen of a global community through the decisions you make. Don't be afraid to try new things (Act! Write! Sing!) and DEFINITELY don't be afraid to ask questions. If you need help--seek out a trusted member of staff or a good friend that can help you to navigate the sometimes-murky waters of your college experience.

A while back there was talk of incorporating the Emerson name to the Boylston T stop. Although I wouldn't want the Boylston name to disappear as it's historic, one of the first subway stops in America, I think a Emerson reference or branding would be nice.  What do you all think?
replies_ddqual:
Arlington could be renamed "Almost Emerson"\\ I see no need to make Boston purchase new signs. If Emerson were a public institution, with a stronger public mission, a case could be made that we should encourage all T-riders to investigate Emerson opportunities. But unlike Harvard, we are not a center of tourist interest, and shouldn't try to become one.\\ I really like the idea of putting our brand on the city's public transport in this way. If Emerson is positioned to be an epicenter for the arts and theater, why not explore this? Imagine it - WERS piped in and our student and faculty work on display, public displays of our community partnerships. I think it could be a really great way to show our commitment to the community. \\ Before Emerson can think about putting its name at the Boylston T stop, the stop itself has to stop ots brutal clash with Emerson's values.  First, the station would need to be made accessible to people who have difficulty with stairs..  Second, the ear-splitting decibel level of noise emanating from the tracks would have to be fixed.  The noise goes against the values of our CSD program because that level is, quite literally, deafening. 



In sum, I wouldn't vote to put Emerson's brand anywhere near that station.\\ In addition to bringing the station up to code, we'd need to find a donor with deep pockets.  The MBTA's initial asking price for naming stations was 7 figures.  Thankfully, no one bit

Response_ddqual: What are some of the ways that the college is dealing with the issue of rape on the campus? I'm concerned about this because I just recently saw an article on Huffington Post. What can we do prevent issues like this from defining the school?
replies_ddqual:
Weird coincidence that Pelton sent out an email regarding that HuffPost article 7 minutes after this was posted.\\ The Huffington headline and photo was so bizarre.  Someone showed it to me on their phone in a restaurant.  Embarrassing, and totally irresponsible of HuffPost to present the content that way.  Would make an interesting case study of digital "news" reporting.\\ In words better than I can personally articulate:



"Dear President Pelton,

In light of your recent e-mail about the rape-related lawsuit against Emerson College, I want to take the opportunity to share my thoughts. I do so not just as an Emerson alumnus, but as a feminist and, frankly, a fellow human being.

Firstly, I think its wonderful that, as you shared, Emerson has taken steps toward establishing a Center of Violence Prevention and Response, as well as other educational and preventative measures to combat rape and rape culture.

However, it should go without saying that actions speak louder than words. Its one thing to talk about rape education in the hypothetical. Its another thing to properly assist an actual rape victim in the real world. As I understand it, in regards to the latter, Emerson College has fallen terribly short...\\ ...Emerson College is not being sued because a student was raped on campus. Emerson College is being sued because of the way it dealt with a students rape on campus. Of course Emerson is not at fault for the physical rape. That blame does, in fact, lie with the assailant. But Emerson is absolutely responsible for the way it handles rape allegations.

First and foremost, if the school wants to claim that it is not responsible for its actions in these regards, then it should not be dealing with these investigations in-house. If Emerson is not responsible for the way it handles rape, then rape cases should be forwarded to the police immediately. No questions asked...\\ ...For all the talk about faculty rape education at Emerson College, the target has been completely missed in practice. During the investigation, the rape survivor was forced to testify in the same room as her assailant. Leniencies of doubt were given to the assailant, but used against the victim. Worst of all, the victims possible inebriation was brought up as a means of victim blaming in order to question the veracity of her claims. Anyone actually educated in rape awareness knows that it doesnt matter whether or not the victim/assailant was drunk.To compare the schools inability to prevent rape to an inability to prevent drinking on campus is, frankly, disgusting, and shows a lack of both understanding and empathy on the part of Emerson College. Legal document or otherwise, the suggestion that the students prior consensual sexual encounter with the assailant somehow matters in the case of rape is also absurd. Rape is rape. No means no...\\ ...A husband can rape his wife and vise versa. Prior consent does not equal consent, and in the case of rape, prior consent should not ever be brought up. Its not applicable to the case at hand.

When it comes to the way Emerson has dealt with rape, not in the academic theoretical, but in actuality with real victims of rape, I ask this question: Would you let your daughter attend Emerson, knowing that if she was raped, the school would deal with it in such a manner? For me, the answer is a resounding NO. I would not want my daughter to attend Emerson. I would not want my friends to attend Emerson. And if Emerson College does not take responsibility for the horrid manner in which it has dealt with student rape on campus, I promise that I will encourage future potential students not to attend Emerson...\\ ...President Pelton, you claim that Emerson considers itself a national leader for campus efforts to end sexual assault. If this is truly the case, Im saddened and shocked that this is the best our nation has to offer.

Nobody is asking Emerson to stop rape from happening before it happens. Were simply asking that Emerson deals with rape properly, fairly, and most importantly, compassionately, when it does.

Im not proud right now to be an Emerson alum. Emersons response to rape has permanently tainted the way I view my alma mater. I am, however, proud to see so many Emersonians speaking out against the actions of their school. I can only hope that, in this case, the faculty can learn something from its students.



Best,

Dan (Stark)"\\ Ok, I know this question is not considered enlightened or politically correct, yet I will continue to ask this till I get a sensible answer:  why are colleges exempt from involving police in campus sexual assault investigations?  Rape is a crime, and successful prosecution often depends on forensic evidence.  Our campus security force, wonderful as they are, aren't equipped to prosecute this kind of crime. \\ @Maureen. Any/every student is asked if they would like the BPD to be called. The student makes the choice. This is considered best practices because it actually gives all the power to decide what happens to the student who is victimized. 



And whether or not the victim asks for the police to be involved, the college--every college--must report any act of violence to the government. (The Cleary Act.)



@Hsiao-yen I'm angry too about how things have been handled. There are people on this campus who are and have been for the past year working tirelessly and passionately to change policies, procedures, and campus climate. Many, many policies and procedures have now changed. Now we need to change the campus climate.

I would think Emerson is very insular in nature. It doesn't reach out to us and engage with us enough. Not enough of it's students participate in local community efforts and it doesn't have an impact on the community as much. Sure they go out to the restaurants, but other than that, they aren't giving back at all. If you look at Harvard, they always have programs helping out the local youth, and they're embedded within the culture of their city (Cambridge.) Harvard's name is on everyone's tongue, not just because of their #1 status, but because of the fact that they are constantly improving the area around them and giving so much back to the community. From a local's perspective, I've seen kids from Cambridge benefit educationally from having Harvard in their city. They get tutors from Harvard, they have special programs for the kids during the summer. It's a net benefit.

Innovation means not only pushing the boundaries of media but it also means expanding the minds of the people. Teaching kids the hard skills is one thing, it's very important. They need that base to excel, HOWEVER, it's no use if they're not challenging the status quo. For instance, an issue like racism isn't really even talked about on campus among the general population. How as a school of innovators can we innovate and create new things out of old mentalities. I just think it's a misnomer to be calling this a school of innovation but we still lag far behind other institutions in terms of the types of dialogue that's fostered on campus. It's not on the minds of people at this school. That's fine, but living in a bubble that's not representative of the world around us has a profound impact. They might not see it now, but we can never truly be innovators unless we expand our minds. So tackling and wrestling with problems that our society has can be a great starting point to start making these kids think more critically about real life things. We need to teach more soft skills on campus.

entropy

[en-truh-pee]  Spell  Syllables

Examples Word Origin

noun

1.

Thermodynamics.

(on a macroscopic scale) a function of thermodynamic variables, as temperature, pressure, or composition, that is a measure of the energy that is not available for work during a thermodynamic process. A closed system evolves toward a state of maximum entropy.

(in statistical mechanics) a measure of the randomness of the microscopic constituents of a thermodynamic system. Symbol: S.

2.

(in data transmission and information theory) a measure of the loss of information in a transmitted signal or message.

3.

(in cosmology) a hypothetical tendency for the universe to attain a state of maximum homogeneity in which all matter is at a uniform temperature (heat death)

4.

a doctrine of inevitable social decline and degeneration.

Response_ddqual: Is there any way to amend the policy of needing a doctor's note or the contact info of someone at the health and wellness center in order to get an absence excused? I was really sick yesterday and didn't have the strength to walk from Paramount (where I live) to the USB, let alone go to a doctor....it seems extreme. I understand the reasoning behind it but at the end of the day, as students we should be treated like adults. Just because some students lie about being sick and don't come to class shouldn't mean that students who are actually sick should have to go to great lengths in order to get their absence excused. We are paying for our education and if we decide not to come to class that's our prerogative. That being said, I have extremely good attendance (I only missed one class all last year, and yesterday's absences were my first this year) and I am a good student who comes to class on time, does the work,and participates. I shouldn't be penalized for being sick.
replies_ddqual:
Is this actually a policy??? It seems very unreasonable to expect someone who is sick to drag themselves out to get a doctor's note! Seems like another example of the trend to over-supervise students' lives.\\ You should be treated like adults. We get sick days if were out sick and unless we are out for an extended length of time we don't have to get a doctors note. Why should you? You're also paying to be here. It's should be your prerogative to attend or not attend classes. The only person getting hurt is you if you miss something. Money up in smoke!\\ I agree you shouldn't be treated like children. However, I believe the reason for this policy is to insure sick people see a doctor/med professional - which in the current Ebola age, is a smart thing to do. Because so many of our students are venturing into adulthood for the first time, the college is trying to provide guidance to make the transition easier. Sickness may not mean Ebola, but might mean a regular issue with hangovers, or a sign of more serious problems. 



If you're feeling unfairly penalized, please speak with a dean.

The ways in which Emersonians work to address societal problems are far too numerous to list here. A major obstacle for Emerson to overcome is educating the public on the value created through communication and the arts. I think we often look at addressing societal problems in very traditional terms: volunteer days, direct service, cleaning up a park, etc. This game is a great example of one way in which Emerson has worked to address societal problems - not one, but many. The liberal arts context of an Emerson education must play a role in this effort. In the future, I'd like to see the Emerson community focus on the ways in which we can use our strengths and mission to make a positive impact on both the local and global levels.

Response: In 2014, it means you went to a school that many people have heard of, but might not know much or anything about. When I mention Emerson in conversation, I typically receive a positive response, but with little reason why. I believe the college currently offers a quality classroom education complimented by hands on experience and a liberal arts context. Moving closer to 2020 or 2030, I would like to see increased focus on creating a context for the work students arriving at Emerson know they'd like to study. There is a difference between what I think I need to know in order to be successful and what I actually need to know. I believe the college plays a vital role in closing that gap.

As with most questions, that depends. Engaging with ideas and concepts outside a chosen field of study can challenge our mental constructs and inspire us to think in new and creative ways. Innovation means providing opportunity for community members who are already finding creative solutions to existing problems and encouraging others to do the same. That can mean encourage risk taking, which is difficult in a traditionally risk adverse setting. That said, I actually see innovation happening in pockets across Emerson. Obviously in the examples listed: Emerson Accelerator, Engagement Lab, and Entrepreneurial Studies. But, also on a smaller scale in classrooms, departments, and offices across campus. One challenge I've encountered is actually the rush to have innovative practices and approaches serve as a model for others rather than focusing on refining those practices to more fully address the issues that necessitated their creation in the first place. Reflection and revision must be a part of the process.

Response_ddqual: Emerson, what makes us EMERSON? What are the first words and images that come to mind?
replies_ddqual: For me, it's the legacy of Charles Wesley Emerson, his emphasis on speech, oratory, and voice culture, which characterized the school from the beginning. I remember when oral interpretation was required of every student. I think Emerson College is unique in having been started as a school of oratory, and I like that the emphasis on expression and voice has continued today, though it has been transformed into the broader context of "communication."

Response_ddqual:
Sometimes, I think we do too much at Emerson. Creativity and Innovation needs space. 



Who needs mind space? Who needs time space? 



What would you do with that time . . . . . . . . .
replies_ddqual: I agree, Kelly, if you mean we are often way too busy to think, reflect, and come up with truly innovative ideas.  Even more than the reality of having lots to do, there's an emphasis here on being perceived as always busy--in fact, I've been cautioned not to appear too eager to take on projects that I might be passionate about, because it will look like I don't have enough to do in my "full-time" job. But I truly believe that with mind and time space, well used, amazing things can happen. Without the time and space to think, reflect, dream . . . nothing creative happens, just a lot of display and design.  Beautiful and appealing, but not substantial.\\ I also agree! I think far too often we are so determined to finish a project and start the next that we tend not to spend as much attention and time on the process or reflect on the experience. We are so results oriented and that is a tough cycle to break! Granted, the work is always great. I think we ask staff need to model the way by prioritizing, pacing ourselves and celebrating process and reflection as much as the end result.

You're asking us to predict the future. OK, I'm game. How about a course in Robotics, which would be offered in conjunction with MIT. This course would involve new media, environmentalism, and communication. MIT would provide the tech, Emerson students would provide the communication. The robots would to travel into areas where sea level has risen and flooded communities (like Superstorm Sandy or Katrina). The robots -- which would be waterproof -- would be programmed to travel into stricken areas where humans could not safely go, introduce themselves, find out what's needed, then relay the message back to the appropriate parties.

Many fewer students will come to campus. Classes will be conducted via massive online hangouts. This will be a great boon to low-income students whose financial limitations would prohibit paying for room and board. But it could also hinder their education as I believe in-person classes are more effective than online ones.

Response: Cultural Studies

What Ken has heard is entirely true, and that's part of what makes Emerson great. Boston has such a different vibe from any other small, college town in the country: those college towns have one, maybe two colleges, and have a very specific social set. Boston, however, is a a college town of a hundred or more big colleges, making the city as a whole a varied and mixed vibe of college experience.

Emerson in particular is a place with an essential vibrant community, if only because our students are a vibrant group of people. The number of different groups and people you can meet just by walking out of your door in the morning is fascinating and immense: Emerson is a community that is always changing to represent its members.

I think that for freshmen, sophomores, and even juniors have the ability to change their path at Emerson, they need only talk to their advisors and figure out a course of action. For a sophomore, particularly, who is transitioning from one writing-based major to another, it's very possible for her to change her major. It she talks to her Advising, and Emerson can find a way to transfer some of her WLP requirement credits to her WTF requirements, it can be easy for her to change.

The main transformative event at Emerson that has changed me was the Castle. It's impossible to explain exactly how it changed me, or what pieces of that experience caused the change, but now I feel like a more competent individual with a strong capacity for leadership and organization. It's as if I now better understand where I can go with my life, and have a better idea of how to get there.

I don't see Emerson doing enough to address society's problems. I think we're on the right track to get there, but we aren't there yet. An issue will arise and the community gets fired up about it, but then it dies out, and other than something like a social media campaign or a few panel discussions, not much is done. We don't always use our assets to their full potential, and that's really a shame.

I think an Emerson degree in 2014 tells employers that you have real-world experience, you are eager to learn, and that you will be a true asset to your field. I think ECLA will absolutely increase that, and by 2020 or 2030, I hope there will be possibilities like that for all majors.

I think at Emerson we get caught up in viewing Gen-Eds as a waste of our time, but that is far from the truth. Having knowledge in a variety of subjects will only help to make Julian a better film-maker.

I can create entire productions on video screens - on walls - on floors - simply by describing them into my computer or similar device. Response:
A degree means that a student has a fair chance at entering the professional workforce with a fighting chance at becoming someone. To me, a college diploma is more important than ever before. Whereas it used to be a career bonus, it now has become almost a necessity to individuals wanting to "move on up the career ladder."



An Emerson education can provide that little extra boost, but only in certain fields. A VMA degree isn't going to necessarily help someone looking to be an accountant, but can be the extra something in a production company.



In 2020 and 2030, an Emerson degree can be even more valuable, but only if the college keeps up with innovations in the arts and communications fields. New programs,, such as online journalism, can boost the value. Also, faculty needs to encourage students to go bigger and broader.

Somewhat. Philosophy does encourage critical thinking skills that can't be touched upon in film production courses. It tapes into a section of the brain that encourages individuals to think "outside the box" (even more so than a general Emerson education).



On a personal note, it is important to have a foundation of knowledge based in fields outside of your study. When you're at work, you talk to coworkers about more than just work. A base in other areas of knowledge will help Julian to relate and keep up with conversations not just related to film production.
Some but not all

Maria will need a number of housing-related things for her dorm room - sheets, clothes, computer, mini-fridge, microwave, TV, and FEBREEZE. She will also need school supplies (books, notebooks, pens/pencils).

I am most excited about being part of the Emerson Community when I see our students, faculty, staff and alumni doing something truly amazing.  I never stop being impressed by the Emerson community around us or the breadth of variety of things our community members are involved with/experts at/etc.

Response_ddqual: The closest match from the options above is "liberal arts college," given our foundation in the liberal arts. But we have no majors in the traditional liberal arts, so we are truly something else entirely. We are not merely "arts" (let's not forget about communications!), not at all a conservatory, and so much more than a professional school. We are our own unique institution -- firmly grounded in the liberal arts but with major courses of studies devoted to a range of fields in both the arts and communications.

Response: Thom Mayne

What do you mean, "the world"? 



Fully 3/4 of the world's population has no exposure to Emerson. Of those that have any, more than half would consider us to be related to noted American Transcendentalist Ralph Waldo Emerson. 



Of the very small portion of the 8 billion people on earth who have any specific idea what and where Emerson College is, it is the where that matters most, the what that matters next, and the exclusivity that matters after that. 



Emerson has opportunities, particularly with its foreign programs, to increase its global presence, but this means active and well managed community relationship maintenance in every site we set up shop. It means hiring locals and assisting them in increasing their own potential, and advocating for their rights and development in our partnering nations and communities. It means keeping Boston informed of these relationships and efforts, so that when we travel, we behave beter than the average American tourist, and can check in and get assistance from those in other places. 



Emerson is capable of being a leader. But leadership means sticking your neck out, which Emerson is often reluctant to do without a fairly reliable promise of success.
Other
Response_ddqual:
I think the biggest mark we could make is in the published work of our faculty and students, and in the presence of our alums in institutions and notable positions throughout the world. 



Second biggest: find ideas and influences from all over integrated into our coursework and projects - both in the curriculum and in our super-curricular activities.
replies_ddqual: Dan - I like that you focus on both what we bring to campus, but also what our campus brings to the world. In order to be a global hub, I think we need to be fantastic at both.

Response:
It's not so much what's displayed, but the secret backstory about why it's hard to find that makes this emblematic to me. (No, I can't tell you.) 



I've been here long enough to have several great stories, but my favorite experiences are usually with juniors and seniors who have picked up a lot while here, and retain the enthusiasm and dedication to confront challenges while not letting their standards slip at all. When students can take in new and unexpected information, balance it against their intentions, and find a means to make them work together - I know they are likely to find Emerson a platform for greater success. 



Alumni weekend is often inspiring to see how fondly people recollect their Emerson years, and how personally valuable the connections to people and ideas were to them, regardless of their financial success.
Africa

Oh, look, a Wordle. 



Emerson is more focused on helping its students achieve than in addressing issues of hunger or poverty or civil war or terrorism. It would be nice to care about such things, but due to our limited impact on the world, and limited time and resources, we are constrained. I know Lee has worked to make things happen here, but his initiative is not enough. (I've earlier mentioned http://gunviolence.emerson.edu/ seems to be more taking up space than taking anything on at the moment.) 



How could Emerson help? The best thing that might be feasible, it seems to me, is the creation of some dedicated think-tanks, with which faculty or courses could partner and produce white-papers and dedicated studies centering on issues. We've relied for years on Harvard's Berkman Center, but we ought to be stating what communication means in the digital era, what intellectual property rights and ramifications could and should be, how significant things like Net Neutrality are for individuals, corporations, and nonprofits. We could and should be active in illuminating the stages of Boston, but also in assessing them and reviewing them. The skills our students need to succeed must be our primary focus, but accomplishing things with them ought to rank more highly. Other than the CommDisorders treatment center and the polling society, it is rare to see students, faculty, and staff engaged with producing or effecting change more than incrementally and in piecemeal fashion. 



I don't believe a Day of Service each semester would do much to fix anything. I do think when profs are given the discretion to follow their passions, things can happen. However, Proyecto Medellin would likely fall apart should Tamera Marko be appointed to a more-deserved position elsewhere, and in spite of the extracurricular groups continued pushing, efforts fitting change in during a few spare minutes is a drop in the ocean. 



If Emerson is willing to make social justice and societal reform a real goal, it will require time and energy and funding and long-term commitment. All of these are in such short supply, I am pessimistic Emerson is in any position to lead on this.

Response_ddqual:
There are a lot of places in the US and the world that could benefit from Emerson's unique expertise. But rather than LA, I suspect Nashville is a closer sister-city to Boston, and might provide more opportunity (and less ego) for our students to practice and our curriculum to impact the region. 



Though I'd love to hang out in Venezuela or New Zealand or whatever, in terms of areas where Emerson's sphere of influence could and should be greater, I'd stick closer to home. Cities like Nashville, Detroit, Chicago, and so on need to have their minds and art-scenes expanded, and their message communicated more effectively.

Response:
In 2014 - I went to one of the most exclusive institutions with a unique focus on areas of production and culture and was able to succeed there. I still have a lot to learn, but on my area of expertise, you can expect me to have some in-depth knowledge unavailable elsewhere. 



In 2020 - I made a firm decision to focus on success in one or more specific areas of the arts and communication, and to excel in it. Ask to see my portfolio! 



In 2030 - I know more about 1 or 2 things than most people in the room, but I haven't gotten more than a cursory exposure to many of the subjects and concepts taught in basic undergraduate courses. I hopefully have learned to teach myself well.

Julian is trying to weigh his interests against the marketplace's values, the world's values, and his own future values. This is stress-inducing. 



It helps if he believes his professors are providing him with worthwhile experiences, if the rigor of his elective courses do not get in the way of him meeting his self-identified needs, and if he gains anything at all from the experience. 



We know that Emerson students are far more likely to find value in their elective courses than in their required courses, and that the professors make a big difference. But what Julian wants to know is unknowable. Philosophy might teach him how to deal with unknowable matters, but a good college education must prepare him to defend his choices as well as accept the consequences of them.
Some but not all
Response_ddqual: Skills like seeking common ground and understanding differences are the basic of any decent undergraduate program, at least in the US. But learning the tools to clearly communicate and converse with someone with minimal common ground ifs growing more and more necessary by the day, and much of Emerson's efforts are focused on this.

Response: Protection 101 - the legal, physical, and social basics to insure you remain safe and in control as you begin to practice your chosen field of study and your adult life in a significantly wider, more complex,  and more dangerous world.
replies_ddqual: If there isnt one already, a class about the legal ins and outs of each field would be a great addition!

Response:
Depends on whether we take a utopian view or a dystopian one. 



If U, no more printing! Easy access to licensed resources, and good security to prevent account fraud or privacy violations! A safer campus, and less dire poverty on the streets of Boston! More options to work along an independent production model of my chosen field, or to work in one of the giant corporate structures providing access to all forms of media and entertainment! 



If D, more learning requirements! More testing and administrative positions requiring more boxes be checked and ovals be filled to jump through more hoops to demonstrate our compentency! Inclusiveness! More time spent replicating and distributing ideas than engaging with them! And lots more skype and video-based courses with fewer interactions with more overworked professors! 



But the T will probably be better regardless, and tuition is likely to be nearing $100,000/year. That's in either situation - because our utopias have to be realistic.
replies_ddqual:
I agree about tuition - but are you SURE the T will be better? (I mean, I hope really really hard - but I wonder if it'll be invested in or continue to limp along).\\ I remain skeptical about the T. I think future Emerson should provide us with company flying cars.



Also, a paper-free campus is my dream!!

Response:
Dawn's answer needs to be individual, and focused on her coursework and accomplishments. I could not presume to guess how she should answer, but I hope she'd speak about the psychological and philosophical effects of the arts, and how being conversant in these aspects of our culture and knowledgeable of our history of development, and of recent trends and movements, will affect the customer-base of this company.



But to be honest, all she needs to say is that in working with artists, she learned about psychological diseases and conditions such as megalomania, depression - both bipolar and monopolar - as well as schizophrenia and other forms of adversity. As psychological pharmaceuticals are a major growth area, having substantial experience with this client base will make her work more effective in generating sales.
replies_ddqual: Really, Dan? You trolling with this one? I'm usually able to ignore a troll, but this one was well played. Well played indeed. *slow clap*\\ thank you, thank you. But yeah, I HATE this question. \\ If she plays it for a laugh and it works, that response might get her the job, actually. People often hire based on how they think interacting with the person everyday will go (if the person "fits" the culture), and making them laugh during an interview helps. \\ I've been told that once you make it to the interview, the institution is trying to figure out who will fit best (and isn't lying completely), so Elena you have a very good point. \\ I think the point of these questions is to assess whether emerson is providing students with the rote language and talking points to answer these standard charges. However, much of our curriculum is about marketing oneself, and though students may do so very differently, it is fair to assume Emerson grads know how to connect & charm their way in the door. Getting farther is the real issue.

Response: Professional school
Response_ddqual: Emerson tries to some degree to be all of these things, but is most successful as a professional school. It is gaining in the liberal arts, and when a more interdisciplinary curriculum is finally completed it may provide some basic art and conservatory options to all students - but primarily, Emerson is about networking, developing professional skills, and building experience and a portfolio is a narrowly defined discipline. This is why it is so difficult for students to switch majors, or to find time to explore other interests.

When the campus is being shut down due to snow, Email and phone are best. If you need an answer from me, depending on what you're asking, try emailing or calling.

Response: Other (explain in comment)
Response_ddqual:
There are a lot of assumptions leading up to this question. 



I most value the diverse nature of passions, interests, abilities, and desires in the Emerson community - but I believe that diversity could span a greater swath than it currently does. I want to hear new ideas, see new means and methods of addressing more and more complex and novel concepts as our students learn and grow and develop here. I know a hefty portion of becoming an adult and a practitioner is reconciling with the past and recognizing strengths and flaws while expanding notions of what is authentic, what is possible, and even what is right and wrong. 



I distinguish multiculturalism from diversity, and am uncomfortable with the idea that one means the other in current discussions. Multiculturalism is a worthy goal, but methods of achieving it can be not just discriminatory, but hateful and hurtful. I'm not sure how well we've confronted that. But for the most part, our efforts are responsible and respectful.

Response:
Once again, I really want to see the previous answers. I suspect there are going to be a lot of folks with the exact same answer. 



But the BPL is the best answer i can think of to this question.
Colonial Building

Amira has a bunch of options, including some Emerson departments, courses, extracurriculars, and others. She will find them challenging, but hopefully rewarding. However, she'll learn more and do greater good for her community and herself by looking at Boston's opportunities and resources rather than Emerson's. While Emerson is working hard, most efforts and initiatives and programs at Emerson require immense amounts of energy and involve many people with multiple priorities all working at once. There is generally greater focus, clarity, and return on investment in working with external partners. 



Amira's academic advisors ought to help her in meeting this goal, as it is a learning goal. Similarly, her campus housing staff and residence folks should have ideas on how to get out of the Emerson community what she wants to accomplish. But Amira is not wrong to feel alone or frustrated - doing things here is not as simple as at schools who have made the community a more-active partner in campus culture.

Regular and steady community service is not really an option for me given my current circumstances. However, there is much that needs doing, and when i can, I do.

Response:
Bah! Emerson wants to be, but it doesn't understand itself - it's a corporate entity incapable of understanding. 



Social responsibility has been best defined here: http://site.ebrary.com/lib/emerson/Doc?id=10367801 as "Most definitions of corporate social responsibility describe it as a concept whereby companies integrate social and environmental concerns in their business operations and in their interaction with their stakeholders on a voluntary basis. Being socially responsible means not only fulfilling legal expectations, but also going beyond compliance and investing 'more' into human capital , the environment and the relations with stakeholders." (Commission of the European Communities, 2001:6)



What it ought to mean for Emerson is a clear statement of our priorities being social, environmental, and economic and political justice, enhancing access to Emerson's resources in a manner that provides our stakeholders with the benefits to counteract the costs we impose, and making every effort to increase transparency, democracy, and liberty in our dealings with each other and the world beyond our campus. 



Having recycling is not enough. (When does single-stream recycling start again?) Hosting debates is not enough. Setting priorities and making plans which involve our neighbors is a start in the right direction.
replies_ddqual: It doesnt answer all your issues, but the Colonial Building was remodeled with the environment in mind. They used; renewable resource wood, recycled glass, building materials mostly within 50 miles of Boston, and theres even a rain catch system! Its Gold LEED certified. And any usable office supplies gathered during Clean Out Your Office days are donated to one of the schools near us (I think its Urban College). Its a start!

This is a ridiculous question. Why not go into Chinatown and ask its residents? 



Who the residents are is going to make a huge difference in how this question is answered. However, I think it's significant  to note very few of Emerson's faculty, staff, and off-campus undergrads live in Chinatown. (I believe some of the more clever and cost-conscious grad-students do live in parts of Chinatown.) 



I wish the Paramount had a Sunday afternoon matinee series of Chinese-language films of significance to both Asian-American and Asian audiences. But I'd think we'd need to get Anna's concessions plan in place for it to have real appeal.

I don't think it's ridiculous to ask people to attempt empathy. I suspect the intended end result is not to act on our assumptions, but rather encourage us to try to consider our neighbors' perspectives as we go about our own business - and to be aware that we do, in fact, need to talk to them about our impact on them.\\ there's a difference between encouraging empathy and avoiding authentic responses. Emerson's ideas about what their neighbors theink of themselves is not as useful in my mind as directly inquiring from our neighbors how we affect them. I find this question elicits presumptions (and stereotypes) that I find uncomfortable at best. 



The Globe has done some good work on actually asking residents what's going on. I prefer this mode of idea-gathering: http://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/2013/09/06/chinatown-attracts-more-developers-and-rents-increase-local-residents-fear-being-pushed-out/iKX0eZr6DsjWab4hdbQFtO/story.html

Response: Of little importance
Response_ddqual:
Service learning is but one of thousands of learning activities available to college students. It provides a unique setting and style of learning, but not one identifiably superior to the other learning opportunities available to college students. What would be useful is to create partnerships with (other) nonprofits to provide opportunities for work-study students to do meaningful work, and to see more of Boston than an on-campus shift at (wherever) would allow them. 



Doing "volunteer" work for course credit or to enhance your resume may be useful for both students and orgs, but will lead to more administrative oversight at these sights of less than enthused student participants. Emerson is about following one's passions. Creating avenues for more contributions to effective orgs is useful, but only if matched with authentic enthusiasm.
replies_ddqual: I had friends in college who were able to use their work-study hours at local community organizations. They loved the experience. It was positive all around. That type of arrangement could be great for Emerson students. \\ grr, "sights" should be sites, obviously. The lack of an edit function is very frustrating to typo-prone writers.

Response: WGBH, ArtsBoston, and the Boston nonprofit movie theatres (that's to keep it to 3. But it's the Coolidge & the Brattle I mean. Cheap student/staff memberships would be AMAZING).
All of the above

Innovation is an overused term that largely means finding new ways to make money. (See the LA campus, for example.) 



Innovation within a community ought to mean more participation in community events - organizing representation in places of importance, as well as places of general opportunity. the Dragon-boat team is probably the best example of this. 



Emerson has little trouble proposing new ideas, though one could argue how sound some of those ideas are. What Emerson lacks is follow-through. The president's gun-violence initiative/letter-to-Obama was good for headlines, but had little legislative or therapeutic or long-term beneficial effect. 



I can speculate as to why innovation fails to find a foothold here: students, faculty, and staff are stretched too thin, don't have adequate space or time to operate effectively, and cannot get beyond their professional commitments to devote the necessary thought and energy to anything else. Have you seen the people who get tenure? They are burned out. And have you seen everyone else? They're on the verge of burnout and juggling more commitments than they can possibly meet. 



Creating new centers and administrators is how Emerson lays claim to being innovative. but that isn't going to provide much for the larger community, other than give them more options to drop money. (Thank you, season ticketholders.)
replies_ddqual:
Thanks for the Dragon Boat shoutout, Dan C!  

I disagree that everyone is stretched too thin, though.  But the ones who are don't always want to authorize the ones who aren't burned out to do innovative projects. Empowering the people who are not high profile administrators to act on innovative ideas would help Emerson move forward.\\ and hey, empowering the mid-management people would be innovative in itself!\\ I'm glad someone disagrees! I'm not sure how you can - it seems plain on its face students, faculty and staff are combating collapse much of the time - but I like to think those who make making change a priority find the will and the way to do so. \\ Innovation needs money. The college can't support students in LA if they have mediocre resources there. One of the truest things I've found about large organizations is that you need to spend money to make money, and with more money you can take more risks. With a college, you answer to students and trustees, not shareholders. So, as long as there are revenue streams in place, there will be a way to safely try out new programs that can help students.

Response:
Mostly I participate by being careful where I put the few spare $'s I've got. Dunkin donuts, CVS, Subway, and 7/11 may be cheaper, but other than hiring a few folks contribute nothing to the local community. Investing in locally-owned and independently-operated businesses in the neighborhood is the best means of preventing downtown Boston from becoming another Times Square. 



AMC still gets a ton of my money, though. (But I sneak in snacks from better places.) 



Other than spending on consumables, the best means of contributing to the surrounding culture is to make your own voice heard, and to listen to what's going down with everyone else. It's sad that at a school of communication, we don't focus more on listening and interpreting.
replies_ddqual: Do you have a favorite place for snacks beyond CVS and 7-11?\\ Sal's pizza is pretty good. The Chinatown grocery stores are always fun.

I would need to actually meet Ken to give him good advice. I think this question was inspired by the Drexel kid's post on every college subreddit (e.g. http://www.reddit.com/r/EmersonCollege/comments/2bwryi/looking_to_gtfo_of_drexel_emerson_hows_your/ ) this summer. 



This question is asking about Emerson's vibe, Emerson's program, and Boston as a whole. Each of these is too complex to address a caricature like Ken.

Response_ddqual:
I said in class, but what I meant was doing the reading, writing, thinking, and projects the courses require. 



Emerson focuses a lot on team projects, and there is stuff to be learned in those exercises, but group projects in class don't teach as much as the self-selected groups in the rest of college life. The difference is this: if a group includes a faculty member by choice, it's worthwhile. It's when profs treat students as colleagues that most learning happens.
replies_ddqual: I wonder if others agree about not learning as much in the group projects vs a self-selected project?   Seems like this could vary by person.\\ It's my hypothesis that it's true. Response: Student-Instructor Ratio, Opportunities to do original work, Other (explain)
Response_ddqual: I believe the team devising the Academic Excellence initiative has it wrong. Academic Affairs doesn't get to define excellence. Lee Pelton cannot decree what is excellent and then measure Emerson's progress towards his goal. Every student, every staff member, and every member of faculty has an individual standard of excellence which guides them through their own work, and it is the blending of all of these standards that determines the overall excellence of our campus. Students must be given the most freedom, the best opportunities, and the presence of partners and tools to achieve their own learning, thinking, and understanding. Students won't know for 5 or 10 years if their academic experience was excellent or regrettable - and it will be a measure of what they could have done and thought and developed and what they did. But it is never going to happen with a top-down approach. We are thinking of this concept wrongly. We should be identifying barriers to excellence and fixing them.
replies_ddqual: Another good thing about the library--it's a natural showplace for original student work! If only we had the space...

Response: Common Ground

Joanne, unfortunately, your success in transitioning is going to depend a lot on the quality and support of your initial work in courses and projects. IF you were a successful writer, and have found a new area of interest, you will likely be able to meet the people and impress them to make this process less onerous. If, however, you realized your initial track wasn't for you by not succeeding in it, you will find it hard to find people with the faith required to support you in this switch. 



If you suspect it might be easier to transfer than to switch, investigate that option. If however you are passionate about Emerson, and have the support of your collaborators, work your way up the chains of command to demand access to the courses and opportunities you need to succeed. Choosing a major at Emerson is like jumping on a train - there's a lot of momentum that can just carry you along. Switching majors, however, is like  Michelle Yeoh - it only looks easy if you know exactly what you're doing and have a team of hidden supporters in the background.
replies_ddqual: Michelle Yeoh video for the win.

Response:
Much of Emerson seems built on pulling in creative thinkers and hearing them, but doing very little with their efforts, initiatives, and ideas. Emerson as an institution is better at promotion than creativity - because the administrative structure (Emerson is so to-heavy, btw) is risk-averse. Take this game for example. How much dialogue can their be if you are forced to answer before seeing other people's answers? Every librarian chips in their "The library is wonderful" but none of these responses acknowledges what's been said already.



This format is only going to produce many versions of the same ideas. That's uncreative, and unhelpful. I am very disappointed in this exercise - it reminds me of square-dancing in gym class.
replies_ddqual: Dan - I think that the interesting dialogue comes from the comments that people make on each others' experiences once they read them. Just because they answered the question without seeing what had already been said doesn't mean they can't continue to comment.\\ I hear you, but I resent answering a question without seeing previous answers. And I can't participate in the dialogue until I commit to an answer - and as far as I can tell, I can't edit my original response in light of what the previous responses reveal. I agree, it could be worse! But my point is I think it should be better. \\ Dan, I think that as the game progresses, and players become more comfortable we might see more thoughtful and perhaps more honest responses. Perhaps we have to answer before seeing other answers to lessen the chance of being influenced by other opinions, which is good, I think.\\ Thanks Maureen - I hope you're right! But call me a critic (Dan is Hebrew for "judge", y'know...) - I don't see this format as producing our best thinking or our most honest responses. I fear what's going to happen is they game-masters are going to throw all responses for each "challenge" (a misuse of the term, btw) into a Wordle to see which concepts and phrases are mentioned most often. I definitely would benefit from seeing others responses prior to posting my own - but I can see how people might not want to do that. Still, not having the option seems a serious flaw in the "game" to me. \\ From what I understand, anyone in the community is allowed to access this data and do their own analysis. \\ I hope this is true - that would be a benefit. But I'm still pretty sure you cannot access responses prior to submitting a response. Maybe I'm missing something obvious? \\ I think you are correct about that detail, but I'm just not sure that it stifles creativity as much as you are concerned that it does. The benefit of asking you to answer without seeing others' responses, as I understand it, is that your response won't be influenced by the responses of others. This helps avoid "crowd think."

Response: Once a month
Response_ddqual: It's frequent I'm in touch with a few members of other departments. It's rare I have the opportunity to collaborate with faculty or staff outside my building. But I'm grateful to IT, ITG, and many members of staff in Academic Affairs for being considerate, helpful, inspiring, and generous in helping me accomplish more than I could on my own.

http://www.emerson.edu/academics/academic-services/library/databases - enjoy!

Response: I've enjoyed hearing many guest speakers on campus - particularly via the wonderful Bright Lights film series. However, the best learning moment for me was in the spring orf 2012 when both current students and alumni demanded serious change to the staffing of our athletics department - ultimately resulting in the resignation of an athletics director. Seeing Emerson students and alums make a demand to the administration, and make the case that ultimately convinced Emerson to make a dramatic change showed me most clearly what and how students were learning to do as communicators and as standard-bearers.
The primary communal & meeting place for Emerson students at the College's Back Bay campus (130 Beacon Street)

Hi Maria, I apologize if you've heard this a hundred times already, but since i can't see earlier responses...   To succeed at Emerson, you primarily need to know how to engage with new concepts and tools, and how to ask good questions. You also need to be willing to explore opportunities in the wider Boston area - the insulated nature of Emerson's curriculum can inhibit participation in one of the world's greatest and most accessible cities. Response: I really enjoyed my Lit of Extreme Situations class with Professor Doug Anderson in spring of 2014. We were covering literature of the 1960s and I was looking at all the movements that were going on a the same time and I began to feel as though my brain was pressing on the inside of my skull, which I'm told is what it feels like to have your mind blown. Also it was finals week and I hadn't slept properly in a very long time. I looked up from the material we were covering and just kind of thought, "Wow."
The primary communal & meeting place for Emerson students at the College's Back Bay campus (130 Beacon Street)

You need your material school supplies and a laptop--life is so much easier here if you have a laptop. You must go to the dining hall, preferably with people; you must make a "food buddy" to make sure you remember to eat, if nothing else; and RAs are pretty important if you're worried about getting out of your shell. A good RA can make a world of difference.

My "most Emerson" experience would probably be during the first week of freshman orientation, where a few people who lived on my floor invited some people over to play Settlers of Catan, in which you lay out roads and towns on a map. At one point during the game I looked up and asked, "Does anyone else feel tempted to make a Robert Frost reference here?" and the kid opposite me said, "You're in the right school."

Response_ddqual: I feel like diversity of staff and students leads to a more well rounded community. We can learn and grow as a result of being accepting of different views and opinions. Response: I think my best learning moment was when I interviewed a professor for a speech I was writing. The speech was about what it takes to be successful in the industry. One of the things that struck me was when my professor said that success is whatever you want it to be. "Making it big" for one person might be different for another. It is really up to you to give value to your career and life in general. It is all about your outlook on life.
replies_ddqual:
Interesting point!  We don't all have to define "success" in the same way.  It's very Emersonian to think inventively about things, so career & life goals can be defined by each of us individually.  

Ultimately, my sense is that Emerson students will have many opportunities to value and revalue, define and redefine their goals and accomplishments.  Careers are fluid!

Irashai- for sushi (salmon avocado ftw!) and incredibly inexpensive chicken katsu with the most delicious Asian veggies I've ever had.

Tantric- for Indian food and the $12 all you can eat lunch buffet- check this out if you're looking for a fun, high quality, and inexpensive lunch.

Blackjack Pasta- make your own pasta and they have *FREE* delivery until midnight! You choose what kind of pasta you want, which sauce, and then choose from over 35 different mix ins and toppings. I liked to order BJP with my roommates last year.

Bova's Bakery- for Italian pastries and desserts in the North End. Go with your friends at 2 AM, it's open 24/7!

Forum- My brother's favorite restaurant in Boston.. they have sophisticated comfort food like chicken noodle soup, brick chicken, and steak and cheese egg rolls. This one's a little more expensive. Wait until your parents come to town for this one.

Papa Razzi- another great Italian place. I go here with my mom when she comes to visit. Get the gnocchi! It's amazing :3



THEATRE! If you're a theatre major in Boston, like me, it's ridiculous to not take advantage of all of the amazing opportunities to see free/cheap theatre. The Boston theatres that show touring productions (Colonial Theatre, Opera House) have student rush tickets for $25. It's an easy way to see professional shows. Other companies like ArtsEmerson have $10 tickets for students, and regional theatres like the Lyric Stage and Speakeasy also offer inexpensive student tickets. I saw Sweeney Todd at the Lyric for $10 once. Because of these cheap tickets, I am able to see a show or two every week. It's really a great opportunity that I wouldn't have any other way.

My friends and I are insane. I love these people so much. Without them, I don't know what I would do. What we would do last year is a weekend would roll around and we'd all be sitting around Friday night. Someone would say "Oh, wouldn't it be funny if we made a film about..." and we'd shoot around ideas. Saturday, we would shoot the movie itself. We never had written scripts. It was improvised, but we would add in really good moments that we had thought of the night before. Sunday, they would edit the footage, and then we would have it live on YouTube by Monday or Tuesday. My friends lived on the Film Immersion floor last year, and they were all very passionate filmmakers, so they enjoyed making shorts like this. This particular one, "Pickup Sticks", was inspired by one of my friends after he broke his foot. Enjoy! :)

Maria, my love! Here, come sit with me. Let me buy you a tea and tell you like it is. Here are my top five tips for succeeding at Emerson your freshman year.



5) Get involved. There are SO many groups on campus that can fulfill any of your extracurricular needs. Like to write? Try Emertainment Monthly or ISIS Magazine. Not a theatre major, but looking to step into the spotlight? The four major theatre orgs on campus allow every student the opportunity to participate in live theatre both on and offstage. Feeling sporty? Join Emerson's Quidditch team, a popular Harry Potter inspired sport that actually goes to championship levels! There are tons of opportunities for you, and not only will you learn new skills, but you'll also make friends and connections that will last a lifetime.



4) Find time to study. Emersonians are very engaged in their craft, regardless of what it is, but don't let that deter from your time to complete your homework and other class assignments. The cool thing is that professors are usually in tune to the fact that we are all artists, and will probably let you tailor the assignment to fit something you're interested in. I got an A+ on a Pop Culture essay last year because I asked my teacher to let me tailor the topic to feminism in French New Wave movies. Never be afraid to approach a professor for help, and know that you can always talk to them at their office hours or via email.



3) Keep yourself open to friends and people in general. I feel like during freshman year, it's easy to fall into two categories. There's the people who want to be friends with EVERYONE and overexert themselves to the point where they're just not making meaningful relationships, and there's the people who don't ever want to leave their rooms and refuse to make friends of any kind. The people you meet during orientation week might not be the BFFs you thought they would be. You might not get along well with your roommate. Some days, you might feel like no one wants to be friends with you.. and hey, that's all okay. But keep yourself open. Emerson is a great place because people are so passionate about what they do. Find people who share your passions and seek friendships with them. You'll be better off with a few good friends that way.



2) Make time for YOU. Emerson, though it is wonderful, can be a stressful place. We are living in a glorified artist's commune, and tempers can run high when you have lots of creative people together in a small space. It's okay not to go out every night. It's okay to stay in and watch Netflix and order takeout. Do something each day that makes you happy. Whether it's going for a walk in the Public Garden, or buying yourself a tea latte at Starbucks, do one thing a day for yourself. You will be so much happier that way.



1) Enjoy Emerson. Enjoy Boston. Take in all that it has to offer. Four years go by SO fast. I know, I'm almost halfway through sophomore year. Just let yourself enjoy the ride. I promise, it's a good one.

Another being our discussion, response & subsequent steps to change the culture around power-based interpersonal violence.  All of these steps can help to push these ideas outside of the Emerson bubble as more students graduate with this knowledge.

As a journalism student, I'd like to see more partnerships with local news outlets. I know that we partner with The Boston Globe and many students get internships at local news outlets, but it would be really helpful for the students if the department had great relationships with multiple local news outlets.



I would also like to see Emerson reach out to students in the Boston Public Schools. Emerson is a unique school, and it would be really cool to see the Emerson community get kids excited about journalism, film, theatre etc.

The VMA department always seems to be doing some pretty interesting things, though that is from an outsider's perspective. It seems that much of the innovation on campus comes from student organizations. For example, students who work at WERS and WECB are always coming up with great new ideas for radio. Another concrete example of innovation I've noticed is with the annual student entrepreneurial contest that happens every year. I'm sure there's a lot of other innovative stuff going on, but it's not something most students notice.

I've gotten the chance to explore Boston during my time at Emerson. One of my favorite things about this college is the location. You are so close to everything. For someone who grew up in rural New England, that's amazing. From Emerson you can walk to Chinatown, the North End, the waterfront, the Esplanade and so many other great places.

Response: I learned a lot about myself when I had to work, more or less unguided, on a thesis project. Talk about staring into the mirror of the abyss! I had to produce evidence of my capability to a judge harsher than any professor: myself. In the end, I wasn't happy with what I did, but everyone else was. That was the truest lesson I learned at Emerson: it is a lot easier to please other people than it is to please myself.

In the Communication Sciences and Disorders undergrad and graduate programs, we provide clinical services to help children and adults with speech, language, cognition and swallowing problems. Many of the clients we see have diagnoses such as autism, stuttering disorders, communication deficits after stroke, hearing loss and more. We are trying to help solve issues related to healthcare. I would love to grow our undergraduate program so that we can help more people in the immediate Boston community.

Right now, I think that Emerson graduates have been immersed in their fields throughout college and are very able to work immediately following graduation. In 2020 or 2030, I wouldn't expect that to have changed.

The Communication Sciences and Disorders undergrad and graduate programs are deeply invested in providing speech, language, hearing and cognitive therapy to members of the Boston community. We do this in community settings, hospitals, schools, early intervention companies, etc. as well as our own clinic located within 216 Tremont.
replies_ddqual: This is an awesome example of community engagement! It's not new or flashy and won't get us written up on BostonInno / get a ton of retweets / be as visible as the theater marquees, but it is a solid, established and well respected part of the Boston community. It is a great example of us using our expertise to provide something the community needs and is interested in. When I was teaching we were thankful to have undergrads coming through doing screenings, and would refer parents to Emerson if they had concerns about their child's speech or language.

Response_ddqual: It depends on the class. It would be a difficult task to force people in a writing class to go serve the community when they should be/are paying for a class to teach them writing skills. If you were in a nutrition class, for instance, and you needed to learn how to plant healthy foods or sustain organic food, then, maybe, something like this makes sense. But I don't think it is fair to force this into every class at Emerson. Some things are just meant to be learned from trial and error, not always service learning. I also believe in 'learning by doing.' You can't really learn by doing if you aren't doing what you're supposed to be learning.

Response_ddqual: I learn something new literally every day. I ask too many questions as it is; it is inevitable that I will learn something new...but at Emerson I have people and professors around me who are willing to humor my curiosity and thus I retain a little more every day.

Response: The best learning experience I have had thus far is being able to meet with some of my advisors, who are both expert screenwriters and also excellent sources of information for me as I try to make my way into the working world and a career in film. They totally surprised me; I went in there thinking "Ok, I'm going out on a limb here asking for help, so I shouldn't expect any miracles." But I was completely blown away at how willing and able they were in helping me--people who actually cared about my future and my education giving me advice, telling me the best books to read, and supporting me with the knowledge I needed. Nothing like my previous schools where my advisors were confused and angry at me for seeking help.
The primary communal & meeting place for Emerson students at the College's Back Bay campus (130 Beacon Street)

Maria definitely needs to first take advantage of the excellent counseling services the Academic Advising department has to offer as she maps out a plan of action for the next four years. The advising office certainly helped me get on the fast track to simultaneously enjoying my social time at Emerson but focusing also on getting my credits in order and maintaining strong academic strategy. At the end of the day, you come to Emerson to get an education first, and make connections second. Although Maria can and should focus on making connections at Emerson, nobody is going to want to work with (or hire) her if she falls of the academic bandwagon and can't keep up with school to begin with. After seeking out advising, Maria should join clubs. That is the #1 way I have found I can explore my options and get a feel for possible interests at Emerson. It is also where I meet a majority of the people I socialize with and learn from working with and is the best career practice I can get. I would tell Maria to be successful at Emerson College she should find a healthy and comfortable balance between the academic demands she faces and the socializing and exploring she should do while in college. A happy medium works well.

I am most excited about being part of the Emerson Community when I am a part of a large production and am able to collaborate with my fellow students to create something bigger than ourselves. One thing that is magical to me about creating any kind of art is that it is achieved with double the passion when it is accomplished by a group. There is definitely strength in numbers, and I see it every day at school. Whether it be an animated movie, a group performance, or a publication; getting together with people, holding a role, and contributing to a project much larger than something I would do on my own makes me feel like a part of the Emerson Community. We have a special sort of style at Emerson that I am very proud of and we can bring out the best in each other when we create something huge.

Response_ddqual: I always find myself at the Campus Center at Piano Row. I feel like it is the heart of the campus for off-campus students particularly, if not all students who are actively involved at Emerson. It's that one place where we all meet and collaborate. Most of the clubs I am a part of gather here. This is where auditions, crew calls, and meetings occur; and I feel the most sense of community when I am in this building.
replies_ddqual: What would you say is your favorite spot in the Campus Center?\\ Probably the lounge area upstairs. I am off-campus, so it's one place where I can really feel at ease, like I'm not going to get kicked out or told the area is primarily for on-campus students (i.e., the dining hall, where I have been told to leave and that I couldn't bring my own lunch in). The only issue is how uncomfortably small the lounge is at the Max. If a bunch on on-campus kids want to hang out there, obviously nobody can stop them, but if they are there using all the electrical jacks, sitting in all the seats, and taking up all the space--it kind of leaves me nowhere to go, and that's my only beef with it. Since they all have their own dorms to sit in, that makes me a little angry, because if I need to charge my computer or sit down during the day it is the only place I can go other than our way-too-crowded library. Otherwise it is the best part of the Campus Center.

Response_ddqual: Hi, guys. I messaged the head of the Off-Campus Department with this proposal and want to hear your take. I could be going out on a limb but I suppose this is the best place to do it. I was thinking about a lot of the different things I could do to help the off-campus community at Emerson College. Since I came to Emerson last year as a sophomore and lived off-campus now for both of my years at Emerson, I have been tossing around ideas in my head about what might be done to improve the quality of commuting/off-campus life for students like myself at school. One of the things Community Plan-it has been asking us repeatedly is what areas at school we feel most welcome, and which we don't. I have realized from these prompts that aside from the one area at the Campus Center and the library (if there are ever any seats), there is really nowhere for commuters to go during the day that isn't also swamped with dorm students who very well could be in their rooms; instead they are hogging (cont.)

the precious wall chargers and taking up the seats from people who have been riding trains and lugging books all day. I understand they are students too, and would never discriminate, but one of the things I would want to donate my points for on Community Plan-it would be an off-campus student union of sorts--maybe a group of people who could organize and vouch for areas on campus specifically for off-campus kids to take a load off and feel welcome. I have never felt more disconnected from Emerson than when the woman swiping cards at the dining hall told me I couldn't eat my bagged lunch there, and since the library was closed I had to sit outside or in some random store to eat my lunch. I felt so cast out. I think if the off-campus students could have their own lounge with a dining area, maybe it would make a lot of people's lives easier who could finally have a voice that were to afraid to speak up. What do you think? I wholly back this idea if others are in the same boat.
replies_ddqual: I agree that a space for off-campus students would be great, but one of Emerson's biggest problems in general is just ... lack of space. Lack of rehearsal space, performance space, study space, lounging space, it all falls under that umbrella, unfortunately.\\ Yeah, this is also true. But, still, it is worth a shot to maybe just expand one area, since the faculty are pledging to have their own faculty space as well (I thought that there was a grad student/professor lounge the faculty used in Ansin?) maybe what Emerson needs to do is acquire a new building overall. That would be fantastic. We have a really ambitious community that needs more space. But $1,000 couldn't really do that for us right now anyways...hopefully in the future.

Response_ddqual: I don't know where to post this or how to link it to the therapy dog cause, but isn't $1,000 a little steep to have simply have dogs come visit the school? I'm not against it, and plan to donate my coins to it, but I'm just hoping this is not something that is spent frivolously and will actually buy more than lint rollers and advertising that the event described. I've advertised for my own services on campus before for literally $2.50 in printing and online ads. It just seems a little ridiculous to throw $1,000 towards therapy dog 'lint rollers and advertising.' Couldn't that be expanding upon more? Why not go the extra mile and make it 'Relaxation Week' with therapy dogs. My last school did that and it was great...free food, I think we stuffed some bears or something, and we fundraised as well. Why not make this into something bigger and make sure the money goes where it can help relax students besides trivial details? (Dollar Store lint rollers are a thing!) I like the idea.
replies_ddqual:
Christina,

You have a good point, and the group that's been planning for the Therapy Dogs has been planning complimentary activities to support it which would use the money.  We've been thinking of calling it a "Cirque de De-stress" to emphasize its variety. For example, we plan to have sites for students/staff/faculty to de-stress in other ways, such as an arts & crafts area, the WARC tutors who can do short reviews of writing, ECAPS staff doing relaxation activities, and possibly a massage therapist for the students' hands, shoulders, etc.  



We have received additional support from a couple of offices due to our visibility in this game, so what we're planning has been broadening as a result.  And yes, we hope that this can happen at least once a semester going forward (after all, Harvard has dogs in weekly)-- with the dogs and other ways to support students towards relaxation, both in the moment & for acquiring tools for ongoing de-stressing. \\ Hi Christina,



The $1000 would not be spent on lint rollers and face masks, but is insurance in case there's unforeseen damage to college property. Assuming we do not need to spend $ on repairs and clean-up, we will have the funds to do it again the following semester (if the first semester is successful.) 



Due to the nature of events, more money needs to be in reserve than is spent on events. But unspent money will be used as a springboard to future success. \\ Additionally, Paws for People is a non-profit organization and volunteers do this work of their own volition. It would be nice if Emerson could turn around and make a donation to this group.\\ Thanks for the clarification! Like I said, I'm backing this idea with all my coins anyways, I was just worried based off the description that the money would be distributed in a funny way...but seeing now that this will indeed be a long term thing and include insurance makes much more sense. We are a mass of stressed out students and I think this would benefit everybody, glad it's turning out popular.\\ And perhaps most importantly, without making this a Cause, we would not be receiving the visibility we have been needing to gain approval from top admins.  



Committed staff have been advocating for Therapy Dogs for three (3) years (!) already, and it's not until this public forum and students/staff/faculty combining to voice support that we've made significant progress to realizing the goal. 

Woof!

Response_ddqual: Emerson is collectively one of the most stressed-out communities I've seen! We need puppies, stat.
