Ken has the right idea about the college "vibe" of Boston. It's a vibrant city and provides you with many different ways to spend your day. Boston is a big city that has a small town feel. With Emerson's location, you can experience many different aspects of the city, and most of them are just a short walk away. Ultimately, the decision to enroll here should be based on many different factors. However, if "city with a college vibe" is high on Ken's list, then Emerson is the right place for him.

Response: The best learning experience I had at Emerson was in Intercultural Communication taught by Chester Lee at Kasteel Well. The entire class was about understanding different cultures and how different actions are interpreted throughout cultures. We also spent a lot of time comparing the culture in the United States to those in Europe. I found it to be endlessly fascinating and I learned more about life in that one class than I had in my 19 years on the planet. In fact, because of how much I loved this course, I decided to pick up Leadership and Management as a minor so that I could continue this kind of study.

Response: Thom Mayne

When I was in Dublin, visiting Trinity College, I talked to a few students there that I was from Emerson, and they knew right away where I was. They even knew that Emerson was in the Theatre District of Boston! Now, it might be because Boston seems to be pretty familiar to many Dubliners (can't imagine why), but I've gotten acknowledgments of knowing about Emerson from people across Europe. With our China programs ramping up, I'm hoping even more people from overseas hear about us. As always, I want Emerson to be perceived as being a school for people who are passionate and creative.
replies_ddqual: That's great to hear!

Response: Steady stream of international artists, communications experts, and scholars visting our camupus, Regularly cited in the press about our specialty fields
Response_ddqual: I wanted to include a higher percentage of international students, faculty and staff in this, but with rising tuition costs and the ability for so many foreign students to be educated for a fraction of the cost in their home countries, I can only see students who a) have a lot of financial resources and b) have a burning desire to study in the United States coming here in the future. However, visiting scholars and the press are what drives foreign minds to Harvard, MIT, Stanford, Oxford, and La Sorbonne. So, baring a major change in how college educations are financed in the future, I think those two items are good bellwethers.

Response: It's a short anecdote, but I think it sums up my Emerson experience nicely: the teacher who influenced me the most at Emerson was Richard Hoffman, and even though I graduated in 2003, I can still go to his office and chat with him about writing and life in general. The relationships we make at Emerson among all of us Emersonians goes far beyond the desire to get a piece of paper after four years.

This is the hardest question yet! It's also really unfair. Society has many problems. Too much to solve on a case-by-case basis. Betterment of society needs to be more general, and I think that Emerson can only really help by continuing to give students the opportunity to experience other people and the world and hone their skills in empathy and passion. When a society has more empathy and the will to act on it, big things happen in terms of social justice and peace.

Response_ddqual: Easy! I'd spend some time working with the renewable and geo thermal power companies there. Not in the engineering aspect (though that is very interesting) but in the out reach. These are the kinds of operations that Emerson alumni would excel in, since I believe that we want to be challenged, to be creative, and do good in the world.
replies_ddqual: I could see you sitting in one of those geothermal hot tubs with a drink in your hand!\\ Been there, done that, and every day wish I could do it again...every day.

Response: Emerson is well known for it's "Mafia", which is almost as prolific as Harvard's alumni culture, as well as it's uniqueness among US colleges. The degree shows that while you have a technical proficiency, you're also able to think critically and have gone through a more traditional set of core, liberal arts classes. In 2020 or 2030? Tough to tell, but as long as Emerson continues to expand it's global influence, than students will be able to show potential employers that they have the ability to work across cultural borders as well excel within a US college environment.

Allow me to quote from the great A Fish Called Wanda:



"Apes don't read philosophy."

"Yes they do, Otto. They just don't understand it."



In all of the talk about STEM majors, they're finding that people focused in the hard sciences aren't as able to think creatively as STEM majors who have taken art, philosophy, and other humanity courses. These types of courses foster new ways of thinking, which can be applied to professional fields in cool and creative ways.
replies_ddqual: WWWWWWWanda!\\ That's true.  If all you see is your little piece of the universe, how will you ever make a discovery that might not fit in that mold?

Response: Yes
Response_ddqual: First and foremost, Emerson reinforced the need to be open to different types of people, and to listen to other points of view. As the world becomes "smaller", very disparate cultures are colliding a breakneck speeds. There is potentially something else at work here, though, in that I think Emerson attracts the kinds of people who wouldn't be afraid to try and learn and speak (badly) a very foreign language to try and break the ice. Or, the kind of person who isn't afraid to go out on a limb and try that cultural activity that is bizarre to Americans (naked sauna, business dealings anyone?). So, maybe it wasn't part of Emerson's curriculum, but it's innate culture that helped me feel comfortable in a multicultural world.

Response: I think Emerson will eventually have to offer up some kind of UX major. User Experience is the next stage of User Interface design in that, as we move into a service-based economy, products are more holistic. Products not only have to DO something, but they need to make us FEEL something. Think Disney World versus Six Flags. They're both amusement parks, but one has a much bette handle on UX. This major would probably live in the School of Communication, as it's a close relative to Advertising/Marketing, but UX is something that may be evolving in the visual arts as well. Especially as things like 3D film, AAA gaming, and other interactive story telling techniques continue to grow.
replies_ddqual: I would like to see a UX major offered as well.

Response: I'll assume that technology will make things look different, but the behavior will be the same. I imagine people will still want to sit around and talk, but it will be common to have someone video conferencing in as, by this time, bandwidth has gotten much better. As online education continues to take off, there will always be a market for face-to-face communication and education, as that's how our brains are wired to work. Larger, lecture-based classes could be done in real-time via video conferencing, and smaller groups could utilize the limited space we have on campus.

All marketing is story telling. It's a simple as that. If you have a background in writing, or film, or any narrative medium, you'll be able to effectually communicate a message that will resonate with the audience you want to inform. Being able to construct a narrative (in this case, why someone would need the drugs that you're selling) and have proof that you have experience in that activity will separate Dawn from the other, focus-group, market-tested applicants.
Something else entirely
Response_ddqual: Emerson is definitely in a unique arena when it comes to curriculum. I would say all of the option could fit within the Emerson model, as students can customize how they want to engage with their classes as they go through their undergrad experience. By the end of senior year, most students are doing professional level work (often in the actual profession due to Internship Programs). Yet, along the way, most Emersonians would have taken a course that resembled something found within an art school, liberal arts college, or a conservatory.

Response: Socially responsible does NOT mean politically correct. Emersonians are many things, but we're not PC. Social responsibility at Emerson is driven 100% by empathy and drive to treat everyone else with respect. When I came here as a freshman in 1999, it was known for being the most gay friendly school in the country, and it still is! But, it's gay friendly not just because it has a student GLBT group, but because all of the straight students don't treat their gay peers with a fear of "otherness". Same goes for the transexual community, minority communities, and religious communities on campus. Different people coming together is one of the Emerson signatures! Which, in America, seems radical. But, to Emersonians, it just is.
Elma Lewis School of Fine Arts

Emerson's relationship to Chinatown is unique in the city as far as I know. There are no other schools that border such a specific, cultural inlet. Chinatown, due to it's cultural importance to so many Asian immigrants, has much different needs and values than say Allston or Newton. Like other neighborhoods around colleges, I'm sure that Emerson is as much a source of irritation to Chinatown inhabitants as it is a boon for their businesses and services. In the end, having a large organization at your doorstep most likely always benefits more than it detracts, but I don't see Emerson and the Chinatown community actively engaging with each other very much.
replies_ddqual: I totally agree with you, Chris. I have not seen any engagement with the residents of Chinatown. How to do that? Would the residents welcome that? Has anyone attempted it and did it work or not?\\ Agreed Chris! I don't see Emerson engaging with the community at all. \\ As I told Jenn, we need to engage with their restaurants. Peach Farm anyone?

Response: Very important
Response_ddqual: We've known for a while that learning that is restricted to just the classroom, or compartmentalized, is less effective than continual learning strategies. Traditional colleges leave the learning time outside of the classroom to be organized and decided on by students without any guidance from their peers or faculty for the most part. Building in hands-on learning would help give students more options when it comes to applying their passions and majors earlier in their college career.

Response: First and foremost, we should partner with the City of Boston itself, especially with their Innovation District endeavor (http://www.innovationdistrict.org/faq/). There are so many opportunities here in Boston for communication internships that could lead to jobs for graduates who aren't interested in the West Coast. Emerson should also partner with Mass General and Tufts Medical for a place to engage our health commutation and communication disorders students. Finally, we should work to expand overseas study options as they are still very limited when compared to other colleges in the Boston area. So, this means finding other schools to partner with in Europe, Asia, and the Americas.
replies_ddqual: Latin America for sure!

Response: All of the above

This is such a broad question! Which community to do we want to focus on? Also, for me, the one component of innovation that no one wants to acknowledge is failure. We talk about entrepreneurial opportunities as what will grow our economy and communities, but 99% of those ventures fail. I think that whatever community that we want to make a new for ourselves in, whether it be civic engagement and social justice, or giving students more resources to help with their own startups, we need to build into account both a safe way for the college to not waste funds and a place where students can potentially regroup, learn from their mistakes, and try again.
replies_ddqual: This is the best approach to take!\\ Some one much smarter than myself said " We are doomed to repeat history if we don't learn from it." Failure is definitely an option if we learn from it!

Response: Boston really is a world-class city, and it's big enough to be able to enjoy a Rembrandt without having to deal with the lines of the Louvre. One thing that my husband and I have been doing is enjoying the theater that is presented by Emerson Stage. Some of the best (in terms of quality and bang for your buck) shows in town are at the Semel and Black Box. A few years ago we saw a production of The Grapes of Wrath, and there wasn't a dry eye in the house! While I would never recommend this for undergrads under 21 (obviously), Boston has a surprisingly rich pub culture. I was very pleased to return from Dublin to know that our pubs are often just as vibrant. I think that stems from Boston being a world city, but still being very local-centric. We enjoy each other's company for the most part (except on the T during rush hour).
replies_ddqual: That is one thing that we can say with pride... Boston is a worldly city!

Honestly, if Ken wants to have more options with majors, he's better off going to Ithaca. Emerson is full of very smart people, who are also in the top of their high school classes, but the school is too specialized for people who don't really know that they want something related to communication or the arts. However, in terms of "vibrant community", Ken will find no better school than Emerson. Few colleges in America allow so many students to be so accepted and be themselves at the same time. And, that's not just about GLBTQ students. Emerson has all the same stereotypes as other schools these days, but the students are seen mingling with each other and aren't nearly as cliquish as they are in other area schools.

Response: Before I came to Emerson, I knew I wanted to be a filmmaker. Done. Easy. Except Emerson taught me the collaborative nature of creative work. I realized that I was really terrible at cinematography, but I really loved editing and acting. I also found a love for creative writing, especially memoir. I went in knowing I was going to be a digital filmmaker, and left with a major I made my own that combined all the things I liked! Emerson not only gave my the opportunity to try things out, it allowed me to "fail gently" at things I thought I'd be good at, and reinvest in new activities and passions I never knew I had!

Response: An arts education prepares you for many of the same rigors one would face in the marketing field. You learn how to clearly and concisely present your ideas, especially those which are not obvious or straightforward, as well as how to market yourself and your skills, an essential quality for any successful artist. The creativity one needs in the marketing world is mirrored in arts education, as is the ability to take and learn from criticism, as well as offer critical observations of your own.
Liberal arts college
Response_ddqual: While the focus rests heavily on art, it is hard to argue that practical skills - communication, self-possession, and functional creativity - are not the primary focus of this college. It is unlikely that many (even most) of us will go into fields relating to our majors, yet the skills we learn at Emerson will help us thrive wherever our ultimate career path lies.
replies_ddqual: I agree that the practical skills are quite valuable. It seems like it could lead to a direct career path, a windy tangential one, or a even just a full circle.

Response: Cultural Studies

I believe that what he has heard is absolutely true - Boston is a dynamic, fascinating, and oft-times frightening city that welcomes college students with open arms. There are no dull moments in this town, from the colorful characters on the streets to the trials and tribulations of the MBTA, and we wouldn't have it any other way. While I've heard that Ithaca is 'gorges', it's got nothing on the dirty beauty of this city, and no college can compare to the color, life, and enthusiasm that Emerson is positively brimming with.



That being said, there is more to college than the 'experience'. Much of that is inherent - you will grow older, gain more responsibility, and begin to make 'adult' decisions about your future at any college, as it is the nature of the beast. While Emerson has a lot to offer in the way of culture and personality, it cannot compete with some colleges on an academic level (though, as an alum, it does pain me to admit this) and if academic fulfillment is Ken's primary focus - a desire to earn good grades and perhaps continue on to a terminal degree - Emerson is not the right choice.
During extra-curriculars and co-curriculars, Professional development
Response_ddqual:
I am biased in this response, but I definitely found most fulfillment from my work with Hyena Comedy and the IT Help Desk. The skills I learned on the job - problem solving, how to stay calm under pressure, creative solution making, attention to detail - have served me in great stead both personally and professionally.



While the long-reaching benefits of Hyena Comedy are less visibly apparent in my personal life, I cannot deny that the exploration of humor in all its forms - from the puerile to the sublime - has not only made me a happier person, but also I believe a better judge of character.

Response: Opportunities to do original work, Opportunities to collaborate with academic or professional experts in your field
Response_ddqual:
The inherently creative nature of the coursework at Emerson challenges you beyond the norm - instead of memorizing, learning by repetition, or producing reams of work, you are encouraged to work at Emerson not harder but differently. Non-traditional assignments, provocative ideas, in-the-field assignments created by professionals - these are the hallmarks of an Emerson education. 



This  is a major part of the reason I believe our graduates excel in whatever field they end up in, as the ability to think in the abstract, framed by experience with other successful experts, is critical regardless of your eventual profession.

Response: Common Ground

The beauty of college (and this is especially true at Emerson) is that it is exactly what you make of it. Change your mind about your major? The folks at Academic Advising are there to make that a reality for you - they'll help you determine what of your previous classes will work toward earning a different degree, what additional classes will be required (as well as if summer/extra courses will be required) Unless you're a senior within four credits of graduation, there is always a way to get the degree you want from this college.



Should the burden be too great, it is important to remember that coursework is not the be-all and end all of what this college has to offer. Extracurriculars and student projects offer all students additional outlets and opportunities to explore their interests and make connections beyond the classroom.

I came to Emerson as a child, in many ways - idealistic, secure in my own 'creativity', utterly unprepared for the harsh realities of city living and true competition. I was a big fish in a small pond - a syndrome I think many Emerson students suffer from, by the very nature of this college - and realized very soon after arrival that I didn't know as much as I thought I did, I wasn't as sure of anything as I thought I was, and I had A LOT to learn.



And learn I really did - Emerson proved to be a fertile environment for exploring new interests, honing old skills, and determining what in life actually gave me satisfaction and made me happy. My hiring at the IT Help Desk as a student - a slightly anxious, not particularly tech-savvy student - set me on the path that finds me where I am today, the manager of a critically-important IT department at my alma mater. I have had the privilege of working alongside some truly brilliant, incredibly helpful people who made the transformation possible.
Weekly
Response_ddqual: Without other departments, IT (and especially Lab Operations) has no purpose. The labs and classrooms on campus exist for the benefit of the the students and faculty of the academic departments of the college. On at least a weekly basis, I communicate with faculty in Journalism, VMA, WLP, and Comm Sciences to answer their questions, resolve their issues, and make their teaching experience the best it can possibly be. Additionally, our support of other general use spaces puts us in collaboration with numerous other entities - TRF, the staff of Kasteel Well, WERS, the Writing and Academic Resource Center, Post Production, the Phonathon team, and Human Resources.

Response: Charles Wesley Emerson, founder of Emerson College

I believe 'infamous' might be more appropriate here, but I am certainly most proud of my work with Hyena Comedy, Emerson College's only intentionally funny publication. A contributor for my first two years and Supreme Overlord in my last two, I did my very best to carry on a proud legacy of satire and silliness, while having the privilege to work with some of the funniest people I will ever know. My magnum opus, Hyena Goes to Hell, is far too large to post here, so I'll leave you with the cover (a pretty amazing piece done by Ross Norton '12)
Almost everyday
Response_ddqual: It is the very nature of my work to solve problems, and the Emerson community's voracious appetite for the newest and coolest ensures that IT never has a dull moment! Every day, there is something new - a weird, hitherto-unnoticed quirk of a piece of software, strange projector behavior in a classroom, a challenge from a professor to get a new system implemented in only a handful of days - and we are certainly never bored! It is, however, without a doubt the reason why many of us stay at Emerson. The constant challenges, the learning opportunities, the fresh ideas -- this is what working for Emerson so great!

Response: My work for IT has allowed me a number of brilliant teaching and learning opportunities, both at Emerson and beyond. I feel incredibly lucky to be a part of a community so interested in and dedicated to the exploration of technology in instruction. I think perhaps my brightest moments of both teaching and learning have occurred at the Course Spas hosted by the Instructional Technology Group prior to the start of the semester. The opportunity to sit down with faculty - either one-on-one or in a group setting - and discuss what the labs and classrooms can offer them pedagogically has been an absolute dream come true. I enjoy especially meeting with new professors, many of whom are eager to try new things with technology in their courses, and work on making these ideas a reality.
The primary communal & meeting place for Emerson students at the College's Back Bay campus (130 Beacon Street)

Emerson College is rich with the resources to help any student succeed, regardless of college 'preparedness'.



- Technological resources of all types are available to students, from a robust wireless network to computer labs open 14 hours a day. Laptops, video cameras, iPads - any sort of device you could possibly desire is borrowable from one of our many distribution centers. The Student Technology Guide on it.emerson.edu offers a comprehensive look for all students of what is available at Emerson



- The administrative support structure is unparalleled - counseling of personal, academic, or professional natures are available from Counseling and Psychological Services, Academic Advising, and Career Services respectively. For those both unfamiliar with the collegiate environment or eager to succeed to the fullest possible extent, these resources are invaluable.



- The personal resources available to Maria are everywhere - her fellow students, her advisor and her professors can provide a support structure for a student just starting out. As she grows during her time here, she will find even more resources - peers in extra curriculars, in service groups, at on-campus jobs - all of whom can make Emerson feel a little bit more like home.



- College is expensive. Responsible conversations about student loans, credit cards, and other aspects of 'adult' finance cannot be had early or often enough. Scholarships, financial aid, and work study opportunities will all provide Maria with opportunities to leave Emerson in a healthy financial state.

I am most excited about being a part of the Emerson Community when we make the news for the right reasons, because of one of the progressive initiatives we are known for, or a community-wide demonstration of the very best qualities of human nature.



My most Emerson experience would probably be any of the multiple short films I appeared in during my time in undergrad - I am no actress, but it is impossible to make it through four years at this school without acting in multiple Film II productions for friends and classmates.
replies_ddqual: That's so true. I remember I was in a bunch of EVVY shows, including a sci-fi comedy show where I played an alien with amnesia named Buttr'd Krumpetz.

Response_ddqual: The Walker Build is now, and has been for all of my time at Emerson, the hub of my universe. I know its secret stairways, the quirks of its elevators, and what it sounds like wander the halls at 2 in the morning (eerily quiet).

Response_ddqual: A large part of my job is training the student staff at the IT Help Desk. Even if I am not the one solving the issues, I enjoy reading through the resolutions so that next time the question gets asked, I have a better chance of being able to help. Response: I love the fact that we have free access to Lynda.com. The site has thousands of courses on all sorts of topics, computer software, and business skills, and they're constantly adding the newest and most up-to-date subjects. It can be accessed anywhere (at home, on a phone/tablet) and has things that are useful to my career but also subjects I am just interested in outside of work. Spreading the word about our Lynda.com access is important to me because I think it is a fantastic learning tool that more Emerson members should explore.
replies_ddqual:
I agree! The challenge is finding the time to take the courses! As a supervisor, I encourage my staff to carve out some time each month to explore and learn, but it can be hard with so much going on! How do you schedule yourself to use it?\\ Thanks Sharon! The time battle is always a tough fight. I find the shorter videos are easier to squeeze in during commutes and lunch breaks. ("10 minute tips" and "Monday Productivity Pointers" are some of my favorites.) \\ omigod, I totally agree!!!  This is an incredible benefit and resource.  It IS really hard to find the time to use it. But it's such an opportunity for staff development, maybe if more supervisors and managers encouraged it, it would help--right now i almost feel guilty taking time to work with it.\\ What I love about Lynda.com is that you don't have to watch a whole course. I will often pop in, skim the transcript, and then just watch the video for the parts that are most interesting to me. It can take as little as 10 minutes, and I always learn something! 



I just wish people were more aware of all of the Lynda.com courses that address professional skills other than software. For example, they just came out with one called "Leading with Applied Improv," and another called "Managing Multiple Generations."



(BTW if you don't know how to sign up, Carlin has created a great set of instructions on it.emerson.edu).

Response: Student-Instructor Ratio, Opportunities to do original work, Opportunities to collaborate with academic or professional experts in your field
Response_ddqual:
What first comes to mind is the "Honors Program". But I'm not really a big fan of the honors program here. Honestly, I feel like my honors classes are typically the ones I spend the most time on, yet the ones I care the least about :/



Occasionally, these classes have their moments, but they are usually my least favorite each semester. There is very little room for creativity or unique work. We write essays and read books (or papers scanned into canvas). I'm not good at long, academic papers. I don't like reading books that I will honestly forget about the second class is over. :( I like trying new things and being creative. Let me test theories, not just listen to a lecture about them. Instead of a 10 paged essay, let me recreate the Ideas of Plato's Republic as a modern day political campaign, or as a short film, or as a metaphoric short story!

Response: The Walker 10 Gallery

I changed my major and added a minor within a week and a half with very little difficulty. However, I went from WLP to Marketing, so I do not know if there is a difference for switching into film... Either way, the earlier it's done, the better (easier to move, more space in your schedule, etc). Go to her academic adviser for specific advice. (My adviser has saved my college career multiple times now... Thank you, Lynn Butkovsky!)



The only part I had trouble with is going between my honors adviser (who frankly, did not know anything about me, my current major, my intended major, how to change majors, and didn't even have access to my transcript) and a real adviser. Ridiculous.

I am naturally a shy, introverted person. Now I am still definitely an introvert (and proud of it! ;) ), but I am much less shy. 



I can't say it was one specific event that helped me. Really, I'd have to say it was more the other students than anything else. Everyone here wants you to succeed, and wants to help you reach your goals. Through the Emerson clubs and orgs and even through class projects you really get the opportunity to be your self and learn how to let other people be themselves. Emerson is a learning community in every way- external, internal, inter/intra personal- every way.

Response: Records and information management(RIM) because the more "tech" you have, the more opportunity (read: NEED) for humans to overlay sensible organizing & system structures to enable efficient access.Records and information are part of almost everything we do in the arts, education, administration. Adding RIM skills with Emerson's tech & professional skill development will result in highly desirable job candidates!

Emerson's full-time records manager (RM) is 10 years into supporting the College's complex recordkeeping, compliance and retention needs. By collaborating with us & IT on solutions to our records creation and storage issues, RM has made my job is so much easier that I've been recognized for exceptional efficiency and service delivery in my [imaginary] Student Support Services job. We are practically paperless now! 18 of the 20 file cabinets are gone, opening space for more wrap-around student services and comfy workstations for visiting families to use when they come to campus. Even better, thanks to RM & IT, everyone in the office follows ONE file plan set up in Cabinet: we know how to name our e-docs & what folders to put them in so that we can quickly and accurately respond to student and family needs. Our inboxes are loaded with thank yous from appreciative peeps (& we know how long to keep email records too!)

Emerson has given me a lot of opportunity to not only write creatively, but to present my writings and other communications skills in forums ranging from student theater productions to course project presentations - and I;m not just talking about PowerPoints! I've worked collaboratively with students, faculty and production support staff to develop and deliver skills development training for individuals and organizations. I've really enjoyed bringing creative thinking to all the projects I've been involved with while at Emerson. Since graduating, I've been volunteering for my local ABCD after care program by helping them to develop a social media marketing policy and plan for communicating the awesome programming they provide for inner city kids and their parents.

Response: Emerson should strive to be part of the base of a student's life. The final piece that a student can then start building upwards. With a shaky base, a pyramid cannot get very high - nor can a student go very far. This doesn't necessarily mean just the education provided - it means the overall experience. Students should be in a diverse and engaged community. There also should be a focus on improving financial aid with the rising cost of college. Ideally, cost nor the prospect of student debt, should never hamper a person's education. And college should never be a barrier to a student's future - it should never get in the way of greatness.

Emerson works to cultivate graduating classes of young, intrepid thinkers. These are kids who are going to go on and want to change the world. There is also a great social awareness in general at Emerson - students talking about uncomfortable and hot-button issues openly. As for the school itself - there are always open discussions and panels going on. I'd like to see more action taken - whether that's students volunteering to go somewhere and help out, or staff being able to engage in more community volunteer days. There is an awareness of what's going on, but sometimes I do worry that Emerson feels that's sufficient. To know, but not to act. I'm not saying Emerson needs to contribute in some major way - but there could be more than what we are already doing.

Response: Emerson, now, more than ever - has cemented itself as a unique institution that offers it's students a broad experience from engaging in critical thinking to honing hands on skills. The focus of Emerson on it's students and the push to give them the best education possible is so palpable - and it keeps getting stronger. I can only see Emerson's reputation increasing as the years pass - as long as the current momentum is kept up. However, I think this is the wrong question. I don't think Emerson should be focusing on what the degree means - I think they should be focusing on what it takes to get to the degree, and who these kids are who are getting the degrees. That's really where Emerson can effect where it's going in the future. It's a good goal and an admirable goal - that degree - but the degree should never overshadow the journey. Really what Emerson should focus on is getting more students in here who may never have thought they could go to Emerson because of financial constraints or background, as well as continuing to hire world-class faculty who will push these students. As long as the students are challenged and have to work hard and are engaged - those degrees will speak for themselves.

Has thinking gone out of style yet? Is being a well-read and intelligent individual suddenly obsolete? Are future employers only interested in someone who spends all their times in one tiny microcosm of the human existence? I think not. Philosophy is one part of a greater education that introduces undergrads to thinkers and books they may have never encountered before. What happens if he has to make a movie one day about Nietzche and casts a non-mustachioed actor in the lead role? How's that going to look? Philosophy is an amazing and intricate subject matter that can only improve upon your mind. If you zero in on just film, you are hurting yourself. It's like those guys who go to the gym and just do arms. Huge biceps - skinny little legs - you're totally off balance dude! No one is into the skinny legged-giant-armed man. Just like no future employer is interested in someone who doesn't get outside their comfort zone. You cannot be a fully creative adult if you don't dabble in different things and yes, read impossibly hard books and try to wrap our brain around the a priori judgements, and Descartes cogito ergo sum - never mind delving into Plato's notes! Philosophy is about more than just really hard reading and big words. It's also about guys with weird last names. No, joking. It's about learning how the human mind has evolved, how thought has evolved, and how rationality came to be. So unless you are Aristotle reincarnated, take a philosophy class and broaden your mind, Julian. Don't be a goombah.

I love you, Paula!\\ heheheh  "Don't be a goombah"!\\ Now this is a Goomba.

http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/c/ce/Goomba.PNG\\ Sing it, sista!

Response_ddqual: Sometimes - and I am going to get a tad critical here - I think colleges in general suffer from this - is zeroing in on something called "global" skills. What exactly are these skills we need for this global world vs the other world people assume Emersonians are living in? I think instead of making it sound fancy and futuristic, and a tad unattainable, Emerson should focus on helping hone the skill sets that have always been in style. Courtesy, active listening, empathy, open-mindendess, excellent communication... these are not "new" skills we are just learning when we get to Emerson. We've been working on these skills our entire lives and always will be. Emerson should focus on pushing those skills to become even more engrained - before the students leave and enter the real world. Honestly what a great college should do is illuminate where students' weaknesses are - whether communication, timeliness, or working under pressure - and help the students work on and strengthen them!

Response:
While technology can advance teaching and offer wonderful, lightning fast tools that help students and faculty alike - at the end of the day there is no substitute for great teachers and hard working students. It doesn't matter the tool - across the historical gamut of education - it has always been the conversation and the Socratic method that has lasted and has made a lasting impact. I do think that there may be more of a blended classroom in 2025 - the lectures are online, while class time is spent engaging and conversing. Of course there will always been hiccups and glitches - that's just the way it goes. But there will be an expectation for faculty to know these tools well, and the students will always be pushing the tools. In a weird way, I think technology will lose it's glamor a bit and certain tools will become naturally part of the class, and others will fall off as unnecessary. I do also think that certain skill-sets will become more common - basic HTML and CSS, and basic CMS administration.

Innovation is a tricky word. Does it necessarily mean "new" and "flashy"? Or does it mean assessing and implementing meaningful change that can positively effect both Emerson and the communities that are around it? I think, and hope, it means the latter. While I might not have any ideas of exactly what that can mean, I believe that the most poignant ideas are the ones that are not self-centered or self-serving. Rather they are the ideas that are bigger than themselves, that catch people's attention and inspire them to act. 

At Emerson, I am not sure I could point to a crystal clear example - but rather that there are tiny sprouts of it all around - little flashes of potential that are slowly dictating where the college is going. We are trying to be more connected as a community - after all you are reading this right now, aren't you? :) We are seeking ways to stay committed to diversity and inclusion. There are pillars that we can refer to to try to shape these ideas around. We are trying to get classes online. We are participating in community events - some us planted flowers on the common! And there are committees and groups discussing these issues and trying to come up with ideas. 

It might slow and painful sometimes, and the change might seem small - but that's part of the fun. It's the journey, after all, that is usually a little bit more memorable than the destination.
replies_ddqual: Well put Paula!\\ Well said!!!\\ Preach!

Response: Boston is the most amazing city to be a student in and a resident of! First, Emerson has amazing student discounts at different museums - including the MFA, which was a second home to me as a student (since it was FREE ADMISSION.) You can go prowl around the North End and see the sites - although don't go to Mike's, got to Modern. The T, although cranky and slow, can bring you to a slew of different neighborhoods with a million different things to offer. And finally, my favorite thing, which is my prejudice as a Massachusetts girl born and bred - the SPORTS! What a city to love sports in or to learn to love sports in. The Bruins, the Celtics (although they are pretty terrible in recent years,) and the ever up and down Red Sox. Everyone should go to a game at Fenway and the Garden. They are magical, historical places where you can taste the culture - see the generations of families brought together by a common passion ingrained in the very roots of the city. Even if you don't share in it, or understand it, you should witness it and let the exhilaration of a Patrice Bergeron goal wash over you, and try to see Papi glaring down a pitcher. Share in this world - this strange, R-less world of these crazy Massachusetts people. I even say get out of Boston - go wander down the Cape, go see P-Town, and even get up on the North Shore - Rockport, Gloucester, Salem! Try to get out to Lexington and Concord and wander around that beautiful park. Just, try to see as much as you can. You may not live here forever like me. I want you to see a little bit of this wonderful, amazing state and city as you can. :D
replies_ddqual: And get used to saying "There's always next year!" if you're a sports fan.

Response_ddqual: Hey guys! Do you know about google.emerson.edu?! We have Google Apps for Education at Emerson. This includes Google Drive (or Docs), Calendar, Sites, Google+, and Hangouts! It's available for faculty, staff, and students. (Please note: it does not include Gmail, and in fact you should log out of your personal gmail if you are attempting to use Google Apps. Or just use another browser.) One of the greatest thing about Google Drive is that everyone from Emerson College is in there and it allows you to share things pretty easily with the folks in our community! It also allows you to keep your personal google account and Emerson content separated. Please spread the word about Google Apps at Emerson - it's such a great tool that a lot of people do not know about or utilize. And if you are nervous about using it or want to be trained on it - or just have questions - let ITG know! We support it and would love for you to stop by and chat! We have chocolate and coffee. (itg@emerson.edu)
replies_ddqual: Google apps are a great resource for the school, BUT you need to keep one thing in mind when you do use it...we (Emerson) don't control security over the Google servers so it's important that sensitive or confidential documents not be shared or stored there. Everything else is fine and get's IT's "Thumbs Up" for Google Apps!\\ All good info!\\ Seriously. Google Apps everyone. Check it out at google.emerson.edu.\\ I love our Google apps suite. It's made communicating in our office so much easier!\\ We in Student Life use it on a daily basis! Makes communicating and collaborating so much easier and in real time! Efficiency! A++++ on this system!\\ Ah thank you guys for chiming in, I really appreciate it! :D

Response: Student-Instructor Ratio, Opportunities to do original work, Opportunities to collaborate with academic or professional experts in your field, Amount of work required for good grades, Co-curriculars
Response_ddqual: The student-instructor ratio because teachers can help students on a more individual level. The opportunities to do original work because we almost always have the freedom to express ourselves and better ourselves creatively. Amount of work because we are constantly busy, and procrastination is pushed aside in the wake of industry. Co-curriculars because art would be nothing without mind behind it; classes outside of our major tracks that we can take help us learn more about the world and more about different types of art, and this enhances our minds and our own art. Finally, the opportunities to collaborate with academic and professional experts because it is a truly unique experience to be able to learn from the best to help oneself become the best that they can be.

I wanted to post a video that I made as part of my VM120 class, but I kept getting messages saying it was too large. Instead, I will describe it. As a first project in that class I was able to create a short one minute video without any camera movement or dialogue. I used these guidelines to create a video that I tried to make depict what suicidal thoughts felt like. When we presented the projects in class, I, like many other students, got sorta grilled with constructive criticism. However, after class another student came up to me and told me how good he thought my video was, and that really meant something. I want my art to affect people, and as long as one person is touched, that is all that matters.

Response: Okay, this just happened last night, but it was amazing. I was in a SPEC meeting and the faculty sponsor came in to speak: Hassan Ildari. He seemed kind of reserved at first, but then after a short time, he turned into a freaking messiah of screenwriting. What he said in that room will stick with me throughout my years at Emerson: the writing you do for screenplays needs to be for only yourself--no one else--and it has to have emotion. It has to be alive.

Response: Good question, although I find it a little tricky to answer without falling into assumptions about residents of Chinatown. If I imagine more broadly that I were not a part of Emerson but lived in this neighborhood, I don't know that I would have that much information about it beyond noting the banners marking the buildings, the bright lights on the marquees (which advertise typically ticketed events I might or might not have interest in or money for and probably don't pay much attention to in any case), and the sometimes hustle and bustle of relatively young people on Boylston St. and Tremont. Would I perceive much of a connection between my neighborhood and Emerson? I'm thinking probably not. More like two separate worlds in one small geographic area.
Important
Response_ddqual: I think service learning is very important to developing students' sense of engagement with, and responsibility to, the wider community. I don't know enough about how many classes it is currently a component of to have an informed opinion about whether it should be a component of more, but I think the notion of service learning as a requirement is tricky. Obligatory 'service' can be a turn-off. Providing robust opportunities and encouragement for students to pursue service opportunities on their own may be more fruitful, particularly if classroom learning and the whole ethos of the school fosters real thinking about self in relation to community/the wider world. The prompt here is tricky, because setting up the idea of service/learning as just benefiting the community/org without talking about the benefit/impact on the participant is incomplete. Many people who've done 'service' will say they gained as much, or more than, the intended 'recipients' of the service.

Response: All of the above

The Engagement Game Lab is a great example--great to see the past and upcoming/current projects in Boston. I know there's a fund for curricular innovation, and the Emerson Accelerator Program is a great way to support student innovation and entrepreneurism.

Great example: Emerson is hosting a discussion of this year's Boston Book Festival One City One Story selection, "Sublimation" by Jennifer Haigh, on Oct 23 at 6pm in Iwasaki Library. Iwasaki is one of the free distribution points for the short story, so it's easy to pick up a copy and then check out the discussion at Emerson on 10/23 in advance of the Boston-wide Town Hall discussion with the author on Sat 10/25. The story was was first published in Ploughshares (woot woot)!  There is also a short story writing contest "about coming to terms with an aspect of your own identity" as part of the event. What a cool event for Boston, and how great is it that Emerson is participating?! 



Speaking of books, if you haven't checked out the central Boston Public Library at Copley Square, I highly encourage it...the old part of the building (McKim) is stunning and free tours are frequently offered. And when you're done reading, wander down the street to the New England Conservatory--there are amazing concerts there most nights of the week and Sundays through Thursdays are generally free. 



(And still speaking of books...the President's Book Club (Fiction) here at Emerson just started last spring and is open to new staff and faculty members at any time. Come join us!)

I missed the sign up in the spring, but am interested.\\ Esther, glad that you are interested in joining! An email will go out shortly to all staff and faculty inviting participation in the book clubs (there are two: fiction and non-fiction). Response: Common Ground

I would encourage Joanne to talk to her Academic Advisor and to faculty in both WLP and VMA, including the chair of VMA since he'd need to sign the Change of Major form if she does end up switching changing majors. Her Academic Advisor can help her understand the impact on course sequencing and progress toward graduation and whether Joanne would be able to complete all required coursework for the new major in the original timeframe. (Additional time usually means additional costs, in which case a conversation with Financial Aid would be important if Joanne is receiving aid.) I'd also encourage her to talk to Career Services about the potential switch in the context of her evolving career goals.

I'm a happier person since coming to Emerson! The dynamism and dedication of this community fires me up. Learning, creativity, communication, diversity, inclusivity, service, excellence, engagement, innovation--a great mix.

Response: The primary communal & meeting place for Emerson students at the College's Back Bay campus (130 Beacon Street)

Maria needs to know that this place is filled with people and offices that want to support her in being successful both inside and outside the classroom. She can start with the people she's already in contact with--her Orientation Leader, her RA, her Academic Advisor, her faculty--and they can help her learn about resources like the WARC, Student Life, the library, ECAPS, etc. The Office of Student Success could be a great starting point to help her think through what she'll individually need to be successful and get her connected appropriately. (Come visit us on the 1st floor of the Little Building!) Student organizations and activities can be a great way to meet build a network of peers with similar interests. She needs to remember that everyone is trying to find their way, even if it looks like some people already have it "figured out," and that everyone is going to have a different path and a different definition of what "success" means to them--but that Emerson is hers as much as it is every one of her peers', and the resources we have are for her to take advantage of.. (And of course she needs to check--and read!--her email for important information from the college. Really!)
I am most excited about being part of the Emerson Community when watching students be creative, engaged, and passionate...and hearing them talk about what makes them tick.

Response_ddqual: Little Building--home not only to my office in the Office of Student Success & key spots like the Dining Hall, Fitness Center, Cabaret and super-handy convenience store, but also to some fantastic (and historic) arcade architecture. The 1st-floor storefront windows are a reminder of the architects' original "City Under One Roof" concept 100 years ago, the murals depict colorful Boston scenes from even further back in time, and touches like the vaulted ceilings, Gothic trim and ornate post box are just cool.

Emerson doesn't really address society's problems. In fact, sometimes it pushes them away. There's a huge problem here, in my opinion, with the way males are perceived to be more technical that women. As a manager at the IT helpdesk, sometimes people will dash right to the guy sitting next to me that's only worked there for a month, whereas I have three years of experience and could solve their problem faster. I see it in film classes, when people ask me if I know how to use lights that I learned how to use in freshman year, but aren't concerned with the guys.

Response_ddqual: It's been a dream of mine to work in London since I was in high school. I want to experience different cities and places and I love the heck out of London, so why not? I began researching jobs there last year, and Envy Post Production has been number one on my list since I began looking.

Response: I think today, at least in my major, getting a job is all about the skills one possesses. If Emerson is where you learned how to make a website, or animate, or edit videos, then there you go. But for other majors, it's a little different. Marketing or journalism might be all about the degree, but I'm neither so I can't be sure. Either way, it's kind of all about your work samples and "portfolios" today.

Oh Julian, #bless you. I enjoy many classes I take as well that are unrelated to my major, and they're awesome! I don't think we should be wasting our time on courses unrelated to our careers.
replies_ddqual: What if the course content of these classes were taught in such a way that the connection to the major and to real-life career experiences were more transparent? Would this make more sense to students?

Response: Some but not all
Response_ddqual: "Skills I need to succeed in a global world". Damn. What does this even mean? I guess it means that I know enough about different cultures to know how to interact with people from that specific culture. However, it's easy to say stuff like "I'm global", but not as easy to implement it when you can't speak another language. More language classes would be a good idea, for those of us who want to take them, or even language clubs. I've been dying to speak French, and haven't had the opportunity to do so since senior year of high school, and occasionally with my mother. Also it'd probably be a good idea to have more international students.

Response: Oh wow. Okay so here's what I'm hoping: Emerson will be like Disneyworld. Not in the sense that we have turkey legs and rides (which would be awesome) but we have an app that tells us the wait times of certain things. How cool would it be if you had an app that told you if you left from the 5th floor of Piano Row, you could be on the 6th floor of Ansin in 8 minutes based on information from the Boylston/Tremont crossing patterns, elevator traffic, and foot traffic? Rad. And what if after, you could order online from the Max before heading back up to your room, and the estimated meal prep time is 10 minutes? Boom. Ten minutes later, you got your food from the Max without even having to wait. Boosh.

I've been stuck on this question for days, but I think I've finally got it. To be honest, I think that the complete lack of space takes a toll on everybody. But if I'm trying to get from CVS to Boloco, I need people to pay more attention to where they walk. Standing in huge groups outside the Walker Building after class lets out at 2pm? Unacceptable. Only thing is, I don't know how we'd solve this, but people need to be more conscious of the space they take up. Now it's not like a HUGE problem or anything. The only other thing I could think of (though it doesn't bother me personally) is smoking on Boylston St. However, due to recent changes, students are no longer allowed to smoke on Boylston St., but they are also not allowed to smoke in the Commons or the Public Garden because there is a fine for smoking in public parks. God bless the people who smoke in Boylston place though. They tha real MVPs. They stay out of people's way, and people can avoid the smoke if need be. I suggest maybe putting an awning in that little corner of Boylston Place, that way people can smoke if they need to in that location even if it's raining! (Cause if it's raining, they're definitely gonna go to the Cove, which is now off-limits)

Response_ddqual: But you guys.....what exactly does an API do? Explain it to us plebs.
replies_ddqual: Agreed.  I think more people would sign up for this if they knew what it meant.  Perhaps share some awesome examples of what this might look like?  The way I've been explaining it to people is by saying "Remember when the MBTA released their data so that private app developers could make apps that tell you when the next bus was going to come?  It's like that."\\ for the most part it means access to data. Data that may not necessarily be exposed in the apps. Such as, who exactly "liked" your comment. The most obvious application of having access to data is drawing your own conclusions about what the data means. In the form of graphs for example. makes sense?\\ As has been said, an API is simply a standard, reliable way to access raw data. Your web browser is a kind of API, but built for humans -- it has a URL/address bar where you ask for specific info, and it's returned in a human-readable format (a webpage). An API usually returns information in a computer-readable format instead of a human-readable format.\\ To piggyback on Cylebot's reponse, an API allows different programs to talk to each other.  An API would allow for greater sharing of information between different applications.

I think a switch of a major should be fairly easy if she is early enough in her degree.  I think that since she is changing her career outlook she should definitely consult career services, but first and foremost contact academic advising.  Advisors should be able to get her on the right path.  Planning far enough out into the future and showing her how to graduate on time or close to it should be one of the expectations when handling students switching majors.  That was always the one thing my friends in undergrad had issues with.  The switch would go fine, but then they would not be able to get past the frustration that comes with trying to get the classes they need at the end of their college career.

I had never really taken a more administrative role.  Before Emerson I was limited in my thinking about the possibility of events because the staff here do not rule anything out immediately.  People have big ideas here.  My experience sitting in the office and listening to students chat about event ideas has had a major impact that I know I will take with me when my time at Emerson comes to an end.  They say "why not", rather than straight out "no".  I have found myself doing this outside of this campus.

Response: It means that initiatives for positive change can come from anywhere and be respected and, with enough support, put into action. Students led a push to get rid of plastic water bottles on campus, and it happened. That was grassroots rather than top-down, and it worked. Similarly, President Pelton's letter to President Obama regarding school shootings and handgun violence in general showed impressive foresight and engagement. Other issues have emerged over the past few years that we have not gotten as well out in front of, but hopeful encouraging social responsibility will foster leadership in other areas and concerns as well -- actions, rather than reactions.

As a fan of Chinatown restaurants, it's very heartening to see way more Emerson students hanging out in them than they ever did 20 years ago. Granted back then 1/2 of this area was the Combat Zone and your parents told you not to wander through here. The tools of the creative trades are changing and advancing at such a more rapid rate than they were when I graduated from Emerson in 1991. I feel that innovation is keeping up with all of these evolving technologies and insuring that our students are able to hit the ground running the moment they graduate, and not be caught in a game of catch-up against students from NYU or UCLA or USC who may have had access to more current equipment and skill sets. This is an expensive proposition, but given what students are paying in tuition, I believe they deserve to expect this. I see it happening in VMA's student projects and in the productions mounted by Performing Arts (so advanced compared to what I saw as a student), but I worry that flat-lined budgets for Academic Departments, in the face of rising student numbers, might be hampering the best efforts of faculty to prepare students.

I'm a movie fan -- old, new, high art, low art,and everything in between. The Bright Lights Film Series is the contribution from Emerson toward Boston's culture that most frequently and rewardingly draws my attention. If I'm not in the BFSR, I'm in the Brattle, or Coolidge, or Harvard Archive, or AMC  following which I'm in Alden & Harlow, or Otto's Coolidge Corner, or Hong Kong, or Shojo talking about the movie I just saw with whomever I saw it with.

Complex question! Before I worked in academia I would have figured "of course you can switch from one department easily. You've paid the tuition, you should be able to get the education you've decided on!" But certain departments are already fairly overloaded, which could lead to some competitiveness with transferring. It would also seem on the surface to me that someone already enrolled in another Emerson department should have priority over someone transferring from another school, but I can also imagine that being contentious. What if someone from UCLA or NYU's screenwriting program wanted to transfer in at the same time as Joanne, and there was only room for one of them? I suppose one factor would be who had the better grades, but I can imagine other factors as well. If I were in Joanne's shoes I would hope that I had impressed a few of my WLP professors enough to lend their support to my being a valuable addition to Emerson's screenwriting program.

My job has been conducive to learning strengths that I never really figured I had. In fact, I would have expected they'd be weaknesses but some helpful & patient people have shown me how I can be helpful in ways I never would have expected when I interviewed for this position.

Emerson's policies and bureaucracy can seem labyrinthine and far from intuitive  but on the upside it is crewed with faculty & staff who genuinely want to see you succeed. Don't give up when you encounter what seems like a roadblock -- you'll find the right person to help.

My "most Emerson" experience was the time when my personal hero & favorite Emersonian Spalding Gray presented his monologue "Monster In A Box" at the then-newly-opened Majestic Theater in 1991. Spalding's 1987 film "Swimming To Cambodia" and his book "Sex & Death to the Age of 14" were immensely influential in my decision to enroll as a WLP student in Emerson in 1988. To me Spalding is the quintessential Emersonian: writer (WLP), stage actor (PA), filmmaker & actor (VMA), and his bravely candid exploration of his family history and his own psyche seem well aligned with CSD.

Response_ddqual: The Iwasaki Library in the Walker Building at 120 Boylston is what I think of as the heart of Emerson. Granted, I work here, but because of that I interact with faculty, students and staff on equal footing. The library is one of the few places on campus that's open to all and where Emersonians from all walks of life--alums, graduate students, commuting students, full and part-time faculty, even our neighbors--can congregate to research, transform, and create!

Response: Student-Instructor Ratio, Opportunities to do original work, Opportunities to collaborate with academic or professional experts in your field, Diversity of student body, Other (explain)
Response_ddqual: Emerson is truly strong when it comes to keeping classes small. The point of a college education, or a graduate education, is to enter into more of a mentorship with experts in the field and to become part of a thriving community of scholars, professionals, creative forces in your subject area of choice. Small classes do this. Having students develop their own projects does this. Allowing voices from all walks of life to participate in the conversation, and be heard, is ESSENTIAL to this. And to me, the key ingredient for fostering all of this ambition, is having a top-notch library that beats at the heart of the campus.  Students need libraries to succeed, and Emerson needs a bigger one.
replies_ddqual: TinaTalks! Agree, agree, agree. \\ I agree 10000000% Tina! I love the inter-library loan program, but the library needs to be bigger! It has to fit all those big brains!\\ The Library is, or should be, the academic heart of any college!  And I think ours is!

Response_ddqual: Every time I hear the campus tour come around, I hear about Emerson "going green" and being recognized as a "green" institution.  I think this is great. I think bringing more flora into study spaces and community gardens are awesome. But what I'd really, really, really like to see is an end to printing on campus.  I know this might be impossible because certain documents have to exist on paper.  But it's 2014, Emersonians! We really don't need to have students printing 20 copies of a 30-page screenplay for workshop when Google docs exists.  There are comment buttons and everything!  If we really want to be a green and sustainable workplace, let's make an effort to get rid of paper.  Save students some money, and a LOT of trees!
replies_ddqual: This is a great idea, and I think students would appreciate not having to pay for printing out assignments so often.  Submitting assignments via Canvas rather than on paper is also way easier and faster.\\ Totally agree! Students would love not to have to print assignments.\\ A lot of people do not even know about google.emerson.edu - people should use it!! \\ Yes, Google.emerson.edu!\\ True, although it's hard to get past the convenience factor of commenting on paper. googledocs are less flexible - what if you need to draw a dragon eating a butterfly as a comment? There's no emoticon for that...\\ Well, google docs is one option. I'm sure we can find an emoticon-based document sharing program. =^..^=

Response: The Walker 10 Gallery

I never really considered the path to switching a major, but, from what I can gather, it seems pretty hard. There are so many classes you've likely taken within your major, and they won't always transfer. That means wasted time, money, and energy. In that case, I'd recommend to Joanne to stay the course; you can go anywhere with almost any kind of degree as long as you're dedicated and can show off your talent. That being said, Emerson could best benefit by making the program change process more transparent. Additionally, it would help if major credits - save for those in the most technical of courses - had some sort of transfer potential besides as electives. There has to be some crossover with the curriculum and the lessons learned, and it would make switching easier if there were a way to pick out the similarities. Logistically, that's difficult to do. However, advisors certainly help! I know I've never even met mine before.

Professionally, no; this is the first time I've really piled on and buried myself in many different opportunities. I'm not expecting a huge payoff from most of them other than the ability to lead and have fun. Personally, yes; I have had so many growing up experiences, but they're more with regard to transferring, living on my own, meeting new people, and befriending the wrong people. I can credit coming to Emerson with some of these experiences, but the reality is that they could have happened with or without the school. The fact is, people don't always grow up from stress, though many do. It's more about having examples to follow when going through adversity. I had several, some of them being Emerson students and faculty, and some not. If you want students to take risks and grow from adversity, make sure that the school has those same exemplary people that can provide guidance in the hard times.
Almost never
Response_ddqual: This semester is the first time I've collaborated on a course project with anyone outside of the WLP department. I'm in a directed study lab course called EdTech Times where we group together with marketing and VMA students to act as consultants to a fledgeling company. Lab classes like these need so much more support; departments are so protective of their curriculum, but as a professional I would be better prepared to enter the real world with outside experiences like these.
replies_ddqual: That's really wild and interesting. Good for you!

Response: Charles Wesley Emerson, founder of Emerson College

Along with several selfless people, I helped create a fraternity on campus dedicated to service, leadership, and friendship among brothers. As a colony, it's our goal to leave a lasting legacy, not only through the service we do for and in the name of Emerson, but also in the community we build for the next generation of our own members. Much of that building process centered on finding our niche within the Emerson community and discovering how the Emerson student fit with our principles. While we've found that balance, the next step is to figure out how to pitch our fraternity and Greek Life as a whole to students, as the average Emerson student is rarely interested in what we have to say.
Monthly
Response_ddqual: A majority of my learning comes from coping with taking on too much responsibility, then freaking out under the stress. Most of what I've learned deals with balancing, multitasking, and dealing with the after-effects; the other part is learning that I can only pile on so much for so long.

Response: My biggest learning moment comes from the culmination of so many collaborative projects, either in organizations, through classwork, or from professional work. Emerson IS professionalism, but inevitably there will be someone down the road who hasn't quite made it to college yet with the requisite maturity. Instead of freaking out and wasting undue stress, just act professional yourself and leave an example. The person will either catch on or flounder. That, to me, is the culture of academics here: lead by example; be the professional.
The primary communal & meeting place for Emerson students at the College's Back Bay campus (130 Beacon Street)

The most important first resource you can get here is something that the school can't actually give you itself: an activity to be part of. While there is an organization fair available, it's up to you to find and reach out to that group that will help you succeed in the long run. Besides being your first friend group (or second if you live on campus), the older members will give you the real low-down on what to do and how to make it, and they'll direct you to other resources should you need them. Activities are the backbone of Emerson.
replies_ddqual: Student Life is always happy to help connect students to organizations! =)

How do we engage Emerson students to break out of that little box called "self?" We have our civic engagement initiatives, our service organizations, and the like, but every time I ask someone if they're interested in doing community service, they give some variation of, "No" or "what can I get out of it?" Is this a community that really supports doing things for others, or do we just say that we are?
replies_ddqual:
Being new to Boston, and not very connected to much here, I don't feel strong motivation to engage in community service. I'm guessing many newcomers might feel the same way.



That said, I feel connected to the Emerson community, and helping out this community to the best of my ability is one of my goals.



People are more likely to help others if they feel a close connection. If you can find a form of community service that directly benefits the community that students belong to or identify with, then more students would join up. \\ Keep trying! I believe you will find a way. \\ Emerson does provide opportunities to do community service! And sometimes if people haven't done it before or they are busy, it can be hard to convince them to do something that seems like a huge time suck. This is where making a little film about how and why people engage with the greater community and how Emerson can help out might help. Seeing is believing. Also, Nick D, geez you're all over this game with these fabulous ides. :D

\\ We've had some excellent opportunities to do community service in a really fun way--planting bulbs, working on the Harbor Islands, the day of service where you could pick your task for that day . . . I think one important factor is having the project endorsed by the upper administration, and if it can be done on campus, even better.  though that Harbor Island project was awesome!

Response: Emerson is situated among one of the most dangerous parts of Boston proper. It used to be known as the Combat Zone. Just take a walk down Tremont Street towards Washington Street. There are hoards of people who are outwardly using drugs and begging for money. Emerson should try to get involved in helping to educate/help this population of people.
replies_ddqual:
The Combat Zone hasn't been a thing since about the 1970s. In fact Emerson College itself is in-part responsible for the gentrification of the area. With our arrival has come luxury condos on Boylston and pricing people out of their own neighborhoods.



Boston has massive structural failings that keep drug-use and panhandling as the only good options left for some people. 



To help them, Emerson could do more to dismantle the power structures of our local and federal government.

Response:
I know my first answer seems very harsh, in fact, I've been hopeless trying to find a way to rearrange it to sound more PC, nonetheless, the problem illustrated there by in large, addresses my major issue with this institution. 



I'm not going to reference any scandal that has happened recently because, in my eyes, while important for us to note, it serves no purpose than to drive home the overall point. 



We need a college where the administration and department heads don't seem so terrified and out of touch with the student body. One where students don't need five people's permissions and several dozen papers to sign in order to film in a common room in LB. We need a college that makes being a communicator easy, even if it's critical of the institution. 



There needs to be transparency when you can give it, no red tape where it isn't 100% necessary, and better yet, a community where faculty aren't hidden away in some random floor in the LB,but where a student can walk in and feel friendly enough to ask for a coffee with Mr.Ludman. 





And call me an idealist, or what you will, an Emerson where a student who desires to make something one day, can in fact do so before his semester is out, working both with the students at this college, and a faculty to back them up. As it stands, I think there is too much reliance on the college for students to teach other students the ropes and tricks of production, writing, what have you. I want to be educated by our faculty who have a curriculum  that is thoroughly planned and thought out. Where registration is an adventure like The Hobbit and not easily comparable to the Hunger Games. Where a college which desires to be considered global offers more than just French and Spanish.



 There is so much potential for this college to be a world class institution, but right now, I feel like we're going through some serious growing pains. And I say this, as an Emersonian who is as it stands right now wrapping up his educated,is unsure of how he feels about his time here. I still maintain to all my friends that I think Emerson College it in itself to shine as of the great college's of the northeast, but as it stands right now, we're not there yet, and the one thing holding these students, who by and large are the driving factors in this school, is the backwards behavior of our college's attitude towards us. 



So, to whoever is reading this, I guess this is the best I can give. 



This video is how I feel about everything. We're in halftime right now, and we're on the comeback (I hope)
South America
I don't know as of now how Emerson College physically addresses society's problems, but I know they host a number of talks on the subject. I guess allowing students to speak their minds at forums?

Response: We had a tour come through, called The Wholehearted, about a boxer struggling through domestic violence, addiction, and her own personal demons. The projection design on the show was unlike anything I had ever worked on (a custom fabricated mini-jumbo-tron) and being able to work with this outside company that had such a cool system of their own, as well as watching our video and projection team take the reins on implementing such a big project, was wonderful, and broadened my own understanding of video as a design element.
