Response: All of the above
x
We take advantage of it all in Boston!

Response_ddqual: Robin Williams was such a huge part of my development as a human being. He was a brilliantly beautiful and wickedly talented human being who not only gave me and the world some of the greatest comedic moments in movie history, but also some of the most poignant and profoundly inspiring. I had always loved the Good Will Hunting bench in the Garden, but now whenever the world, or just life in general gets to be too much, I go over to the bench next to that one and just look over and see the greatness that has come out of this man and just how much one person can do. The inspiration that man has brought this world, and still continues to bring to it, to be honest, completely astounds me. I love that bench, I love that place, and I love that man.

Response: Thom Mayne

Emerson has meant opportunity, taking risks, lifelong learning, quality and meaningful relationships, mentoring and being mentored, personal and professional growth and most importantly, people. The ideal Emerson is reflected in the stories and perspectives of our community.
Regularly cited in the press about our specialty fields, Other
Response_ddqual: I think we would reach this when international colleges ask us to set up an exchange or study abroad program in their country or we would be sought after to lend expertise in solving an issue. Being seen as a leader, our reputation would precede us, our work would be recognized and cited, our resident experts would be contacted for advisement and guidance and our impact would be far reaching.

Response: I would hope we are seen as doers, storytellers, agents of change and as a premiere college in the US where all students can thrive and succeed.  As a place where they can teach as much as learn. I think we are seen as a good educational investment and as a great connector to a strong alumni network and employment. I would want Emerson to be known for its innovation.
Africa

The disciplines our students engage in really do have the power to change the world. Access to information in various forms (and access in general) are tremendous tools our students use every day. We are helping to prepare the journalists, writers, speech pathologists, politicians, performers, teachers, film makers, etc of tomorrow. Our students are breaking boundaries every day. Emerson helps provide them with the resources, courage and confidence to take on society's problems, but it will be on their terms and in their own ways. We are actively engaged and we speak up when we see injustices.

Response_ddqual: I wish I could add more than one point! To be honest, I would love to do a semester at sea where we visit a new country or region of the world. I added my point to China. I have never been there, but have worked with many students who come from China. I am very interested in learning the language. It would be a great experience if I could go to a place where English is not the common language, experience a densely populated country and learn about their traditions and culture - especially in education and higher ed.
replies_ddqual: Sharon, I want to go to China too!!!  I've been studying Mandarin on and off for several years, but haven't made much progress--some kind of immersion program would be great!

In 2020 or 2030, I think entrepreneurship will still remain a strong market. Someone is always thinking of a new, efficient and or innovative way of doing something - I don't think that will ebb. Emerson students in particular will be well prepared with their training.

No. He needs to see every opportunity for learning as an opportunity. A way of thinking is a philosophy. Are we looking for the good enough or for greatness? Innovation, perhaps? replies_ddqual: That's a really interesting idea. I had no idea that a lot of Emerson students went on to law school but now that you mention it, it makes sense.

I see monitors all around campus, displaying information at the touch of a screen.

Because of my education at Emerson,  I learned many skills that are transferrable to any company. My studies complement the standard operations and will help take your company to the next level with my innovative thinking!

Response: In my interaction with members of the Emerson community.
Response_ddqual: I intentionally seek learning opportunities every day and do so by talking with members of the community. Everyone here has a story. I ask questions, try not to make assumptions, own my personal privilege and keep my eyes and ears open. I look for differing viewpoints and seek information from a variety of sources.

Response:
The Student Life Office! This is an office that is part of the much larger Division of Student Affairs, that is responsible for complementing student's out of classroom learning. Student Life is an umbrella for the following departments - New Student Orientation, Student Activities, Student Leadership and Greek Life, Multicultural Student Affairs and GLBTQ Resources, Campus Center, Off Campus Student Services, Spiritual Life and student clubs and organizations! We partner with every department on campus so if you are ever unsure where to turn, start with us and we will get you what you need! 



We help to publish the Undergraduate Student Handbook and Policy Guide that outlines the community's rights and responsibilities (http://www.emerson.edu/sites/default/files/PolicyDocuments/academics-undergraduate-student-handbook-2014-2015.pdf), we develop and distribute the Student Organization and Advisor Resources Collection that enables students and advisors to access information and resources in real time (https://drive.google.com/folderview?id=0B3hm0lqr-CdsNUtCdFpQaFVndVU&usp=sharing) and we work to help students and the community to achieve their goals and to be successful.
Colonial Building

Amira can participate in the Off Campus Student Services Engagement Fair at the start of each semester to explore the many agencies and neighborhood associations our students engage. I suggest Amira attend an Imagine Students Reaching Out meeting to become connected with service minded students. She can look to Student Employment and Career Services for off campus employment and internships to put her marketing studies to practical application. She can also connect with the International Student Affairs Office and also with Service Learning and Community Action.
Other
Response_ddqual: I help provide the vehicle and support by which our student organizations engage in community service. The students are the ones who identify who they wish to support (American Red Cross, Casa Myrna Vazquez, Rosie's Place, Sharsherret, ALS, Equity Fights Aid, Greater Boston Food Bank, etc) and my office helps them to do so in a safe and legal way. We also plan a service project as part of orientation and this year, we developed a more formal relationship with Jumpstart that I hope will continue! I also encourage my staff to support Alternative Spring Break by serving as adviors. I wish I could do more.

Response: We are so fortunate to be located so close to Chinatown! There are some amazing restaurants and shops to explore! I am always on the lookout to connect students to the culture and opportunities of the city and will post them to the Student Life Facebook group or Tweet it out! The city is so vibrant - there is always a concert, festival, demonstration, benefit walk, historical re-enactment happening - most you just stumble upon! They are not hard to find! Emerson makes it easy to attend events at the MFA, ICA and there are always discounts at many venues with a college ID. I am also very impressed with the way our student organizations and Greek letter organizations adopt local area beneficiaries. We do some amazing work all over the city!
replies_ddqual: Emerson is right in the middle of the theater district and most offer student rush tickets as low as $10 with your ID!\\ I also love that students can volunteer to be ushers at local theaters - great experience plus you get to see some amazing shows!

Response_ddqual: I see the entire city of Boston to be the boundaries of our campus. Our students live, work, affect and impact the entire city. I see the Walker Building as the center since so many students have classes, faculty have offices, and it is interconnected to the Tufte. The library is located here, as are the Journalism studios. Business Services, the department that provides all of the central services of campus is also located here. Most importantly, Diversity and Inclusion is located here!
replies_ddqual: As much as we gripe about them, the Walker elevators are great places to chat with people between floors and you never know who is getting on/off on any given floor!

Response: Cultural Studies

Emerson College is a creatively charged environment that utilizes the opportunities of the city of Boston to help further our work. The film program here is one of the best in the country, Boston is a great city where you interact with other colleges on a daily basis, and our alumni network is strong. Enrolling at Emerson is becoming a member of a much larger professional community that stays with you long after graduating. I recommend he look at the VMA website and research the faculty in the program and to speak with students enrolled! There is no better way to get a sense of a program or the school than by talking with actual students! If he is looking for a fast paced environment where he will engage in many collaborative efforts both in and outside of the classroom, in an urban environment, then Emerson is the place for him. If he is looking for a more laid back and rural environment, Ithaca may be better suited for him. I have a bias and would love to see him at Emerson but he needs to make the right choice for him. Plus, it is WAY colder in upstate NY!
replies_ddqual: It is SO COLD in upstate NY!

Response: During extra-curriculars and co-curriculars, Working on team projects
Response_ddqual: Working as an advisor to many clubs and organizations has allowed me opportunities to interact with a wide variety of students at varying levels of experience and that has enabled me to grow and learn. I also am a firm believer in collaboration and the more opportunities to bring people together to work towards a common goal will result in an expanded knowledge base and an exposure to different ways of thinking and doing. Our team in Student Life is comprised of some truly outstanding professionals who challenge, inspire, critical thinkers, supporters and service oriented. Working in this team on any project, learning is guaranteed, and we pass this learning to the students and departments with whom we work!
replies_ddqual: I love being a part of the Student Life team!\\ This is why you are so great Sharon! :D\\ Nice photo of you all!!!\\ Awww.... Thank you!

Response: Student-Instructor Ratio, Opportunities to collaborate with academic or professional experts in your field, Co-curriculars
Response_ddqual: Our small class size allows for more individualized interaction between students and faculty. The more interaction, the more opportunities for growth. I also believe the co-curriculars are excellent complements to classroom learning.

Response: Common Ground

It sounds as though there are many transferable skills Joanne can use between the majors. My primary question to her is whether she envisions TV writing as a career or as a hobby and she can explore what gives her joy in this arena. Meeting with her academic advisor will help her in making a decision on her academic path. She also can continue to dabble in co-curriculars affiliated with either major in order to provide for further exploration. She may also merge the two together and consider the development of a customized curriculum with the IDIP program. The more she explores both in and outside the classroom, the better informed and educated she may be in determining her next steps.
replies_ddqual: "The more she explores both in and outside the classroom, the better informed and educated she may be in determining her next steps." Yes!

Response: The Emerson community has challenged me to keep up to date (and most times, ahead) of trend in the field. Our students are quite savvy and are seeking professional growth and challenge and it is up to us to provide that for them. I feel quite fortunate to be a member of a community that encourages exploration, risk taking and growth. In 2010, a group of students proposed that Emerson be a host site for the Association of College Unions-International (ACUI) College Unions Poetry Slam Invitational and I was asked to be the host facilitator. It was a risk since we were hosting 15 other colleges and inviting local community to explore slam poetry as a medium - at the time, a mostly underground medium. It was one of the most exciting and involving events I have facilitated and it taught me another mode of expression.
Almost every day
Response_ddqual: So much of my work is dependent upon others in some way, shape or form. I wouldn't want it any other way!!!  "It Takes a Village" is our mantra in any work that we do in Student Life!

Response: The primary communal & meeting place for Emerson students at the College's Back Bay campus (130 Beacon Street)

I suggest Maria connect with her Resident Assistant and Orientation Leader! Both are tremendous resources for any new student!  I also recommend she attend as many of the orientation events that she can - it will help her to meet others! She also can attend the Organization Fair to get a sense of all of the co- and extra-curricular involvement opportunities that Emerson affords whether now or at any point in her time at Emerson!  She should also see her advisor in the Advising Center to talk through her academic goals and the WARC if she wants to explore study strategies. If she is feeling overwhelmed by her transition, she can make an appointment at ECAPS. She may also enroll in the Money Matters program to give her a roadmap of her finances. Also, she can utilize the staff in Student Life - we will connect any and all students with the resources and support they need to succeed!
replies_ddqual: I totally agree with that!

Response: I am most excited about being part of the Emerson Community when... I have the opportunity to bring people from different parts of the community together for a conversation, to managed a project or just to shared resources or a positive experience. This can be through an event or referring/connecting students to faculty or staff who can share their knowledge or even having a conversation about someone's interest and encouraging them to share this interest with someone else! People here are really open to sharing and exploring together!
replies_ddqual: Collaboration is such a key part of the Emerson experience!

Response_ddqual: I spend more time in the Max Mutchnick Campus Center than anywhere else on campus since that is where my office is located, but also because this is the central hub of student activity on campus. At any given time, you can find students gathering in formal and informal ways and there is always something going on in the Campus Center. I was also involved in the planning of the design and function of this building so it is of particular interest to me that I am able to see how the facility is being used my our community!
replies_ddqual: The Campus Center is such a great space!

Response_ddqual: I imagine it - Cabaret 2.0. Another multi-purpose, multi-function performance and event space on campus that can be reserved on Spacebook, free of charge, employing students to support the work of our community? Tis a beautiful thing. Who is with me?
replies_ddqual: Yes! I'm all for Cabaret 2.0!\\ My vote has always been for Cab 2.0! Just think, Jake will never leave!\\ My vision of Cabaret 2.0 is a space designed by students, managed by students, and featuring events by and for students.  Easiest way to describe it would be a corss between Space 57 at the Revere Hotel and the Hotung Cafe at Tufts - semi-blackbock theater that can be set up as social/lounge space when not in use for specific events, and that has a food service option (my choice would be a coffee/smoothie bar with light snacks) so that students, faculty and staff have another place to come together.  The space would be adaptable to accommodate the variety of events we host, dinners, concerts, comedy shows, theatrical performances, screenings, fashion shows, etc. and feature expanded options of many of the features we have now, such as live mixing for audio and lighting, and more.  It would be the premier space on campus for events.

Response_ddqual: We work so hard to create and encourage the Emerson spirit at orientation! OLs are OL4Life, but how do we keep the spirit and pride shining bright long after orientation is over?
replies_ddqual:
I'm not sure if I can offer a direct solution just yet, but my impression is that after orientation, everyone gets isolated off in their own little clique centered around an activity or social group. Greek Life has done well to break out of this through Greek-wide efforts, but that still stops within our own little community. It sucks to say, but Emerson students are often so self-centered that if you don't do something related to someone else's interests, then you really don't interact. That's one of the big boundaries to overcome.\\ Iy is so easy to get caught up inour silos, for sure! There is so much crossover between them and so many exciting and motivational people and work being done to be celebrated and proud of! I wish we did more of that!\\ I think supporting each other at our performances/games/etc. can foster a sense of community.\\ I always wanted to be an OL!!!! I love the OL's!\\ Nick D., your comment is really interesting in connection to what I hear about students feeling isolated. . . 



\\ I'm so curious if this is an Emerson thing or if this happens at other colleges. Is it fomo (fear of missing out) or something deeper?

Response_ddqual: We will never have as much time or space as we want to accomplish all our plans - that being said, I would love to see Emerson buy or purchase large event spaces - l spend so much of my budget on off campus facilities (that are not theaters) for orientation, family weekend, senior week and other institutional events since there is no open space on campus that can hold over 500.
replies_ddqual:
That is a huge need that absolutely must be addressed. \\ The idea of being able to have Hooray! at an on campus facility is amazing.\\ Or ERA, Family Weekend, Senior Week events, EFA, Org Fair, and the list continues... Think of howmuch we can unburden the gym... \\ Admission Open Houses and Accepted Student Days... where are my Admission folks at to give this some momentum!!!!\\ Most importantly though is that any space we do create needs to be developed with input from the Emerson community, and priority access give to the Emerson community.  



....Sounds like we need Cabaret 2.0. \\ Tell us more about your vision of a Cabaret 2.0!\\ I LOVE this. I work for Admission too and know it's really difficult to find/afford space for large events. Hopefully that swanky new building we're supposed to get has some space in it?\\ I haven't seen the specs, but that doesn't mean I am not asking for programming space there! It probably wouldn't be as big a venue given the footprint. Encourage people to chime in on the types of spaces we want! \\ And best of all if we get Cabaret 2.0 you won't have to ever say goodbye to me! ;)\\ We never have to say goodbye Jake! As an alumni, there are many ways to stay connect to the campus... and to us!!!!\\ We absolutely need more space!  The space must also be versatile, like the Bordy, Cabaret and MPR.  The theaters are not only tricky to get, but are also limiting as far as setup!\\ Good call Amanda! Has there been a set up request that you have made that was not able to happen? \\ Also studio space for theater groups, dance groups, classes, and general rehearsals, if possible! I love the emerson studios in Paramount, but there simply aren't enough- especially for large groups! More space please! :)\\ How large of a studio would be ideal? \\ Josh, should we make Cabaret 2.0 a cause? Sounds like a pretty nifty thing that could use some funding!\\ Cabaret 2.0 will cost more than $100). Josh and I have very expensive taste. :-)\\ I second Pat -- Cab 2.0 should be a cause\\ Cabaret 2.0 isn't a cause, it's the effect.

Response_ddqual:
Emerson College is a smoke free school. Not sure if you have seen the Beacon article on a topic SGA discussed this week around the issue of smoking outside of campus buildings but this is an issue the college has been struggling with for a while! Does anyone have any creative or innovative ideas how to address this? How do we balance the needs of a smoker with the needs of a community member who wants to get to class or their office or walk the streets without passing through second hand smoke? 

http://www.berkeleybeacon.com/news/2014/10/1/smoking-outside-of-buildings-72
replies_ddqual: As a smoker (I know, for shame) I agree that the gaggle of smokers just outside the buildings is a problem.  However, where else will we go?!  At the Union Bank building (217 Tremont St) we go around the corner to the ally way where this is a parking lot and garage.  Are there places which can be designated at smoking areas which are not in front of buildings but are clearly marked and may even have ashtrays?  I think this would be helpful for all.  And yeah, I get it that designating a smoking area feels like, to the administration, they are condoning smoking, but unless and until smoking tobacco is made illegal (not my chosen option) it seems the best option.\\ Thanks Karen! I really appreciate your perspective and it is helpful to hear from smokers on this too! Is there a location that you would suggest? \\ Point taken about the alley between Maj and LB.  The alley next to 216 Tremont has a sidewalk (this is where smoke already) so that could be one.  Also, I notices on Tremont St, the LB side there is a cut out next to 201 Tremont which is NOT a doorway, could this be a place?  It is small, but I am trying to come up with some ideas.

Response_ddqual: An interesting conversation occurred in SGA yesterday that I'd like to pose to the group about emails. Some members of SGA mentioned that email was the best way to reach them but that they get so many emails from various Emerson sources over the course of a day that they get overloaded and often get the same message from multiple sources - citing Emerson Uncommon as an example. They got an email about the game from News, from this week at Emerson, from their faculty, from their department, from my staff in my office, etc. My question is this - how do we streamline the delivery of information to provide the community with info about opportunities in a way that will actually be received?
replies_ddqual: Separating the wheat from the chaff is a time-consuming task of adulthood. \\ It'd be great to have a college-wide internal communications coordination team. We've built up a pretty solid communications team within IT, and it's worked really well to unify our communications with the college. Maybe the entire campus could use one such team that helps streamline big email blasts. \\ I wonder about having some sort of opt-in listserv, where students (and staff) could choose which messages to recieve. For example, choosing to recieve all announcements from the Institue but no email about films.\\ That isn't a bad idea Cate, but then we assume that film students are only interested in film and missing out on other intrests and opportunitues to help expand their perspective. I really like Cyle's plan of coordinating and streamlining efforts. In theory, anyone can go to spacebook to see what is booked on campus by sponsoring department, group, location, time,  etc., but that takes work and I am not sure many do it. \\ Andy Tiedemann and Dan O'Brien recently helped ODI with this problem. We want to advertise our events and newsletter to the Emerson community, but don't want to oversaturate everyone's email box. I think they'd love to know about your feedback!

Response: Right now, I think an Emerson degree means a world of connections. The name alone can help with many jobs. Hopefully this will still be true in the future, but it's hard to tell. Degrees aren't worth as much as they used to be. In today's world it's possible to succeed without a degree and instead succeed based on self-taught skills. It'd be interesting to see what becomes worth more in the future, degrees or skills. It could go either way, especially with how expensive college is nowadays. A lot of people just think a degree isn't worth it, which could effect the worth of all college degrees, not just Emerson.

I think philosophy is important in learning how to think differently and empathize and see things from many perspectives. Response: I know that Gaming has recently been added to the| Interactive Media production track, but it would be nice if Emerson could somehow dive deeper. With all the new gaming classes being offered and our access to technology, I think it would be wise for Emerson to dive deeper into the world of game design and coding. Games can be used for so many different things and "art games" are currently on the rise. It seems that Emerson is currently on track for being more involved with this, and hopefully 20 years from now will be fully immersed with all sides of video game creation. We're not there yet, but the potential is definitely there.

It's almost impossible to imagine what technology will be like in another 10 years consider how far we've come in the past 10 years, so it's a bit difficult to predict something like this. However, I'd like to imagine and hope that Emerson would continue to try and be integrated with upcoming and future technology as much as possible. Whether it be creating amazing projects with 3D printers or filming on the newest 4k+ cameras, I hope that all of these new pieces of technology become fully integrated into students' curriculum. I also imagine that technology will help campuses become fully connected, and maybe even all books will become ebooks, making them not only easier to carrier but hopefully also cheaper to afford. It'd be nice to see technology integrated into lecture type classes too, to help make them less outdated and more engaging than just listening to a professor talk for an hour and forty five minutes. There is so much untapped potential by adding a level of interactivity to lectures that I feel isn't being paid enough attention.

Arts related classes help to improve creativity and to tackle obstacles in different ways. They helped to provide a different perspective that allows for creative and original solutions to problems that wouldn't be thought of in a more logical way.
Liberal arts college
Response_ddqual: Emerson is a liberal arts college because of the majors and classes it offers. There aren't enough fundamental art classes to consider it an art school, and there are majors here that have nothing to do with art.  Perhaps it could be seen as a professional school because it trains you for specific fields, but Emerson goes further than just training you for a specific field, which I think puts it in the liberal arts category.

Response: Student-Instructor Ratio, Opportunities to do original work, Co-curriculars
Response_ddqual: Student-Instructor ratio has been key to making some of my best work. When I get to know my professors I can work more closely with them and get the help I need to do my best on projects. When I'm in a large class and I don't know the professor, I'm less personally attached to my work, especially if it's in a gen ed class. The opportunity to do original work is the most important because it allows you to create resume and portfolio work to help you in the real world. The more original content you create in school, the better you'll be when you graduate and look for a job. Co-curricular's are important to being able to work on projects and be involved in things on top of the projects you're working on in class. I think Emerson has a lot of opportunities, but it could be better. A lot of them can be pretty exclusive which I think defeats the purpose of being a co-curricular.

The college can help her by working directly with her through Academic Advising to show her what she needs to do or what her best course of action would be to allow her to pursue screenwriting.

There have been an endless amount of experiences that have had major impacts on me. Most of them are from interacting with other people. Response_ddqual: Just this past week I learned something new every day. I've learned about how rainbows are made and why the sky is blue and tons of things about how radars work. Every day my classes are teaching me many things I don't know.

Response: One of my favorite learning moments at Emerson was the year long Intro to College Writing/Research Writing course I took with Molly McGillicuddy. I was nervous for both of these classes considering I'm not the greatest writer, but her class not only made writing fun and make more sense, but it also helped build a stable little community that helped me get through Freshman year. Having the same people in class for an entire year made the year feel more solid and allowed ourselves to get to know each other and each other's writing styles very well. This created an amazing environment for learning how to write better and made peer reviewing extremely successful. It's still one of my favorite classes I've ever been a part of, and I take a lot of the things I learned in those classes with me into many of my other classes.

Response_ddqual: Just throwing this out there... I wish Emerson had better heat and air conditioning management. If anything I wish it was at least consistent? I started my day freezing cold in the dorms, proceeded to visit a classroom with a decent temperature that would blast freezing cold air every ten minutes, and finished the day in a scorching hot classroom to the point where the entire class was melting and it seriously impacted our lesson on both the professor and the students' ends. And this has been a problem for the entire three years I've been at Emerson. Is there any way to make this at least even a little bit better?
replies_ddqual:
I'm always cold in the library.  and since I work here, I'm always cold.\\ It might be freezing on one floor in Tufte, but it's hot and stale on the second floor. I know there's one HVAC person for all of campus.  That seems ridiculous. \\ I'm glad I'm not insane and this is an actual thing other people feel. You can definitely experience a hundred different temperatures in one day in the Ansin building. And I'd like no more air conditioning in October, please! 57 degrees and rainy doesn't constitute the AC for me at least.\\ I agree, however, as these buildings are old and retrofitted, it is difficult to get the air to be consistent.  I have been working in old buildings like this and it is always a problem.  Not a solution, but at least and answer,



My office bounces between too hot and too cold!\\ I want to give a shout out to Emerson's HVAC guy.  He is indeed one of the busiest guys on our facilities team, which includes a great bunch of hardworking, service oriented and friendly men and women.  Busy as he is, he always takes time to answer my questions about specific HVAC issues. And even if Emerson had completely modern and fully efficient HVAC systems, there would still be people who thought it was too hot or too cold because different people have different comfort levels.  This is New England, people.  Celebrate the diversity of our seasons.  Bring a sweater to work or dress in layers so that you can adjust to changing temperatures, indoors and out.\\ Sure everybody feels temperature differently and sure layers can sometimes fix temperature issues, but what about when Emerson turns off the heat when it's freezing cold, and turns off the air conditioning when it's extremely hot? I usually wouldn't mind, but for the past 3 years there have been days I haven't been able to use my room because it was too hot to function and there was nothing I could do about it because I had no control over the air conditioning. Is this to save money or does it just decide not to work for months at a time? Shout out to the HVAC guy, I'm sure he works extremely hard, but it'd be nice if for once I could have control over the temperature of my room. I can't even open my windows to try and counteract anything because for the last 2 years I've had broken windows that won't stay open. Remind me what my room and board is paying for again?



I'm sorry if this is rude, I really don't mean to be, but I'm tired of being told to just "deal with it" all the time.\\ I hear your pain but what some of the others have said is true and believe it or not, we recently had some upgrades to the actual systems which have made things better (I know, it still doesn't make you feel better).  One of the other problems is that in buildings like Ansin and Walker offices and spaces change constantly but the duct work in those spaces does not change which causes problems.  For example, I need to keep my storage room within a certain temperature range (cooler) and the adjacent spaces a little warmer. I can tell when their is a problem right away when I walk in and the the hallway is hot. That means my storage area is hot and my office (adjacent to storage) is cold.  Makes no sense, I know but that's how it works.  Bottom line is not system is perfect in any building (Emerson or not) so I find that layers is the best option.

Response_ddqual: I'd like to voice the concerns of not only myself but a lot of Animation majors when I say that the Animation and Motion Media part of the VMA department has also been getting lost. Being in a department that focuses so much on the film side has left us working extra hard to make the most out of our experience here. Not only are there only a few animation specific classes that are actually part of the major, but it's also extremely difficult to get into them. There were only 3 spots available for a required class that happens once a year. So not only are animation majors not always able to take their classes, but the classes offered are extremely general. It'd be nice to have classes dedicated to just modeling or just texturing instead of two classes that try to cover absolutely everything in a really short amount of time. The professors work extremely hard to help us make the most out of what's offered, but it'd be nice if there was somehow a way to improve upon this situation.
replies_ddqual:
I think there is a large disconnect between several of the specializations in VMA. Post Production is in the same boat with only 2 editing classes. Due to the setup of the 200, 300, 400 level classes, I even completed the Animation track before I completed my own Post Production track.  It baffles my mind that I'm supposed to soak up everything about editing in 2 classes while if I were a Film Production student, I would be able to take several different production classes & choose between different directions. Show everyone some more love!



Maybe some compositing or color correction classes?\\ The same problem is apparent in the Audio Post-Production specialization, in that many of my friends who are Sound Design majors couldn't get into sound design classes because they were full with non major students.\\ Exactly! It doesn't make sense that we're supposed to specialize in something with only two or three classes? It's not nearly enough. And the non major students taking specialized classes is a huge problem throughout majors apparently.



It'd be awesome if there was some sort of color correction class. Maybe even a color theory class! It could be for editing and animation. There's so many things and specializations we're not learning about and it makes me worry we won't know enough to succeed outside of Emerson.

http://www.theatlantic.com/education/archive/2014/02/why-study-philosophy-to-challenge-your-own-point-of-view/283954/



Also, 

"The study of philosophy has always been of serious interest to human beings. In addition, in any fieldfrom business, to medicine, to law, to teaching, to computer programming and civil engineeringthe ability to think clearly and creatively as well as the capacity to solve problems is central to professional success and personal satisfaction. Of course, while taking one or two philosophy classes does not guarantee success, a philosophy class is one of the best ways to work on the acquisition and development of:



    Critical thinking skills: The ability to identify key issues in decision-making or problem solving; and to identify various related problems and solutions.

    Skills in argumentation: The ability to proceed in a valid and sound way from premises to conclusions; to rationally persuade others; to more rigorously seek reasoned self-understanding.

    Communication skills: The ability to summarize the content of a message clearly and objectively (for example, to differentiate fact from value); to explain complex ideas and principles.

    Skills in design and planning: The ability to look at a problem, or an opportunity, from different angles and to identify alternative plans of action or design."

--from Santa Clara University

Response_ddqual: It's hard to categorize Emerson. We are certainly not a trade school, though we do offer many brilliant hands on learning opportunities like WERS, the Emerson Channel and the Berkeley Beacon. It's not a liberal arts college, though there is a robust offering of liberal arts courses. We are not a conservatory, though the performing arts program operates much like one. To say we are an art school doesn't really account for our smaller, but equally important programs in communication studies, communication sciences and disorders, marketing, etc. We are an arts focused communication school with a strong commitment to the liberal arts.

As a film person myself (both a BA and MFA in film production) I can say that there is a more dynamic filmmaking community in Boston with more opportunities to intern and world class production companies and see films hosted by the makers. I think we should bring back the discounted meals for faculty and staff. When I first started at Emerson it cost $4 for faculty and staff to eat in the dining hall. It was a great way to encourage more community interaction. I ate there at least once a week and always had brilliant interactions with my colleagues and students. I would bring alumni  and special guests with me as well. We have a shortage of community space on this campus. We should really make the most of what we have. There is nothing like face to face interaction over a meal.

Response_ddqual: I have heard people describe it as both a Liberal Arts College and an Art School. I think the curriculum and programs are much to challenging and varied to be considered an art school. We still have science and math requirements. We have minors in various, non-art, fields, and roots in communication disorders which is not an art but a science and study of the brain. So, no, we are not an art school, but we have amazing art programs and treat almost anything we do here as 'an art form' which is part of the reason why I came here for writing...because I have always felt that it was an artistic process and many other "liberal arts" colleges do not adhere to the ideology.

The World will see what The World will see!  It is difficult to know what the world perceives.  There are too many variants! There were people in a restaurant next to the Paramount Theatre talking badly about Emerson as I passed them.  They did not know I who I was. I want Emerson to be perceived as the College that gets it as close to what academia is about as it possible.  I want Emerson to be perceived as the College that is inclusive, not just because of skin color diversity - which is a wonderful thing - but inclusive of all the sensible, reachable, new ideas to be discovered in the future by the people working towards that future.  I want Emerson to be the college worthy of the Lion's Roar! I'm tired - good night - PEACE

Response: When I try to put description to my ideal Emerson; and the question is what Emerson means to me, Emerson is about the human ties that bind the minds of teachers and learners together in an "Out-side-the-box" almost magical, manner!  Partnerships and friendships are planted, nourished and grow for many years.  Faces change, buildings change, seasons change, causes change, technology changes, history changes, time changes, almost everything changes, but Emerson has kept up with the changes and it seems that students in the far future will attend Emerson because of it's unique ways of staying the same, but changing.  As long as there are young minds anxious to communicate professionally with the world, and as long as Emerson can provide the mental, spiritual, and physical nourishment to help them reach their goals, my ideal Emerson exists!  More than a college in many ways, more like a family in many ways, is Emerson!

Response: Proper Clothing for Virtual Rooms.  Which clothing is proper for which function in the Virtual Rooms. OTFLOL

After my robot wakes me from sleeping, I ride my moving floor strip to my Prepare for the Day Room.  After my automated items brush my teeth, shower me, comb my hair, do my make-up and etc. I ride to my automated closet where I pick my attire for the day. After dressing, I ride to the breakfast/first lesson of the day room.  While my robots are preparing my meal, I watch my first class of the day live stream.  I eat and leave while my robots take care of the cleaning and etc.  Next I ride my moving floor to my exercise room.  The exercise room is filled with equipment that I just relax on while they exercise my body for me.  Now it is time for my human contact class.  I move into the human contact room and communicate with other humans by talking, playing games, all sorts of human stuff.  Now I return to my learning room and do my live stream lessons for the rest of the day.  When I finish my lessons I freshen myself and my robots serve the meals they prepared.  My robots perform little skits to help me remember my family.  When that is done I walk over to the Boston Commons and enjoy the rest of the evening until I return for bed.  There some other stuff that happens in between all of this, but there is not time to elaborate at this moment.

If I were Dawn I may say that my arts-related courses prepared me not only think long-term about situations, but also outside of the box.  These courses prepared me to be an important part of the creative process when supplying the goods to those needing them, in an accurate and timely manner.  The arts related courses prepared me to work as a team member, being trusted and trusting my team.  I have also learned to be confident doing creative tasks alone when required.

Response: Student-Instructor Ratio, Opportunities to do original work, Opportunities to collaborate with academic or professional experts in your field, Support for research & scholarship, Other (explain)
Response_ddqual: Student-Instructor ration determines how much one on one time the Instructor gets to have with each student in order to determine the type and amount of training needs to be provided.  Opportunities to do original work gives the student a chance to explore and produce to their greatest potential.  Collaborating with academic or professional experts in your field allows the expertise of what has been accomplished by them to give you the history, tools and insights of what has already been accomplished while you develop and bring your new ideas into being.  Support for research & scholarship allows work far beyond what some students could afford if wasn't provided.  Other is spiritual uplift.  There must be spiritual satisfaction so that the accomplishments are understood to be about more than just personal physical gains.  The spiritual joy of knowing that what you accomplish will benefit others is very important.

Haley House, Boston: http://www.haleyhouse.org/ 



I am not sure if they already do, but I live directly next to the HH Cafe is Roxbury and it is an amazing place and organization with a purpose.



Hearth: http://www.hearth-home.org/



Hearth was founded as The Committee to End Elder Homelessness, Inc. (CEEH) in 1991 by a group of seven professional women with diverse experience in housing, finance, health, and human services. They realized that elders were a growing percentage of the homeless population and that no one was expressly addressing the issue. Now in its twentieth year, Hearth is an expert on the challenges and solutions of ending elder homelessness. 



Boston Living Center: http://www.vpi.org/boston/who-we-are/



The Boston Living Center (BLC) is a nonprofit community and resource center whose mission is to foster the wellness of all HIV positive people and respond to the changing needs of the HIV/AIDS community. Through peer leadership and support, we strive to enhance and enrich the lives of our members by providing education, treatment information, and support services with the goal of empowering members to live productive lives and participate within their families and communities.



The Boston Living Center provides programs and services, free-of-charge, to members in an exceptionally welcoming, drug-free, safe, confidential and culturally diverse environment. The only criterion for membership at the Center is verification of HIV+ status.

Here's a paragraph from the most recent thing I "made" at Emerson, a short story titled "Sugar Ants"

...



I think there must still be plenty of letters hidden here. Sometimes at night when I can't sleep I'll get up and check the nursery. I'll peel up a corner of carpet that looks loose; or tug on a warped baseboard. Less and less I'll take a book down from a shelf to have a pale pink leaf fall to the floor, but I know there are more. The one and only time I tried to garden I unearthed a metal toolbox rusted shut. When I'd pried the thing open a pile of rust-pink letters slid out. Each time I find another letter I file it with the rest in a series of boxes in the attic. I do my best to keep them in chronological order, but I can't bring myself to read them all. 



...

Response:
As a staff, my favorite learning moment was the Proyecto Boston-Medellin exhibit in 2013 on Walker 10. It was incredible to see students from another country come to our school and share their work with us. It is not easy sharing art or a passion like that, opening yourself up to critics and strangers, and they traveled all the way from Colombia to open themselves up to us. Their stories and art were amazing. 



As an alum and current graduate student, my favorite learning moment is really more about all the things I've been able to do and experience while at Emerson. I tested the waters in several majors and disciplines, and when I came up against a wall, my Emerson education told me to find another way. The things I've learned have given me the knowledge and experience to pursue my passion and help others, and I get to keep learning through the MFA Creative Writing program.

Response: The picture that I have (hopefully) uploaded is from the Emerson island in Second Life.  It features a photograph of founder Charles W. Emerson, as well as the island administrator that was designed to resemble him. I choose this image because it represents one of characteristics of my ideal Emerson, which is being able to reimagine and reinvent yourself in response to the changing world around us. The fact that Second Life is no longer as prominent as it once was is not important.  Instead, it is important that Emerson recognized it, engaged with it and eventually moved on to another platform. In this respect, it shows Emerson's ability to adapt to changing technology, which has allowed us to prosper and grow from the 19th century to the present. Finally, it also represents the importance of remembering where you came from as you envision your future.

Response:
Today, a degree from Emerson means that you have worked your way through a series of courses and co-curricular experiences that have prepared you to enter your chosen field or profession.  Stated more simply, a degree from Emerson means that you are ready to work.  That sounds more mundane that I intended, but I do believe that, more than at other institutions of higher ed, many of our students don't just graduate, they launch themselves out into the world with energy, enthusiasm and purpose.



How might that change in the next decade or so?  Perhaps in terms of what they learn from their Emerson experience and how they channel their talent, energy and enthusiasm.  Given Emerson's increasing focus on diversity, inclusion, globalization and international engagement, I predict that an Emerson degree will also come to signify a person who demonstrates a commitment to these values in their work, their communities and their personal lives.

Julian is right to consider whether his time is being spent efficiently, but he should not let himself slip into anxiety or unease over this question.  Instead he should take a few minutes to reflect on how a course in philosophy might bring some value to his future.  Some might say that the film industry in particular and Los Angeles in general are removed from reality and built on fantasy.  In that context, it might be valuable to develop his ability to understand fundamental truths about himself and the world that he lives in.  So I say take that philosophy and enjoy the different perspective it will provide.

Speaking from my experience with VMA.  Unfortunately, I feel like Emerson sometimes gives students the impression that it's an art school when in fact it's more like a Professional School.  Emerson is clearly very invested in the LA program, in Hollywood, and providing practical tools for students to start careers.  Students are constantly trying to pigeonhole themselves as "producer," "editor," and not thinking about their body of work, not considering what is at stake and larger incentives to make work than a career. 



 It's a hard balance because the skills Emerson provides are invaluable.  I think Emerson has the possibility to straddle between a school whose students make critical media art and a professional school  where students can get real world skills-  students are sponges, eager to learn and question, and the core of the professors teaching in the film dept. are amazing artists. But somewhere in there careers and internships in LA take over.

It means engaging in dialog with the community - including those who are typically pushed aside.  It's absolutely surreal to walk from the Chinatown T-stop and have two totally different worlds on the same block.  The Ritz to the right and St. Francis House to the left.  Not to be to Romantic here but Emerson is located in the center of the block.  I'm not delusional.  I don't think Emerson can change a systemic problem but I think we should seriously consider how we can bridge an obvious gap in the community that impacts our campus directly.  Small steps can make a big impact. <- romantic.



I also think things like giving staff members a paid work day for Community Service would be great.  I think we should be donating "old" equipment to schools that don't have access to the resources we consider outdated.   We should be having dialog with the Emerson community and with the larger Boston community about how we restore properties that we own and what/how/to whom those spaces are distributed to.  I'm sure we do this in some way already but I feel like as a Boston resident, Emerson staff member and Emerson student this information isn't very accessible.

Response_ddqual: Daycare - We apparently receive some daycare benefits from Emerson though this has been hard to track down.  I know we are currently trying to establish a relationship with the day care in the Transportation building but it would be great to have a more robust offering of daycare discounts.  Other institutions in the area offer extremely discounted rates or even offer daycare within the institution itself.  Talk about building community - lessening this burden on families would have a tremendous impact on families in the Emerson community.
replies_ddqual:
If we had benefits for the Transportation Children's Center, that would be AMAZING. I gave up on Emerson-discounted daycare pretty darn fast.\\ What about adult day care?  I have no kids but I do have an aging parent.  We often talk about what we can do for families.  This lets out those of us who do not have families (I had one, but my husband died 2.5 years ago, we have no kids.) Aside from the tremendous financial burden of going from a two income household to a one income household is hard enough in this two income world, there is no one to help me with my mom when she gets sick.  Yet, there is little talk about adult day care and supporting SINGLE people trying to live in this very expensive city.\\ Karen, contact alayne_fiore@emerson.edu to find out when the next meeting of EmCares is. 



Originally there were going to be two groups called EmMoms and EmDads, but it became one called EmCares specifically so that it could also include people who are caring for older or disabled family members.



It meets about once a month over lunch and functions as a social support group and to decide if there is anything that we want to pursue with our newfound power as an officially recognized Employee Resource Group.\\ I used daycare in Chinatown through the BostonChinatown Neighborhood Center, and they charge rates on a sliding scale depending on your income.  The programs are excellent.  They do have waitlists, but the wait wasn't too bad for my kids. Full day programs, and very convenient for those of us who work at emerson.

Response_ddqual: Isn't there a group that meets up on campus for Staff members with families to have lunch and talk/share about experiences?  I feel like a received an e-mail about this a long time ago but then never saw anything again.  I'm curious just as a way of following up with my Daycare benefits concern.  If I didn't just make that group up, it'd be great to meet up and talk about what other institutions are doing and potentially propose something.  I actually wouldn't mind doing some of the leg work but I think I would need a good amount of backing.  It also makes sense to talk with families and see what's needed.
replies_ddqual: Absolutely! It's called EmCares, and it meets on the 10th floor of Walker. Email alayne_fiore@emerson.edu for the next meeting time - I'm spacing on when it is.\\ Thanks so much!

Response_ddqual: I'm a bit concerned about some of the causes that have been approved.  It's not that I'm not for, say a Faculty Lounge or switching the TV studios to HD, but it seems like those types of projects need way more than $1,000 and should probably just be investments made by the school.  Those causes should be priorities for the school and the school should be investing in making the change.  I strongly feel that these $1000.00 prizes should go to a place that: a) really can't be "justified" by any particular department b) where the funds can make a significant impact.
replies_ddqual:
While I understand this, I really think that it is fair for people who feel strongly about something to put it out there.  Myself, therapy dogs for finals leaves me nonplussed (I worry about people who are allergic to dogs trying to share the space.) But is seems important especially to students, so who am I to judge?\\ Karen, we in the library share your concern. We're investigating whether we could provide face-masks so people whose allergies are affected by inhaling hair or dander could get some time with the dogs without suffering badly. (We can't provide drugs, I'm told.) We want this to be accessible to as many people who want to participate, and safe and comfortable for anyone who really doesn't. \\ I agree with Kim-- I don't think she's judging the merits of any of the initiatives suggested. I think she's suggesting that we players of the game should support causes that go beyond what would ostensibly be an extra thousand dollars to a department's budget. And that's not to suggest that those changes are unimportant-- actually the opposite. Rather than get $1000 in this platform, perhaps some of these causes would require (and deserve) more institutional support (as Kim noted, converted TV studios to HD is a great example of that). Just my opinion.\\ Exactly.  My comment is more about making a distinction between upgrades to facilities that the college should  be performing regardless of this game versus achievable initiatives that help us expand or enrich our community. \\ Some ideas about giving more people access to the therapy dogs-- yes, face masks is a great thought; some of the Cause money can be used for that.

Also, we want to broadcast the dog-time on the screens around campus, so people can participate virtually.\\ I think creating a cause may sometimes be intended primarily as a means of raising awareness and support for an service or program that a staff member has, rather than truly trying to "win" the $1000. 



That said, I would appreciate more clarity about what the parameters are for an "appropriate" cause. As it is, there's really no published guidance on how to craft a cause that will be approved, only feedback after it has already been rejected. Also, some causes don't really explain how the money will be budgeted, and I wish that had been a requirement. Or, if not, it'd be nice if there was a way to ask the cause creator questions and receive responses before having to commit coins.\\ I totally agree!  There really should be another platform though to raise awareness about causes that doesn't involve winning actual money though.  Some of the causes that have been posted seem like they could really use and make an impact with $1000.00.  I also agree that there should be some guidelines posted about the parameters for creating a cause and potentially even information about causes that were rejected and why.  \\ I echo the idea that some of the "causes" are really just a way to raise awareness. I think it's important to the integrity of the game that players are able to "vote" with their coins for the cause of their choice. The community building is not just about the winning project but about engaging in the process by which the causes are created and build support.\\ I proposed the TV studio update to HD, with the intention to raise awareness of the issue. While there is some equipment we could purchase for $1000, it would of course be a very small dent in a very large project. But the fact that so many people are seeing it, hopefully that will help raise student and staff support when it might one day be a possibility to be funded by the school. \\ For sure.  Raising awareness about facilities that need upgrades is important.  As this is currently the only platform we seem to have where students, faculty and staff can all post/comment/share ideas and frustration it makes sense to have it as a cause.  And yeah, allowing the community to decide makes sense.  But as it stands, the community doesn't really have full disclosure, the institution does. 



I initially posted the comment because a suggested cause to donate money to a local charity was rejected.  I think maybe the problem is that there is no specification on what a cause should or shouldn't be, making it seem like the community could really put anything up to raise awareness aboutwell, anything.  Donating funds with "no strings attached" to a local charity seemed like a great way to show we are invested in our community.  And if others felt the same, they would also give coins.  \\ there is a part two but I can't post it.....\\ When the suggested cause was rejected it then became obvious that there were parameters in place as to what we as a community could even option.  Who decides this and based on what standards?  Emerson is clearly trying to brand itself in a particular way, and thus not every cause fits within their projected image. In other words, this read to me as a pretty one side take on the community developing and voting on their own cause(s).  

\\ I think what this does show is the need for a platform where students, faculty and staff can communicate and connect about these issues to get answers about why we haven't upgraded the TV studios.  How has Emerson's priorities shifted in such a way that they haven't been upgraded?  How much does this cost?  What are the obstacles?  Do we as staff, faculty and students disagree with the priorities that Emerson is taking versus how we want the school to evolve? 





Anyway, I'm not trying to instigate anything.  I just thought I would clarify my position better.  \\ okay...nvm.

Response: I think there are multiple categories of what the degree means. Assuming we're talking about undergrad, a 4-year degree in any field is a baseline for hiring, so that's important. There's a reputation factor (you went to Emerson?! We've had great experiences with them in the past!). And there's the actual education and experience you received, which I'm sure is different for everyone. Hopefully positive and enriching for most. As for decades to come, that will depend on our ability to maintain all of the factors I just listed.

For a freshmen gen-ed, I can see the value (and duh, philosophy matters in 2014), but his time in LA should be as career-focused as possible. I think it's a silly course to take during the internship program.

Response: All of the above

Innovation for a community-focused institution means housing and developing minds that can revolutionize communication, socialization, and thought in the name of progress. At Emerson, I see talented and innovative minds across the staff/faculty/students, but few innovation hubs dedicated to producing truly new works. I do see an attempt on the part of our academic leaders to develop curricula that force cross-pollination among the concentrations in the name of innovation, but I also see a lot of student resistance to this (since many of them enrolled to study a specific field).
The MFA is an obvious choice. Also free/director-led screenings at the Boston Common Lowes, ArtsEmerson events, stand up comedy at the Wang theater, the Brattle Cinema, Coolidge Corner...

Response: A degree from Emerson today means that you got a focused experience in your field along with a bit of a generalized liberal arts perspective. Six years from now, a college degree may be more focused on the specializations and less on the generalizations. In 2030, the "liberal arts" mentality may be folded down into community/2-year programs that a person does before they go to "real college" where you spend 2-3 years doing specialized training like film.

He's right to worry about it in the sense that if he has the "get the most bang for your buck" mentality, the philosophy class may feel like a waste of time. You could easily take an online class on philosophy from Harvard for free. On the other hand, if the philosophy class opens up his mind a bit and lends him new perspectives on the world, it could lead to more interesting film projects. That's the hope, anyway.

Response: That we try to keep everyone's feelings in mind at all times.

On one hand, it's great to see that Emerson has spent so much time and money improving the local area. We've brought new life to a once not-so-great sector of the city, and helped make it a safer place for everyone. On the other hand, we've encouraged a lot of new development in the area that isn't Emerson College, and it's undoubtedly driving up the cost of living and making it difficult to maintain the cultural identity of Chinatown. Also, Emerson doesn't really open up any facilities for public use, so there's very little the residents of Chinatown can come and do with us.

Response:
Emerson is complicated -- it isn't all one thing. I find a lot of this game to be a little reductive and rah-rah cheering. An Ideal Emerson wouldn't ask "how does emerson help address society's problems" it would ask --- DOES emerson address society's problems.



an Ideal Emerson would support victims of sexual assault and rape, and would restore student rights to the handbook.
Africa

I can't just answer this and pretend like whatever Emerson is doing is some great public service



Tuition                               $36,650



Room & Board                  $15,096



Fees                                 $700

(health insurance not included)



Total                               $52,446



(copied from http://www.emerson.edu/financial-aid/new-undergraduate/tuition-fees)



52,446 dollars. per year. per student. Addressing society's problems? Start at home and do something about that. 



Victoria Snelgrove was shot and killed in 2004 by the Boston Police Dept. We experienced, first-hand what can happen when police use force against citizenry. 



So why, in 2014 after the killing of Michael Brown by police, and the brutal suppression of the residents of Ferguson by an over-zealous, over-militarized, over-empowered Police Force--did Emerson merely hold a discussion, and invite speakers. We should have been present, been visible, supporting them. Upper echelons of Emerson Administration -- joining with other colleges in our consortia and networks, calling congress, appearing on tv, using our vaunted communications and arts skills to DEMAND that these racist, oppressive tactics by police be stopped and the agents and killers be held accountable.



Although these two things are unrelated, they both demonstrate that Emerson is more concerned about addressing Emerson's problems, not societys

Response_ddqual: I'd like it if Emersonians respected the no-smoking rules in front of Emerson buildings. We all have to breathe the same air, and it's already affected by the traffic. Let's not add to that by smoking in entry-ways and directly outside buildings.
replies_ddqual: Maybe there could be some roof-top smoking space opened up? At the same time, I kind of feel like wending one's way through huddled groups of undergrads smoking outside buildings - especially in the dead of winter -  is all part of the college experience. \\ Whoa, rooftop smoking space? If that becomes available I will take up smoking, so help me God.\\ For someone who suffers from severe asthma caused by second hand cigarette smoke, walking by the smokers is the absolute worst part of my Emerson experience. \\ It is very, very unfortunate that Emerson's sidewalks become a smoke tunnel during classes. But I think we are looking at the problem from the wrong angle - we should be encouraging these kids to quit smoking. It's not only lung cancer you have to worry about - smoking depletes your overall quality of life. My friend who is a chemist talked about how the second you ingest nicotine your body immediately attempts to reject it! Let's get something going to help these kids kick this awful habit, save money, and save lives!!!

Response: Well, this question hits home because this was a problem I had to solve for myself. I am a WLP, however, I am very interested in writing for the screen and stage. I'll tell Joanne what I was told: it's difficult switching into the VMA Department - TOO difficult if you ask me. The VMA school is competitive and transferring into it is not easy. I resisted the change and continued as a WLP and have been quite happy. Through student groups, like my comedy troupe and The Emerson Channel, I've gained plenty of experience writing in different mediums. I always figured that WLP was broad enough to learn how to write narratives and characters, however, it was not so specific, like Writing for TV and Film, that might restrict her ability as a writer. Yes, we would all like to write whatever we wish, but if Joanne finds herself in hard times, she may find herself looking for work in public relations or marketing - a reality which she will be better prepared for if she has a strong foundation in written communication and critical reading aka WLP. Also, there are specialty courses inside the WLP Department which are awesome that Joanne can check out.

Response: In my CC 415 Mediation, Facilitation, and Dialogue class three years ago, during a discussion of dialogue as understood by humanistic psychologists, we got to core issues of meaning making....I read aloud a passage from Victor Frankl's Man's Search for Meaning in which he describes surviving forced marches out of the concentration camps by focusing on images of his beloved....our discussion to that point had been mostly rational but the passage hit me hard; tears in my eyes and a bit embarrassed, I looked up to see a room full of people also with teary eyes...we arrived together at some deep meeting place of cognitive learning and affective insight. The ensuing discussion was as rich as any I've experienced. I can take some of the credit as teacher but I know this class (the entire semester) transcended the ordinary because of what this group of students was willing to give.

Response: I think that a college degree from Emerson in 2014 or in the future will depend on what you make of your time in college. While the major is important, it is also about the experiences in college that make you who you are and may set you on a path towards a career. Many of us who graduated from college know that no field stays exactly the same and that you are constantly learning, morphing, experiencing different aspects of your job/career. The things to learn from Emerson are keeping an open mind, learning to work with others, experiencing various opportunities, appreciating that Gen Ed courses may be just as important as "content" courses.

I suppose that Julian will worry as students often worry--am I taking the right courses? does it relate to my major? will my courses help me get an internship? a job? But I think that the "well-rounded" student should be exposed to a variety of courses, thoughts and viewpoints. What better class than philosophy to do this. Hopefully, Julian will see the course for what it is and relax that he hasn't taken a course in his major in senior year. But I appreciate his concern.

Dawn could speak to her coursework and experiences with writing and/or publishing and possibly bring in a portfolio of work completed during undergrad. From a Communication Disorders perspective, Dawn would have had exposure to a number of different communication disorders in a variety of courses including Intro and Survey courses (covering disorders across the lifespan). Response: Charles William Eliot, 19th-century president of Harvard University

As part of my work in the Robbins Speech, Language and Hearing Center, I have helped create low-tech augmentative and alternative communication systems for people with aphasia (an acquired language impairment in adults). These have taken different forms, all tailored to each individual person. Sometimes the AAC system is word based (written) or sometimes it is picture or symbol based. Response: First of all, I want to give a shout out and say I love the picture that you are using for challenge 4. Those are two graduate students from CSD and my colleague, Dr. Joanne Lasker. For the best teaching moment, it was in the Aphasia course that I taught a few years ago. I had 4 adults diagnosed with aphasia speaking to my graduate CSD class regarding what it is like to live with an acquired communication impairment. The students were engaged, surprised, touched, and emotional as each person told his or her "story". Then the students had the opportunity to interact and learn how to communicate with a person diagnosed with aphasia. Students reported "wow" and "Ah-Ha" moments as they saw and heard in real life what it is like to not be able to communicate basic information, say I love you, order coffee, and talk on the phone. As an instructor/teacher, that was a powerful moment for me.

Response_ddqual: I spend most of my time at Emerson in 216 Tremont Street in the Communication Sciences and Disorders Department. My role here is two fold: I am a clinical instructor in our on-site clinic for children and adults who participate in assessment and treatment for a variety of communication disorders. I supervise the graduate students seeking a Master's Degree in CD while they conduct evaluations and provide treatment for adults with acquired neurogenic disorders due to a brain injury. My second role in the department and why  216 Tremont is important to me is that I teach both a clinically oriented course regarding adult disorders and professional issues as well as occasionally teaching an academic course at the graduate level. I love my work with the students and I am passionate about my role in helping those with communication disorders better express themselves in any modality possible, including verbally, through gesture, writing, drawing or a communication device.

We like to talk about innovation and being innovative, but so much of our infrastructure and procedures are dated.  The College needs to invest in ways to make certain processes more efficient and empower people to take risks, even if it means failure at times, so that we can be more cutting edge and proactive.  We shouldn't invest and maintain systems that don't meet the community's needs, or let thinks sit in committees for months before progress is made.  I'm not saying that we shouldn't be strategic and make rash decisions, but we could stand to streamline and improve a lot of what we don't do well in order to provide more opprotunities to innovate.
replies_ddqual: I think what I hear you saying is that perhaps we are trying to do too much or spreading ourselves too thinly?\\ Occasionally, yes, we are doing too much or "competing" against ourselves when there are missed opportunities to collaborate. I would like to know what the College plans to do with the multiple empty business fronts currently along Boylston Street.

Response:
A bachelor's degree from an accredited school is the same degree regardless of where it's from. It's like the old joke, "what do you call the person with the lowest GPA in his graduating med school class? You call him Doctor."



That said, obviously there are certain institutions that hold more weight with certain subjects. One could argue that a Bachelor's from Harvard holds more weight than a Bachelor's from State College of "xyz" for almost any subject. I think the same can be said for film students here. People think of Emerson as a film/film industry school first and foremost, and the power of an Emerson degree in LA is indisputable. That said, it would be nice to think that some of that power could move to the east coast, and create additional film opportunities here. It's sad that our best graduates leave this area after graduation. There should be incentives and opportunities to give weight to their diploma HERE, where the main campus resides.

He's right to consider whether or not he's getting all he can out of his class, but he's not right to think it's a waste of time. You need to learn and experience more than just your own major in order to succeed outside of college. Meet new people, gain new perspectives from a different group of classmates than you're used to.

I joined the Majestic theatre staff when it re-opened after restoration in 2003. I was part of a team of 8 who created it's programming and operations. Response:
I had a student who for whatever reason could not remember to say CUTler Majestic Theatre when she answered the phone. She always said CULter. After trying everything from post-its to repetition, I finally drew puzzle pieces on an 8 1/2 x 11 piece of paper. Inside each piece I wrote "LER". I asked the student to cut out all the pieces to create the puzzle. As she did it, I said, "what are you doing?" She said, "cutting the pieces." I said, "be more specific--what are the pieces you're cutting?" She thought about it for a second and replied, "Ler's". 

"So what are you doing?" 

"Cutting the Ler's." 

"What is the name of the theatre?"

"CUT-LER!"



She never said CULter again. She learned how to think differently and I learned how to come up with a new way to approach a difficult training issue. Plus, it was fun!
replies_ddqual:
Now, THIS is Innovation in teaching and learning!!!!\\ Great story.

\\ Love it! \\ This is so great!\\ Learning can be fun!
