Response_ddqual: Administratively, I feel that slowly over the past year the college as a whole has moved closer to a culture of "yes" as opposed to the culture of "no" that was around for so long. It's refreshing to see departments working together to achieve goals rather than setting up procedures to make it more difficult to get things done. We still have a ways to go, but I feel we're moving in the correct direction...has anyone else noticed this shift?
replies_ddqual: YES! (see what I did there? but also, very seriously and emphatically, YES!)\\ I'd say yes BUT... there's only so much money and time! Sometimes I feel like a dreamkiller when I say that I can't work on/support someone's favorite idea. We try to stay faithful to the mission - but sometimes that means hard choices and saying no so that we can say yes to other things.

Response_ddqual: I feel like it's important to empower student employees with actual responsibility and professional experience. We are preparing these students for the real world, not just academically, but in the workforce. It drives me crazy when I hear someone say, "No, don't give that to a student to do", or even worse, "they're just a student". Let's stop making excuses for our employees just because they're young and they attend classes. If we give them realistic goals and deadlines and trust them with important tasks, I guarantee that in most cases, they'll meet or surpass expectations. If there's one thing I've learned in both teaching and managing, it's that if you don't expect much from someone, you won't get much. Don't lower standards based on what you *think* someone is capable of achieving; instead, teach and set goals at the highest level you hope for, and give your students/staff a chance to rise to success. Our student employees need to be more than just filers, copiers and runners.
replies_ddqual:
I couldn't agree more! Our student workers are seeking professional development, challenge, want to engage and empower in meaningful ways! It is so great to see supervisors like you giving them the time, attention, support and trust to contribute. Way to model the way!\\ Totally agree.  At the Library our work study staff are often the people who are most involved in day to day operations and service. They are the face of the library.  We're very fortunate to have an excellent student staff.\\ I feel that in the Campus Center, both at the info desk and the Cabaret, we are given projects to develop our skills in a professional atmosphere. And I love that opportunity! 



It is a realistic expectation of students to meet high deadlines; if a situation occurs then there is always an option to talk with the supervisor. But by setting higher standards it encourages growth, learning, and exploration of the task. Which should be an awesome motivator!\\ I agree and always try to impart some practical employment and business advice along the way.  While I don't have time to teach fully, I do let student workers watch my as I do a mail merge with Word and Excel and ask questions.  This is a basic business function and most undergraduates don't know about he process.  This is just one example.

"Please separate these papers into AR (accounts receivable - including an explanation of what the is) POs (purchase orders - again with a short explanation) and Perkins loan files (again w/exploitation.)" It doesn't take much longer to explain t the student worker WHY they are doing something, not just how and what to do.\\ I'm with Christina!

Response:
This is a tough one. There are definitely some visuals that come to mind  - students dressed up and cheering on move-in day, the Lady Ga-Ga video which was one of the first things that I saw when I was researching Emerson for my job interview 3+ years ago, the Ron Burgundy School of Communication press conference.



I love all of those visuals and those are things that I often use to brag about Emerson to friends and family who are not familiar with it. However, the most meaningful part of my Emerson experience is the work that my colleagues and I do to make teaching and learning more accessible and efficient. Two stories/examples come to mind:



ITG, Media Services, Iwasaki Library, and IT worked together to design and build a Fair Use tool to help faculty assess whether the materials they are using meet fair use guidelines: fairuse.emerson.edu



ITG, Disability Services, and IT worked together to ensure that students with hearing disabilities were able to view course video with closed captioning. Our system architect integrated Median with Amara, a crowd-sourcing captioning software, so that Median videos can also be captioned if need be. We have also worked together to ensure that all video for online courses have closed captioning from the get-go.
Africa

Emerson is doing some very concrete things to address issues related to communication. The Robbins Center is one example where we are using Emerson's talents to help  people. This Community Planit game is another example of Emerson helping communities to communicate about issues that are important to them. We are also taking steps to reduce our environmental impact.



I'd like to see us continue to do more with regards to sustainability just because it is such an important issue. We need to keep active on this! I'm really glad that we now have single stream recycling. Maybe there could be a more concerted effort across majors/courses to make part of teaching and learning? I think there are lots of ways that those in communication and the arts can help out in this area.

Well, I'm not an Emerson alum so I'm not really sure how complicated that would be. Hopefully since Joanne is still a sophomore, this should not be a big deal but it may also depend on how competitive the respective programs are to begin with. (I hear VMA is comeptitive.)



That said, as someone who majored in International Relations in undergrad, worked in public television for 10 years, and now works in IT, I would encourage Joanne not to stress about it. Your major in college does not necessarily dictate your career path. Actually, it often does not. Think about the skills that you have that are transferable. You are a writing major and you want to go in to television writing. You will have a great foundation in writing and I think that is what is most important. I bet you could even work your WLP major to your advantage and come up with your own unique style for television writing. 



Anyways, don't stress it. Enjoy your classes and take courses that interest you when you can. You never know when those passions will come into play in your career path.

Response: Thom Mayne

Emerson is currently perceived as a leading institution of higher education in its specialty fields, and as an institution that integrates that specialized education with a liberal arts education.  I'd like to see that reputation sustained and enhanced across the country and around the world, to know that there is a general understanding not only of the fact that an Emerson education is a rich combination of disciplinary and liberal arts education, but also that there is an understanding of our commitment to being an innovative, forward looking and global institution committed to the civic good.
Emerson.edu is a go-to resource, Steady stream of international artists, communications experts, and scholars visting our camupus, Higher percentage of international students, faculty and staff
Response_ddqual: I chose three from the list, but really could have chose all of the options listed.  On reflection, I'd also add a couple:  that Emerson faculty, students and staff are out and about in the world, on behalf of the college, with regularity, and that Emerson has an online educational presence that attracts people around the world (a version of Emerson.edu being a go-to resource, perhaps).

Response: Emerson is remarkable to me because of the intertwining of people, place, expertise and values.  By that I mean that the Emerson community always impresses me in its capacity to work together--as a community--toward a shared set of goals even a individuals speak their minds and make a difference by doing so.  We are are urban institution, and there is a palpable energy that comes with that location (and we, without doubt, contribute to it as well).  And our focus on arts, communication and liberal arts lets us channel our energy and ability, be strategic, and so be effective in what we do.
Africa

Emerson is engaging very substantively with the cities of Boston and Los Angeles in various ways, and I think that local civic engagement is something to continue.  Precisely how we engage is and should be determined in conversation with those communities, and should also play to our strengths.  When I say that I'm thinking of such programs as emersonWrites, which brings high schools students to Emerson for writing workshops.  I could envision us continuing to develop educational opportunities for young people prior to college.--I could also envision us working with community-based organizations in ways that use our strengths (in marketing, for example, or film making or narrative) to help them reach their goals. -- Beyond that, and from a somewhat different angle, I think that as a college we are in the business of contributing to knowledge about--and discussion of--significant public issues.  We do this now and I hope will continue to do so, though a variety of channels.

Response_ddqual: This is a tough call, since there are many places in which I'd like to spend time with an eye to enriching my professional competencies and experience.  I initially chose the south of France (Aix and environs) both for personal and professional reasons (there are many opportunities for students to study there and I'd like to know more about them).  But then I changed my mind, and chose Istanbul, in Turkey, for many reasons: because it is poised between Europe and Asia, because its modern culture and cultural history are dense and rich, because understanding how Emerson's fields of expertise--arts, communication, liberal arts--take form there would teach me, and us, a great deal.

Response: We are already known for educating students to a high degree of expertise in the arts, communication and liberal arts, in an environment that is highly creative, and that will continue to be the case.  That said, I think an Emerson degree will be even more widely known as a guarantee of a richly imagined and rigorous education, as the hallmark of an education that integrates liberal arts and professional training in especially resonant ways, and for our intentional engagement with the communities in which we participate, local and global.

I don't think he needs to worry about it, but I would say that he's right to think it.  In thinking through the value of his philosophy class (or any class) he will articulate what might otherwise remain unsaid.  In this case, that would include the fact that philosophy helps us think about the first principles by which we organize our lives and find meaning in the world, and more informed and agile he can be in dealing with such questions, the more he will see their relevance for everything he does, from editing a film (why include one detail and not another) to figuring out how he wants to balance his work with the rest of his life, and how he wants his career--and his life--to develop voer time.
Yes
Response_ddqual: I am a staff member, and in my work at Emerson have had (and continue to have) opportunities to engage with people from around the globe both on campus and off, so I've learned through experience.  There are also good professional development opportunities on campus to learn what one needs to know to thrive in a globalized world - everything from a deepened base of essential knowledge about the world to intercultural skills to understanding the practical matters that come up when one travels or welcomes  people to Boston.

Response:
Creativity and cultural development ... a multi-disciplinary major that brings together work in cultural studies, arts administration (policy, economics, etc.) urban and civic development, and creativity studies (itself multi-disciplinary, drawing from fields that include neurobiology, psychology and sociology).



Such a major will address an ongoing need in many cities - how to ensure that they are the vibrant, livable spaces that the arts help to create - build on our existing strength in arts and communication, and our ever more sophisticated understanding of how these fields intersect with the work of planners, policy makers and business people.  Further it will be characterized by what is and I hope will continue to be an Emerson hallmark:  bringing theory and practice together.

2025 isn't very far away at all!  That's just 10 years from now.  What will have changed?  The face to face learning experience will be as or more intense than it is now, because my professors and I will both be more adept at using various forms of technology to prepare for our time on campus together.   Work that I do on my own can be submitted ahead of time online (even videos of performance, though I know that it won't be the same as face to face work) and evaluated ahead of time.  Time on campus will then be more about co-creating knowledge (as opposed to a teaching and learning model focused primarily on transmission of knowledge), more about working together on what are the edges of my own learning and that of my peers, and on the edges of the field I'm in.

In Dawn's place, I would say that my arts-related courses -- among which I'd include many of the courses I took in WLP, especially the creative writing courses -- helped me develop my ability to think with subtlety and express myself with clarity.  They have given me appreciation for a wide range of human experience -- the novels I read, the stories I wrote were all about trying to think through the eyes of other people.  And those skills will serve me well in the world of marketing, in which understanding one's audience and communicating effectively with it is paramount.
Something else entirely
Response_ddqual: Emerson is a college that educates students in the liberal arts and in the arts / communications disciplines that will be their professional focus.  This is a potent integration of two forms of education, each of which can stand on its own.  Together, they are more than the sum of the parts - they come together in what to me is a powerful form of education for the 21st century.

Response: It means alot to me - that we think in terms larger than ourselves alone and that we are specific when we do that.   So if we do something on our campus, we think about its impact on the community around us .  And If we see a problem in our local community, or even in the global community, we think about whether and how it is ours to respond to.  No college can do everything, but we want to use the resources we have - our material resources, our power as a creative community and a community of thinkers, to engage with issues that matter. -- I'd also say that being socially responsible isn't only about responding to problems - it's about looking around us and thinking about how to contribute meaningfully to the world, anticipating need and finding ways to address it. -- Finally, I'm very conscious that we are a community of learners and teachers, and each of us arguably occupies each role at one time or another.  The teaching/learning dynamic is a powerful lever for change, and will help shape what we are able to contribute to the larger society.
Elma Lewis School of Fine Arts

Response: It's hard to name specific organizations!  I can name organizational types more easily.  I'd love to see us partner with colleges more (not quite what this question is getting at but this kind of connection can be valuable, and we do have some).   I'd also love to see us partner with places that support entrepreneurialism (we do some of this too); with high schools (we do some of this) and with organizations that support young people; I could keep going but that's a start.
All of the above

Innovation means doing new things and re-imagining familiar ones, finding ways to do things differently, and it's everywhere at Emerson.  I see it in boldness of vision that helped shape things that are new on campus:  the Emerson Accelerator, the Elma Lewis Center, ArtsEmerson (not so entirely new anymore).  I also see it in the history of what the college has done:  in moving from Back Bay to the Theater District, for example. And in things like the President's Fund for Curricular Innovation and the work it produces, also in the work of individual staff, faculty and students.  --When I think about innovation in terms of Emerson's relationship to our surrounding community, I think of ways in which we contribute to and benefit from the city's entrepreneurial energy, and of ways in which we can engage as partners with individuals and organizations for the benefit of all.  As education comes to be more and more about what some have described as the co-creation of knowledge, I think about how Emerson can co-create--knowledge, art, community, more--with the city of Boston.
replies_ddqual: Nice. Let's put this in our constitution.

I'm in restaurants a lot too!  I also spend a lot of time walking, getting to know the city, and love the Common, the park on Comm Ave, the Public Garden.  -- I live in Cambridge, so spend time outside there too - walking through Cambridge, along the Charles, in Mt. Auburn Cemetery, which is a wonderful place. I've also spent time wandering parts of the city that I don't live in - that's always a pleasure.

Response_ddqual: This is a tough call.  I chose 180 Tremont because it combines classrooms, department offices and administrative offices, also because it's roughly half way between the Paramount and Piano Row (and I work there, so for me it really is a, or the, center).  If I'd chosen Summer St. and Piano Row as the two most distant points, I might have landed on the Paramount as the geographical center, but I was thinking in terms of more than just geography.  And if I'd left geography out entirely, then I might have landed on 120 Boylston, or Walker 10, or Piano Row ... maybe we don't have a center so much as we have hubs of activities, or nodes of connectivity ...

I don't know about Ithaca College, but Ken's sense of Emerson as a college situated in a vibrant community is certainly right.  I'd tell him about the enormous creative energy of Emerson, about the strength of a curriculum that weaves together a liberal arts tradition with deep learning in specialized disciplines, and also about our strength in educating students in ways that bridge theory and practice, the world of college and the world outside it.  I'd also tell him that Emerson is a college that is deeply committed to its local and global communities.  And I'd tell him that this is an innovative place, a place that will give him the chance to set big goals for himself and realize those goals.

Response: Common Ground

Joanna will be changing her department, from WLP to VMA.  I don't speak with great authority here, since I'm neither a faculty member nor a student, but I know that VMA is a large and popular department, so it could be tricky for her to make this move.  If she can make it, great.  If not, WLP will without doubt help her become the strongest writer she can be, and with good advising, I would think that she could also find ways to get instruction in the particular art of writing for television.

I've spent my career in higher education, but hadn't worked on a college campus for over a decade, and I wanted to do that.  I chose Emerson because it is such a generative, forward-looking institution and I've been able to grow in many ways here:  risk-taking is very possible, perhaps even necessary if one is to achieve results quickly, and we want to!  Learning how to do strategic planning has probably been the most transformative thing I've done.  It can sound very abstract and bureaucratic, but it also provides an opportunity for work that is highly imaginative and ambitious.  I've learned a huge amount through my involvement with strategic planning at Emerson, and this very game of Emerson UnCommon comes (in part) from that learning, and also contributes to it.

Response_ddqual: I'm lucky because I get to work with people across campus almost every day. And what I learn varies a lot - new things about Emerson, about people's areas of expertise, and also about how best to get things done.  I learn a lot about moving from theory to practice, which is--after all--a distinctive Emersonian capacity!

Response: My best learning moment at Emerson .... there have been many, but one that stands out is working with the steering group when we applied for Carnegie Foundation's Community Engagement classification.  We'll hear in December whether we get the classification or not, but either way, the process of applying was great.  It was highly collaborative, people were deeply committed to it, and the application that we put together was much stronger than anything that any one or two of us could have done on our own.  It was also a lot of fun, and gave me a chance to get to know people better - that's always a benefit of this kind of process.

While this description makes getting these things sound easy, she might not know that she can ask for them or feel that she should, so some good orientation to the college that makes clear how welcome her inquiries would be will be important.

Response: I think Emerson would do well to offer a degree in Information Technology. It sounds may sound kind of out of left field but I think with the shift towards the internet as a primary method of communicating and distributing news, media, and advertising it would be wise for the school to offer courses about how this new medium actually works. I think that the classes that would be added as a result would help not only people majoring in the technology of communication through computers but those whose work may involve computers in any way, which I think will be everyone.

I think in 2025 technology will dramatically alter what is taught at Emerson more than how it is taught. I believe that as a school focused on communication we're in for a turbulent half century as the information age continues to completely disrupt the way communication has been conducted up to this point. More and more immediate response is a part of not only direct interpersonal communication but advertising and even art. Already we begin to see interactive ads online as well as ads tailored by viewing habits, interactive art and storytelling in video games, and the addition of interactive elements in things like television programming through services tailoring programming suggestions to viewers.



I think that changing technology is less likely to create challenges than the rapidly changing ways we utilize technology, much of which already exists in some form basic or complex, on campus already.
replies_ddqual: But the TV studios will still be SD

Response:
Arts related courses allow for communication of ideas in ways that are unexpected and unique. They create a background with different communication techniques that allow for flexibility in the ways and channels in and through which a message may be communicated.  They help to discern what channels and techniques are most effective for what audience and they help to encourage considering solutions that may not be obvious to others. 



Students with a background in art criticism for example, may better be able to understand causes of a successful or unsuccessful marketing campaign based on aesthetics and communication techniques used in the campaign.
Conservatory
Response_ddqual: Emerson College is at it's best a school dedicated to the study of Communication. Each student specializes in a very specific and intense method of communication that they've chosen for their own reasons and utilize towards their own ends. Some communicate by acting, some by writing, and some by newer media. Emerson is a school that is most beneficial to students who want to communicate something or who want to facilitate communication for others. Actors communicate emotions and dialogue written by screenwriters and playwrights. Film students write scripts or assist in shooting to communicate their own idea or the idea of someone else. Marketing majors communicate ideas to promote products. Comm disorders students help others to communicate who may otherwise have difficulty. Emerson is a unique institution. It's conservatory of Communication and expression of ideas. Expression IS Necessary to Evolution and Emerson is at its best when enabling and encouraging expression.

As an RA I can't say that it is a difficult or easy process, since it is different for everyone. That being said if she wishes to change her course of study I would first suggest trying to take classes in that area to see if it is truly something that she is interested in. If she does enjoy it, or already has her heart set on changing her course of study I would suggest talking with Academic Advising and her advisor to begin that process.

I think that becoming an RA has had a profound impact on my life and my Emerson experience as a whole. No opportunity has afforded me the ability to meet and work with as many diverse individuals outside of my area of study quite like working as an RA has. I believe that my environment is very conductive towards taking risks, I do worry however that not everyone feels this way. One of the largest risk taking opportunities that I had (in a classroom setting) while at Emerson came from Dimensions of Creativity, a pass/fail course only offered for a limited time. Since it was pass/fail the professors encouraged taking risks and as students we weren't afraid of failing so long as it was apparent we had put the effort in.

Response_ddqual: Anyone else think the college is in desperate need for a new open performance space? The Cabaret is constantly booked and is small, the Green and Semel are not free or open, and just forget about anything EmStage/ArtsEmerson uses.
replies_ddqual: Even if it's just that the Green and the Semel are opened up to the community, Emerson needs to create more space. We are short on rehearsal space, performance space, and space to hold events. With all of the organizations and activities that Emersonians participate in, we should have more space where they can promote what they are passionate about.\\ Also, it would be great to have a larger gallery space, with state of the art lighting and climate control.\\ As a new student, it always sort of confused me that we had this beautiful theatre (the Cutler) that was outsourced to outside theatre companies and we could only use for orientation and the Evvys while campus groups fought tooth and nail for performance spaces. We also need more (or bigger) rehearsal spaces, because booking space can get pretty cutthroat within the different dance and theatre companies, especially. There are a lot of small piano and voice spaces, or classroom-type spaces in the campus center for meetings, but for organizations that need a lot of real estate to rehearse, they're sort of out of luck a lot of the time.

Response_ddqual: This is tough. If I knew where I would find the best professional development opportunities, I'd be reaching out already. For now, I reach out to staff at other colleges in the area and across the country to discover their best practices.

Response: I would hope that an Emerson degree is valued as much as it is today for the well prepared graduates it produces who come with amazing (and often multiple) real-world experience in the form of internships, but also for the reputation students have gained for being well prepared all around, with a solid liberal arts foundation where a philosophy course informs a film project; where the Chinese language skills learned junior and senior year will help students reach a global audience; and where Emerson still equals quality in the arts and communication fields.

I've heard students say this very thing, but I'd reassure Julian, like I reassure them, that what he's learning matters. He may not see the explicit connections yet, but every piece of information he acquires will influence him as a student, human, and citizen. He won't be passionate about everything he learns, but some of that knowledge will sneak into his film work, and he'll be glad he had the experience. Plus, that student sitting next to him will probably be a key partner in his next film project.
Some but not all
Response_ddqual: I feel we're engaging in the global world, but I wouldn't say I feel like an expert yet in how to navigate that world.

Response: The Art of Conversation: How to Talk to Your Fellow Human Beings. This course (potentially a major) will be a required Gen Ed, because if we don't know how to talk to each other today, we certainly won't know how to engage in 20 years when my robot communicates with your robot. Courses will teach conversation and listening skills as well as proper email etiquette.

While we all need to embrace technology for its marvels and the innovation it offers, I hope it doesn't change the way faculty and staff interact with students. Having a one-on-one conversation and meeting in a physical classroom are still important. We connect with students in a way that technology can't always replicate.

Art-related courses were integral to my education and prepared me to be a well-rounded person. I not only know about marketing but how design influences consumers' decisions. I know how to collaborate effectively with a team to build something, whether it's an art piece or a marketing campaign. My arts-related courses honed my appreciation for art, music, and literature--all elements that will contribute unique strengths to this Marketing Assistant position. I bring a lot of hidden talents.
Liberal arts college
Response_ddqual: This is tricky. Clearly we have a strong liberal arts core but we also have an arts and communication driven focus. While Emerson is not what I'd consider a typical art school, it does have several elements of one: writing workshops, acting classes, filmmakers, hipsters-in-the-making... It's important to have both: artists cannot pursue their art in a bubble without having a solid liberal arts foundation.

Response: Piano Row

I'd suggest Amira start by contacting the Office of Service Learning and Community Action or the Elma Lewis Center for Civic Engagement. But if those don't offer the perfect fit, she could strike out on her own and look into Boston Cares or browse Idealist or another volunteer site that matches preferred activities and availability. Better yet, strike up a conversation with other students or ask a faculty or staff for input. When English isn't your native language (and even for students who are just shy), an email is often less intimidating than a phone call or visit. She could even visit the Writing and Academic Resource Center to practice her English conversation skills or to get help crafting an email to the organization where she hopes to volunteer.

Response: Two of the biggest challenges in the city are in the realm of education and homelessness. Emerson is helping to meet the educational needs of Boston's students through Jump Start and other after school tutoring programs. Can we do more? I think we still have a partnership with St. Francis House around the corner, though I suspect we could do more there too. Boston Cares is a great organization that needs volunteers and the best part is that long-term commitments aren't needed: perfect for students who have an occasional night or weekend to volunteer.

Response: I'm a staff, but I'm also an alum of the graduate Publishing & Writing program and one of my best learning moments was as a student in a nonfiction memoir workshop. The class was workshopping my submission when my classmate blurted out some harsh feedback: "This is so cliche!" among other things. The other students were stunned silent and the professor apologized to me after class for the criticism. Except...that student (who admitted later that she had had a rough day and might have phrased her feedback in a kinder way) was the only one who spoke the truth that day and had the guts to say it. The fact was, the theme of my piece WAS cliche and my revision was stronger for hearing her honest, critical feedback.

students share their passions about their field and succeed!

Boston is the College City of America, and Emerson certainly is a major proponent of the "college vibe" of this city.  If you're seeking an institution that will push you to your limits academically, Emerson isn't for you.  But if you're seeking a community of like-minded, innovative, passionate individuals who are consumed by the desire to create together, then you've found the right place.

Response: The President's Room

Unfortunately, switching majors in the School of the Arts is nearly impossible.  But thanks to the IDIP program, you can add film classes to your writing curriculum and craft the course of study that will best serve your professional goals.  And at the end of the day, your undergraduate degree does not automatically place you in a profession for the rest of your life - you might be surprised as to how few television screenwriters studied just that in their undergraduate program!

The biggest difference between Paul now and Paul then is that I don't beat myself up over failure.  This change has come through failing, losing things and people close to me.  Through and through, I'm still standing.  So taking risks and putting myself on the line doesn't scare me as much anymore.  Because I live with less fear of failure, I generally enjoy life that much more.

Almost everyday
Response_ddqual: You can't go three seconds at Emerson without learning something new, be it a life lesson from a professor or helpful tips from your classmates.  There is a wealth of knowledge being shared at this College, and to discover this, you need only listen in on a conversation at Einstein Bros (formerly Emerson's Cafe) or in the library.

Response: Our faculty in the Performing Arts department is top-notch, the best in their respective fields - but at the end of the day, there is no better way to learn theatre than by doing.  That is where Emerson excels: it gives students many opportunities to learn by experience (oft lauded as "the greatest teacher of them all.")  My biggest learning (and teaching) moments have been in working on plays here at Emerson.  I have acted in, directed, and produced over twenty different projects in three years at this College, and I could write a book filled with the lessons each project taught me.  But perhaps the biggest overarching lesson I have learned from my work at Emerson College comes from the breadth of projects that I have worked on.  The times that I was the happiest were the times in which I was working on projects that I was passionate about.  Not simply doing a show to improve my standing in the theatre hierarchy at Emerson, but doing something simply because I loved it.  I have done too many shows that were favors for others or attempts to bolster my standing with a certain organization.  Do the work that makes you happy - life (especially your life at Emerson) is too short to do anything else.
replies_ddqual: Wonderful that it's worked out so well for you! Great advice!

Response: The primary communal & meeting place for Emerson students at the College's Back Bay campus (130 Beacon Street)

Arriving at Emerson for your first year of college can be overwhelming to even the most prepared new students.  We are a small school full of very ambitious creators, and so everyone starts hounding you from Day 1 to get involved with their student org or to take a crew position on their Film II.  At the end of the day, you are your own best resource for navigating this crazy communication college.  Know your interests, dream of goals, both short-term at Emerson and long-term beyond your four years here.  There is someone on campus who can help you explore those passions and lead you towards fulfillment of those goals.  To connect you with that person or persons, there are a plethora of resources - be it your floormates, classmates, RA, Academic Advisor, Student Life, or the head of your department, there are many people here who will do their best to guide you toward success here at Emerson.  Even if you're totally lost, you already belong to a community in your Residence Hall, so take advantage of your RA - they can be an excellent first resource.
replies_ddqual: Great response!

Response: I am most excited about being part of the Emerson Community when the community comes together to create something larger than the sum of its parts.  Whether that be the performing arts department coming together to put on a phenomenal Emerson Stage production, working with my fraternity brothers to participate in community service across the Boston area, or coming together in the wake of a city-wide tragedy such as the Boston Marathon bombings, it is the sense of collaboration and teamwork that makes me a proud member of the Emerson community.

I have made so many memories in each of the 9 rehearsal studios in Paramount, and many more to come this semester.

These types of areas are extremely rare to find at Emerson especially for off-campus students.  Students often sit in hallways and eat over garbage cans. My best learning moment at Emerson was when I was learning to create a web site in Coldfusion. I had worked with Bill Lynch, the other programmer/analyst on a project but it had been a while since Bill had explained the basics to me.  I had a new project but had no idea how to get started.

I told Bill of my difficulty and he mapped the logic of the entire project for me and explained step by step how the pages would interact with each other. He also indicated which pages he had created in other projects that I could use as a templates for the site I was creating.  Bill was always generous in sharing pages and explaining concepts that I was unclear about.

Response: I honestly think it means less than ever, not because it isn't important, but because there are several other factors to determine its value. A degree may be a prerequisite for many professional fields, but with the low supply of jobs and the ever increasing demand from highly qualified applicants, this fact has faded in importance. I think that if an emphasis on entrepreneurship and Freelance work is attained from a degree, than it's value would be much increased, because it would aid in its application even when typical job positions are scarce.

Response: No he is not right at all...philosophical understanding underpins all aspects of life and certainly all forms of effective communication no matter the medium. Technical skills are great, but unless you have the substance from which to apply those skills into projects that touch on the humanity we share, you will lose your audience. Whether you're making a comedy or a drama, in knowing the human condition (your audience!) is essential.
Some but not all
Response_ddqual: I think that Emerson both thrives and lacks in its preparation for global success. While I was happy that Emerson didn't make me take more foreign language classes (went through 7 years of French, 3 years of Spanish, and 2 years of Latin... and I don't remember hardly any of it despite doing very well in the classes), I think there needs to be a greater foundation in foreign culture literacy for those that wish to go in those directions in the future. However, in all of my Interdisciplinary classes the emphasis on de-"othering" was very apparent and successfully communicated.

Response: INTRApersonal Communication... one of the biggest glaring lacks within higher education is self learning and understanding. While having the specialized skills to communicate with others is extremely important, without a base of self understanding and actualization all experiences will inevitably be filtered though the converse, misunderstanding and unfulfillment. These practitioners of Interpersonal Communication could aid others in the process of understanding the relationships they have with their mental, emotional, physical, and social selves. This type of major would bring together the disciplines of psychology, sociology, philosophy, writing, neurology, etc. in order to help students/future practitioners understand the self-communication loops within the body, mind, and spirit.

I feel like as technology and culture together advance, our rigid structures that have dictated our methods of learning will slowly fall away. Lectures have already statistically proven to be ineffective methods of deeper learning. Classes would evolved to be oriented towards kinesthetic learners, auditory learners, and visual learners...all of which would be more experientially based (social experiments and life assignments used as a method of theory driven practice) than surface level (memorizing facts to regurgitate). While technology could certainly facilitate those means of true conceptual absorption, I feel like a lot of the technology used in the classroom can distract rather than engage.
replies_ddqual: Love the idea of more experiential learning. And yes, agree completely that technology can distract, rather than engage.  Put those damn phones away in class!!!!

Response: During a student presentation on Kant's Observations on the Beautiful and Sublime (where he sets the ground for the Romantic conception of the sublime as an aesthetic standard that has transformative potential because it's so awesome), the student dutifully noted the different forms of the sublime and how Kant connected it to other, sometimes crazy, ideals. She then proceeded to change the class discussion of Kant's essay on the sublime into a discussion of the "three wolf moon" t-shirt that because popular a few years ago. It was a funny and silly moment, but it also brought home in very keen and ironic ways the aesthetic categories that Kant was trying to outline. It was, in many ways, a very #soemerson moment as it brought together pop culture, intellectual rigor, and humor in a really effective and enlightening moment that everyone enjoyed and really got something out of.

This is tough, but I'd say that in the most general sense she needs to find her people, the folks that become like family--an academic, intellectual, and emotionally supportive community (or communities). This can be faculty, other students, members of student orgs, staff in one of the student services offices, librarians, someone or some group off-campus involved in the community or anybody. Find a Professor who teaches the kinds of courses that excite you; find a student org where you might want to be part of the leadership in two years; find a space (on campus, in the BPL, in Chinatown, anywhere) that you and your friends make your own space.

Response: Charles Wesley Emerson, founder of Emerson College

NOTE: Planit won't let me upload a Word file for the project mentioned.



For a Public Affairs course taught by Alex Goldstein, a longtime communications advisor to Governor Deval Patrick and now a  consultant, we had an assignment where you were asked to choose an issue or candidate you were interested in, evaluate media coverage on that topic, and build a case for "Who Won the Month".



In the  paper, titled "Red State Republicans vs. Abortion Rights", my analysis is summed up in the introduction:   "Where abortion and reproductive rights are concerned, Red State Republicans are waging a devastating, long-term offensive against choice and contraception, and theyre winning in almost every place that counts: in state legislatures and governorships, in the courts, and in the media, where the massive scale and success of their assault is largely unrecognized, except by those who follow the issue closely.  If we were scoring wins and losses this month, wed score it 95% to 5% for the Red State Republicans."
Almost everyday
Response_ddqual:
In every class, all my readings and in every project I'm learning new things about communication in general and my area of focus, political communication in particular. So far all my teachers are very competent, well-organized and articulate - and most assignments are totally absorbing.



 One of my favorite assignments during Spring 2013 semester was to analyze how the "Bridgegate" scandal in New Jersey was affecting Chris Christie's presidential ambitions and to assess whether his aspirations for 2016 would be wiped out by the drumbeat of scandal.
replies_ddqual: The "Bridgegate" assignment sounds awesome. And so topical!

Response:
In my Political Discourse class I was one of 4 people  assigned to a 2 vs. 2 debate on whether George Zimmerman's acquittal of all charges in the shooting of Trayvon Martin was a just result. I chose the Negative side of the argument, asserting the verdict was not just. 



I was confident that my partner and I could easily prove our case, but after carefully examining a large body of evidence and media reports, I realized it was much more difficult than I had thought to build an airtight argument that could not be easily knocked down by our very competent opponents. We had to put ourselves in their shoes and anticipate their strongest arguments and then "innoculate" ourselves against them. We worked very hard on our "line of argument" and on polishing the oral presentation and ensuring we came in under the designated time limits.



Happily, the class voted, by a margin of 15-5,  that we had won the debate.

Response: I am Assistant Director of Academic Advising AND a full-time Media Art MFA student, so I feel like every single day is my "most Emerson" experience. I tripped over my own feet on camera in my production class and then stumbled over my chair in Subway as I tried to catch up with Matt Finn of Academic Affairs, who was also cramming in a late lunch. This is a real day-in-the-life: being insanely busy is an Emerson trademark.

While there hasn't been much change between who I was before I came to Emerson and who I am now, I find that I have had to use a lot of my previous experiences in order to serve the needs of the College.  Every day brings new challenges that require creative ways to resolve the situation or taking a gamble in order to make something new happen.
replies_ddqual: Part of learning a new place is taking risks, as well as learning how much risk a person can take, what the environment tolerates.  It is a challenge, a struggle, and ultimately, hopefully, all worth it.\\ Emerson rewards risk-takers!  Well, if you think a reward is being invited to take more risks. . . but that's how innovation happens, balancing the risks, the failures and the successes.\\ I think the hard, and unfortunate, in my opinion, lesson is learning, as Robert A says, "how much risk . . . the environment tolerates."  As much as the Emerson community lauds innovation and creativity, I've found there are barriers to taking the risks associated with going beyond the usual. These barriers are not articulated, but I believe they include rigidity and hierarchy of roles, unwillingness to appear "not busy enough" and so able to take on "extra work", and fear of public embarrassment, even on an institutional level.

Response: Someone once told me that if an employer receives two identical resumes - one from Emerson, one not from Emerson - and they are equal in every other way, the employer will choose the Emerson grad. (This was an LA student repeating what her boss told her). It's about who you know, but it's also about the choice that we all made to come to Emerson. Coming to Emerson shows that you're serious about whatever major/career path you've chosen.

This hits close to home, because I took a philosophy course (to fulfill my Ethics requirement) and I'm going to LA next semester! I absolutely LOVED my Narrative Ethics course with Robb Eason. I think it was the most "liberal arts college-y" course I've had here. Sometimes, our elective courses have nothing to do with our chosen careers. We wind up taking supposedly "throwaway" courses to get credits or fulfill requirements, choosing whatever can fill our schedule. Narrative Ethics probably won't help me get a job in post-production, but now I can have an intelligent conversation about the Ring of Gyges or the "people-seeds" abortion theory. It can be hard to balance our liberal arts courses with our more technical courses, but we shouldn't think of them as any less important.
Some but not all
Response_ddqual: I feel like I've developed a lot of technical, practical skills here at Emerson, but I put a lot of value in the experiences I've had working with people. I've been an assistant, a team leader, a co-producer, a stage manager, a supervisor....everyone learns differently, and I think knowing how to work with different types of people is an incredibly valuable skill for any career.

I hope that Emerson continues to stay up to date with both software and hardware so that we can be prepared to use the same equipment once we enter the industry,

I think that all Emerson College courses have a creative element. "Creative" can be taken in the artistic sense, like making videos, collages, plays, and other artistic pieces are classwork, or it can be taken in a "critical thinking" sense. Emerson students are encouraged to think outside the box - there is always more than one way to approach an issue - and I think that is a valuable skill for any industry.

Response: Liberal arts college
Response_ddqual:
To society, I strongly believed that we are looked as a Liberal Arts college or an Art School. While some may view this as negative, I look at it in a very positive way. Liberal teaching allows us to appreciate, argue for, and construct our own opinions after being presented an objective view for which we are often told to look at all sides of a piece of work or critique.

Of course, Emerson is unlike many other colleges. Our organizations and leadership within our community is extremely unique to our school. It's something I take pride in, and I know that other students do as well. We feel ownership over our ideas, collaborations and our creations, but are often more than willing to bring other enthusiastic, talented people on board to share our own personal experiences with.

Response: All of the above

Innovation is growth by active choice. Innovation is updating, evolving and growing with the community that is around us. Whenever we update or renovate our school, that is a form of innovation. Adding additional classes so we can meet the demand of student requirements is a form of innovation. Making sure needs are met and then expanding upon how to better suit those needs means that active effort is needed. People need to speak up about issues that bug them or things they would like to see change for innovation to happen.

The MBTA makes so many things possible. As much as I dislike the green line sometimes, the fact that every aspect of the city is within reach is wonderful. 



I tend to explore areas that my friends and I live around. Other times, I will reach out to a few people and do something that may be a little more expensive than the typical fun day. I try to do a little bit of everything when I can.

Response_ddqual:
As big as Emerson College has expanded to be, I always believe that I will consider the Boston campus of Emerson College to be the "center of campus." Travel abroad programs are very much Emersonian places where Emerson students wander and share their ideas, but our origins were all founded in Boston. 



As for boundaries within the Boston campus, it's very interesting. Students live just as much throughout Boston as they do on campus. Still though, I feel a separation of work and school when I go home to my off-campus apartment (which I consider to be a nice thing). So there is definitely an attachment that where I learn and where I eat when I learn and participate is where I associate for a campus to be. So basically, any place that I have gone with a class or have been to due to "Emerson" reasons I associate with our campus.

As an off-campus student I spend a lot of time in the library. Especially the study rooms where I can have complete quiet and concentration for my studies. I feel like there aren't many places for off-campus students to roam to when they are on campus. Because many of us have organizations at night, it isn't worth commuting twice. We would rather stay on campus and have a place to reheat food, relax, study, chat. It would be nice if all of these places would be separate and more diverse rather than encompassing them all into the library.
replies_ddqual:
If there were separate spaces, like an off-campus student lounge, what activities would you still do in the Library?\\ I suppose that then the library would be more designed for quiet, focused study time which is still a space in high demand for students. 



However, I still think it's important that an off-campus student lounge be considered as more of a relaxing place to eat, socialize, be comfortable and have it be a reasonably sized space because there are many students would use both. 



The separation would provide more space, and allow for specific student needs to be met in both environments.\\ Be sure to check out the Cultural Center, Student Lounge and Quiet Lounges in the Campus Center at 150 Boylston St! They are great places to be in between classes and meetings! We also have microwaves and lockers for off campus students!\\ Walker 10 also has a great little common area that we call Common Ground. It's open for students to work, collaborate, eat, and even just hang out between classes. Plus there are some great offices on this floor that you should check out!\\ I definitely encourage students to check out Walker 10! It's a great space that goes unused by so many. \\ I think that even though living off campus can sound pretty great for a first-time transfer, it can also be intimidating especially when worrying about making friends. I think that if there were a way to initiate just for the first semester in living on campus, transfers wouldn't feel like such outsiders.\\ I was a transfer student and remain an off-campus student, and this rings true. The advice you give to on-campus students: bring layers for the AC on in the winter, bring a lunch AND a dinner if you can't afford EmCaf, join as many clubs as possible, etc. are 10x harder when you trek through the snow on the MBTA for an hour a day and walk with all of your belongings on your back because you have no time between class to stop at a locker (trust me, tried it, when you commute and have all your classes two days a week there is little wiggle room). When I have to leave home at 5:30 AM to make it to an 8 AM class, stay till 11 PM because on-campus students don't seem to understand that the MBTA closes at 12:30 and it is less than fun to commute alone for an hour on the T at midnight, and have nowhere to sit because the sororities use the Max lounge as a meet space at night, I'm done for. We NEED an off-campus lounge, it's not just a luxury, there is literally nowhere guaranteed to sit.

Response:
This is interesting. On the tail of any technology is automation. Certainly designing a webpage now is a lot easier. Even something like follow-focus on a camera, and many other aspects of image capture have been simplified by technology. 



But what of the next technologies. Television followed radio because it made sense. Will we need to study scene composition for 3d when the viewing apparatus is a cube-shaped tank that allows us to view a scene from all angles? Will "acting for the [immersive tank]" be a course? It's hard to say. Perhaps a technology that allows us to differentiate timber and tone when presenting text will help differentiate between glee and rage when we see all caps in some subcutaneous manner?  Would I enroll in "wiring for the Mercer Empathy Box" in 2034 to do so? 



And what about CSD? What will we have overcome in the next 20 years that would allow us to treat people with disorders, and what new disorders will emerge from data we are still gathering today?
replies_ddqual: Very interesting, Bret! I bet there will be lots of interesting new courses about the brain since we will understand so much more by then. I'm sure that will enrich the CSD major but probably others as well...like game design or marketing.

I have been here working in IT for a while, but honestly, I learn something new almost every day. It is usually in the form of what the Emerson community wants or how people like to do their work.



For example, there was a location with some seats to wait by an elevator, that for years no one sat in. Then starting a number of years ago, people started to congregate there. Over time, the location became almost continuously occupied. Why? There are outlets behind the benches, a wireless antenna right next to it, and a lab you can print to one door down. It has become the perfect spot to lounge while you work on your laptop!

Though it felt forced, I think through community involvement in certain acts or participation in helping others, and not just through Emerson, we could see some changes. Otherwise, I'm not sure how to answer this question.

Dining is a big thing I take advantage of as my taste in food has been changing lately. But it's always nice to just chill out in a cafe or something. Museums are also pretty relaxing and integrating of the arts. I only wish I would get out to concerts more.

It usually depends on the courses taken. I'll be honest, I wouldn't know. I'm a VMA major, specifically a Studio TV major. Students who were/are film majors used to have a difficulty changing to TV or vice versa, in which case Emerson decided to "make things easier."

Getting involved with the Emerson Channel has had a huge impact on who I am today! I sound like I'm repeating myself through these logs, but it's all true. I thought to most of them as acquaintances before I did the Orientation Series this past August for my first and last time. It was through this experience I had gotten to know a lot of them better and vice versa while applying myself at full potential and having fun. I worked with two marketing majors. Through this experience we were all able to collaborate on the project in a creative way where I actually learned different aspects of marketing from them that I had not known before.

Response: Almost everyday
Response_ddqual: Whether it is through classes, through extra curricular organizations, friends, the community, and myself, I am constantly learning something new each day which has a huge impact on the decisions I make while molding myself more as an adult. The influential people that come into my life and that I cross paths with through these experiences have made my stay at Emerson a pretty positive one. This idea comes from considering that I've taken some big steps for myself in opening up with strangers who ultimately become like family-friends. Everyone is always willing to teach you something, so you shouldn't be afraid to ask questions, that's one thing I've taken away from these past few semesters. You shouldn't also be afraid to explore new opportunities, take advantage of what you can while here. There is always something to take away with even the little moments.

Response: I think the best learning or teaching moment came from something outside of my major. There's always plenty you could learn within courses that apply to your studies or even outside the classroom through extra curricular activities. But one thing that I noticed from the start of my ethics class last fall was how my professor was looking to challenge us from the get go. He came off as intimidating to try and force students out of the class. I chose to accept the challenge even though I didn't know what I was in for. I didn't particularly like the content of the course, but my professor made sure to make it a good enough learning experience for those who actually stayed in his 8am course. His exams were pretty critically thinking, open-ended, recollection questions too which were just as challenging at first until you got a rhythm going. The class and professor made me realize just how capable I am of pushing myself in what was considered a new environment at the time.
The primary communal & meeting place for Emerson students at the College's Back Bay campus (130 Beacon Street)

Maria should get herself involved in many organizations on campus. Start small, if necessary, then realize what you're capable of. Try different things, don't just stick with the things you think you want to do. It is through these experiences you find yourself, you find your friends, you find out what you want to focus on in your studies/career goals. The people you meet and the challenges you  encounter could only help you become more connected to yourself and you community at the same time. College is a time for personal development. Some textbooks may deem unworthy to pay for, but those books may eventually be something that you look back on and say, "I'm glad I still have this to reference with what I am doing right now" even if that sounds lame. But getting involved is definitely one of the best ways to learn and keep yourself connected outside of the classroom learning experience. Classes can only get you so far, but working with others in an organization could help you branch out in many ways you might not get from doing the homework otherwise.

I am most excited about being part of the Emerson Community when there is a group collaboration going on, whether that means being involved at the start of a project, during, or seeing the change that becomes of it.

Response_ddqual: This is where the Tufte Center is. Here you can find the Vin Di Bona Television Studios, where I most often am for shows or classes given I'm a VMA Studies. It's become another home, another community, another family of friends with my stay at Emerson College this past year and a half. I've learned a lot from the people I've worked with and the people I'll continue to want to learn from or stay connected with. Everyone is always willing to help you out if you feel lost and excited to be a part of the creative content made every day to promote education, entertainment, energy, and more.

I think everyone should start to observe elevator adequacy. It's something mentioned during orientation but then forgotten. If someone pushes the button to the 6th floor, and you CLEARLY know that your class is on the 5th floor, it shouldn't mean holding everyone else up by being "that person" who decides to push the button anyway. It's not that difficult to take the stairs.
replies_ddqual:
But perhaps "that person" has a specific reason for needing to get off at the 5th floor instead of walking down to it? Sure it's a kind gesture to get off at a floor that isn't yours, but everybody has their own reasons for why they can or can't do things, and this whole "elevator adequacy" thing makes it uncomfortable for people who have legitimate reasons to get off on specific floors to do so. Perhaps they injured themselves but the injury isn't visible? That makes it pretty difficult to take the stairs. You just never know what's going on in somebody else's life.\\ There are certain intricacies to it. For example, Colonial residents have to take the elevator down even from the third floor. But Little Building residents can walk, but sometimes the stairs are closed! If it's a class day in Walker and someone goes to 5 when 6 is pressed, that's okay in my book because 5 is a common class floor. There are such weird little idiosyncrasies to it. It all depends on high-volume times and which elevator you are using. That said, I highly believe in elevator ettiquette, but I wish there were a better way. In my opinion, I'd love to see an app much like the T times app that shows elevator wait times. That would be pretty cool and would seriously help people plan accordingly.\\ Caitlin -- whether it is "that difficult to take the stairs" changes from person to person, based on their level of ability. that is something for them to assess themselves.\\ As Alex E pointed out, lots of injuries or other reasons why people can't take the stairs are not visible.  They could be invisible physical reasons or psychological or something else entirely.  

This is related to another discussion going on at the college right now about the importance of all-around courtesy and how to increase awareness and inclusion of people who may proceed differently/slowly or need additional space/resources.  



Our core values of Inclusion and Diversity encompass ability and issues of disability as well.

Response: Radio, duh. That medium is totally going places!

Well gee. I don't know where technology is going. I will say this, if the school wants to catch up with the times how about upgrades to the TV studios - which still broadcasts in HD. How about getting  more higher end cameras? We have two F3s, that's as high end as it gets here at Emerson. Of course VMA just got the F5 but here's the deal --



This summer when shooting my BFA, a location dropped. So we of course had to adjust, there was nothing we can do right? So we go to school asked for "one F3 please!" and learned the camera was already booked. Because of that I lost all my life savings to my BFA (who needs those anyway?) in order to secure an F3 from Boston Rule. I shouldn't have to do that.



Some students had to rent out LIGHTS because all of the equipment in the EDC was booked. Sure we have so and so amount of C100s and 60Ds but I don't know... losing 2,000 dollars to a camera is just something I shouldn't have to do. Students shouldn't be renting lights if they're available from the school. 



Technology discussions are great and all but how about an upgrade to facilitates first? Maybe I'm just a little teed off, but that's all I got to say.
replies_ddqual: *BROADCAST IN SD. My bad.\\ I hate how you can't like edit any of these after the fact. haha\\ this brings up an important point about access to production equipment and supplies--students shouldn't be excluded from working in film because of the high costs associated with it.  Diversity includes economic diversity.  Inclusiveness means everyone!

The VMA department at Emerson is way too shut off and doesn't offer many courses to people outside of the major. One option would be to open up more screenwriting classes to WLP majors and I know that is a thing but still how about this real case scenario for you.

any ideas on how this could change? would a formal mentoring program work?\\ It seems that a mentoring set-up for faculty would be a natural fit with the College's goal of "innovation in teaching and learning."

Response: When I was giving current events quizzes to my freshman seminar and they were failing them miserably. I told the student my purpose for giving the quizzes -- since we were studying media literacy, they needed to be daily consumers of news media -- and asked them what other task or assignment could accomplish my purpose. We all talked for a while, and the students came up with the idea of having the first 15 minutes of class be a discussion of one story in the news, with the discussion started by a student I chose (that way they all needed to prepare because they didn't know whom I would choose.) It worked wonderfully.
replies_ddqual: I love this story because you knew your objective, but you let the students help you understand their learning styles so that you could actually accomplish the objective. Everybody wins!

I think the answer here is going to be it's an on-giong challenge to make technology work for me rather than having me work for the technology.



Ultimately, I see the crucial work at Emerson as learning. Technology both facilitates that and impedes it. I would like to think that technology will enhance instruction, but I have serious doubts. I can say for certain that technological changes demand my attention, and that I have sustained and substantive discussions with my students about the full human experience and the extent to which technology degrades our memories, our direct interactions, etc. We should strive to assert control and agency over technology and not the reverse. Technological changes require that I constantly develop strategies for determining its role in my teaching.

Through my coursework in arts, I learned about a variety of visual strategies for capturing and sustaining people's attention. I analyzed how stories and values could be effectively embodied in pictures, sculptures, and so forth.

Response:
I think it's vitally important to have a degree from any college. It shows any employer that you can commit and complete a difficult task. It's equally important if you are going into a field of some kind of communications or acting that a degree from Emerson is just that much more icing on the cake. In 2014 it means something out there that you have completed a field of study from one of the top communications\arts school in the country. 



However, if Emerson wants that degree to mean something in 2020 or 2030 then it will also have to keep up with the ever changing landscape of the industry. It's going to have to make the financial and philosophical commitment to enhance it's programs to something better than status quo. The other schools that we compete against for students, NYU, Ithica, Pace, Sarah Lawrence, etc. all will be doing the same thing. We can't be complacent and just "keep up with the Jones"! We need to make ourselves better and more streamline, less convoluted and confusing. I see most everyone trying to help paddle the ship, but we're not all paddling in the same direction! Some are just along for the ride and aren't paddling at all. We all need to find one focus.Together this will attract more students, attract more donors and beneficiaries of the college, to provide more opportunities for the students with real world experience and internships, and to continue to foster that "One Family, One World" feeling that you get when you are part of the Emerson experience.

Yes he has a right to worry. The question he has to ask and answer for himself is whether or not he feels prepared to enter the job market with the knowledge that he does have about his chosen major. Is there another class that he could have taken instead that could give him a slight edge over others when it comes down to whom the employer is going to pick when it comes time. I know that philosophy is a noble profession and course of study, but unless that is what he is planning to seek a job in he may have better chosen an elective more inline with his major. Yes, being well rounded is a great thing, but many employers are looking for that individual who is going to give them that sharp focused edge in the job.
replies_ddqual: Dang, Dennis.  :)\\ NO.\\ I'm sorry, nope, nope, nope. Philosophy broadens the scope of the mind and the overall knowledge of knowledge. It is a humbling and necessary subject matter for minds in their prime.  \\ I'm not saying that philosophy doesn't, but what I am trying to convey is that if he had a choice of electives and one was more in line with what he intends to do when he gets out of school AND that class could be a tipping point for an employer as to " This kid has got some great skills or I wish he had this skill" I would drop the philosophy like a bad habit! If all the electives that were available weren't in his field and he had to pick something, sure philosophy is a nice study.\\ I disagree with Dennis - but maybe that is because I haven't recently been job searching or hiring, so I'm less in touch with the dog eat dog world out there.

Hey, at least it would be an actual game at that point, instead of a dressed-up survey.\\ HAHAHAHAHAHA!

\\ We actually considered something like this. There's an issue with losing coins though - if you pledge all your coins before trivia, you have nothing to lose.



I suppose you could say the wager is always just on top of the normal coin award so if you have no coins to bet, you can't take advantage of that option. That might be fun, but it still has a few issues.



1) The answer to the trivia is always in a resource, so the obvious right move would be for everyone to bid the max and then get the trivia question correct by reading the resource. This doesn't make it any more of a "game" since it's not a strategic choice, but an obvious one.



2) Adding a wagering element increases the complexity, and CPI is supposed to be playable by anyone including people who "aren't gamers," or are not savvy web users. The game is being played in Bhutan later this month, for instance. I'm almost out of characters, so the rest will have to wait. Who's lousy idea was a character limit anyway?\\ Long story short is we decided against any scenario that could result in negative coins, both because we didn't want people confused between positive and negative coin values, because the concept of negative coin values is a little complex for some, and because we didn't want any situation where a player engages meaningfully, but then does not get to have a say in the causes.

Response:
This is a very interesting question, but I'm not quite sure how to answer it.



Speaking in generalities, a college degree from a liberal arts institution or any traditional private college will probably be diminished over the next 20 years, as MOOCs and other innovations make learning more accessible to the world.



I don't think Emerson should fear this, however. I think it should be embraced. EC has already offered a number of MOOCs. There's every reason to continue, and to increase it. The more people know of and respect Emerson, the more cache a degree will have, so it works both ways. Whatever you do, don't get left behind.

I get his concern, but there's something to be said for being a well-rounded person. Expanding your mind in different directions can have unexpected benefits for your main line of work, too. Ever seen True Detective?



Philosophy.
Yes
Response_ddqual:
It wasn't immediately obvious when I first graduated Emerson that I had gained the skills I needed. Yes, I was quickly employed as a copywriter, but after the crash in '08 the marketing industry was hit pretty hard, including my job (and most everyone at my agency, too). 



However, now that I work at the Engagement Lab, I realize what my time at Emerson was actually preparing me for.

Response:
Game Design or Game Studies!



I'd also like to see a game writing minor, or at the very least a few classes that deal with digital game production. The video game industry is more profitable than the film industry! It is now clear that games are here to stay - and that YES, they can be art.



We should be leading on this. Boston is a national leader in this growing industry, and there are colleges in Boston with game design majors, but not Emerson. We have the Engagement Lab. What's next?
replies_ddqual:
Seems like a lot of people want this. It's kind of surprising that we don't have it already given that we have the engagement lab.\\ Games get the short end of the stick. Most established critics don't consider them art. Roger Ebert famously said that a video game could never be art. 



Film had the same problem when it first debuted, but video games are not a new media any more, and they are most certainly art. If Emerson is "innovative," it should be supporting one of the most innovative art forms in existence!

Response:
Virtual classes with the Oculus Rift? 



Seriously though, I think it's going to be very hard to predict what technology is going to be like 10+ years from now, or what it will afford us. In 2003, smart phones were basically PDAs and primitive blackberries that only hardcore work-a-holics used. Social media didn't even exist (unless you count Live Journal).



If we can figure out how Emerson can be ahead of the curve on Tech, that would be a great coup for the school.

Having a creative background should be a big plus for any marketing job, as long as it's a creative position. Even if it's not, having a writing degree would make Dawn a valuable asset to any marketing department, since she should know the basics of style, and be able to catch errors (a huge concern in the advertising world). 



Emerson also puts a lot of emphasis on collaboration, which will be a big help to Dawn when her team is working on a complex project.

Response_ddqual:
Though I think it's a little bit of each, I consider Emerson a professional school for arts and communications. Students here dream big, and more than any college I've seen, they seem to know what they want to do when they graduate, and view Emerson as the place where they will learn those skills.



I've known a few people that transferred out of Emerson to more liberal arts type colleges, and those people have tended to be the unguided types who don't already have a career path in their heads.
