Response: Student-Instructor Ratio, Opportunities to do original work, Opportunities to collaborate with academic or professional experts in your field, Amount of work required for good grades, Diversity of faculty and staff
Response_ddqual:
I was always happy with the student/instructor ratio at Emerson when I attended, and I am amazed by the intimate nature of the classes we hold at the Lab (kind of a necessity since the classroom only holds about 12).



Diversity of faculty and staff: this is crucial. Learning from people with just one perspective/one voice is not a recipe for excellence of any kind.



Being able to put in maximal effort for maximal results (work for grades) is pretty essential, too. And the opportunity to collaborate with professional experts is half the reason anyone would want to attend Emerson in the first place.



The other items listed here are very important, too, but those are my top 5. Maybe we should have asked for the top 3 to narrow it down more.

Response: Common Ground

I honestly have no idea what it's like to switch majors here. I never tried when I was an undergrad, and I had a weird talent for creating good class schedules for myself. I graduated a semester early.

Many experiences at Emerson have changed me. I did my undergrad here, and then after a few years writing ad copy, I'm back as a full time staff member working at the Engagement Lab (the folks who built this humble game).



Leaving aside all the amazing people I met, suitemates I still talk to daily, and fond memories of hanging out on the common and eating NYP, I can think of the following things off the top of my head.



First, it was an Emerson professor who put me on the road to copywriting. I was a WLP major who knew he'd write the next great novel. That never materialized, but a career in advertising did. I honed the skills that I use every day in my current work (see item four below) this way.



Second, my semester at the Castle opened up the world outside of the USA to me. Being able to travel extensively in Europe while studying literature and poetry was an opportunity I feel very privileged to have had, and was fundamental to my future.



Third, I started seriously designing games while I was a student at Emerson. I met my co-designer through an Emerson gaming organization, and we've designed dozens of games together, some of which won awards.



Fourth, now that I'm back at Emerson working at the Engagement Lab, I have been able to break away from my advertising career and now spend every day using my passions (writing and games) to actually foster good in the world. What's more Emerson than that?

I would tell him to talk to Emerson grads who have gone on to achieve success in their fields, and ask them how hard they worked, and on what. Being creative and thinking critically about art is very hard work, and there's plenty of room for intellectual rigor.

Response: I was head scriptwriter for a movie I was producing with a small group for my Foundations in Visual and Media Arts class, but I wasn't exactly sure how to write it. What came out was actually pretty decent and we ended up using practically all of it in our final product. What I learned from that experience is that when you're in a bind, sometimes it's best to just sit down and write.

First and foremost, I work at the Lyric Stage Company of Boston as my service work study. It's about a 10 minute walk from campus and is a source of great theater in the Boston area. It's also part of the Emerson Mafia as Emersonians are the box office and front of house staff, production interns, marketing interns, actors, and even Producing Artistic Director Spiro Veloudos graduated in 1974 and teaches at Emerson.

Response:
I have been fortunate enough to study abroad in Beijing, China through Emerson's External Programs.  I was the first student from Emerson to utilize our partnership with the Communications University of China in Beijing and I spent Fall 2013 there studying Mandarin and Communications.  My greatest learning experience occurred when I first arrived to the CUC campus in Beijing, immediately got lost, and then realized: I am on completely my own.  

Of course I had the wonderful support of my family as well as David Griffin (Director, International Study & External Programs) via electronic communication; yet, everything I knew was on the other side of the planet!  I was "a stranger in a strange land".  But this has become one of my greatest experiences and life lessons.  Even with love and support, I must still find my own way.

Response:
We had to take a StrengthsFinder assessment recently and, as has been the case with other schools I've worked at, I expected the results to be ignored or used as a conversation piece and nothing more. I was surprised when my office actually took the results to heart, using them to make sure my coworkers and I were being given rewarding work and tasks that played to our strengths.



I think that Emerson, as a whole, is wonderful about doing this sort of thing. Faculty, students, staff - none of us are  cogs in a machine. We're not interchangeable or homogeneous, and we aren't treated as such. The institution celebrates our diversity and individuality, allowing us to explore what that means and responding to us once we know who we are. 



That's a rare and wonderful thing.
Africa

We're a tolerant place, we're a safe place for people to define themselves, we foster creativity and innovation, and we help people develop the tools to secure meaningful, fulfilling work for themselves. That's a good start in terms of how we address society's problems.



I'd like to see us help by continuing to develop thoughtful, altruistic, and hard-working individuals. The students here are amazing in so many ways; as long as Emerson continues to foster that, we're doing good in the world.

Response_ddqual: I should probably pick somewhere more exciting or dramatic but...I'm a practical guy. James Madison University offers a graduate certificate in becoming a Higher Education Assessment Specialist (http://www.jmu.edu/outreach/programs/all/assessment/index.shtml) that I think would be fantastic for me personally and professionally. Also it'd potentially lead into a Ph.D. program that sounds interesting. Yeah...not the sexiest answer but I would really love to do some professional development there. I mean, who wouldn't want to spend time learning at a place that has The Center for Assessment and Research Studies?
replies_ddqual: It's a good point. Emerson doesn't having anything related to higher ed administration.

Response_ddqual: As a staff member, participating in the Office of Diversity & Inclusion's certificate program in Inclusive Excellence in Action has really helped develop my ability to succeed in a world where cultural lines are blurring a bit more every day. It's easy to play the "color-blind" card or say that since we're all human we're essentially the same and should be treated thusly, but this is not the best way to go about things. We are different. We are the direct result of internal conflicts and external pressures from a variety of cultures as interpreted from wholly unique lenses. It's okay to recognize the differences. It's good to talk about them. It's even better to celebrate them.

Response:
As an armchair futurist, this question really intrigues me. Let's look back at the things that have changed since 1994. Marketing online, the entirety of journalism, online publishing - in all of these things the common theme is that technology has changed traditional means of communicating in unpredictable ways. In 1994 the internet was such an up and coming thing that Time magazine actually did a cover story about it - just look at this http://techland.time.com/2013/09/29/everything-you-needed-to-know-about-the-internet-in-1994/ - and had to explain the basic premise of why it was important because the average reader what it was. 



How prevalent has the internet become 20 years later? What amazing cultural changes has it wrought across the world? More germane to this question - how could we possibly know what majors will be created/altered 20 years in the future because of some unknowable technological shift? Honestly, as long as the new major has something to do with new cutting edge technology and not how to eke a living out of nuclear fallout, I'll be a happy camper.

I would hope that, by then, we would fully embrace online education for both undergraduate and graduate degrees and certificates. As a person working in the Office of Student Success, ensuring non-terrestrial students (students taking classes online) have the same access to important resources as traditional, terrestrial students have would be a difficult task. With that said, I think that technology will only become more ubiquitous for students attending college in 2025 (generally those born between 2004 and 2007 for undergraduates) and their status as digital natives (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_native) will help them navigate the challenges that come with an online education. 



Oh, and by then I hope they have high speed trains between Worcester and Boston because the commute right now is a real bear.

Arts education, and liberal arts education as a whole, helps the student learn about a variety of subject but, more importantly, teaches a student how to learn and think critically. While the arts-related courses might not immediately seem helpful for someone applying for a marketing assistant position at a pharmaceutical company, any employer should agree that a candidate with a proven track record of being a well-rounded, thoughtful, and creative person would be worth serious consideration.

If you can imagine a Theatre, and walking in not knowing where to sit or if you were even in the right place...maybe looking for a friend, and then just deciding to sort of hang in the back so as not to disturb anyone- this was me pre-Emerson. Now, imagine a Theatre that you walk into, ready for engagement, ready for the experience, you have a ticket that you chose, you know right where you're sitting, you can walk confidently towards it. There are friends all around you, some you know and some you don't- yet. Response: Over the summer I took the Urban teaching institute class. It was a two week intensive; the amount I absorbed in those two weeks feels immeasurable. Response: I remember at one point when I had first started my current position at Emerson, I was struggling to find an article someone had requested through Interlibrary Loan. Response_ddqual:
I think service learning is one of the major opportunities colleges and their students can not only assist a community, but also represent themselves to the communities. Having a more enjoyable neighborhood for our campus is ideal, and assisting our communities via service learning is one of the best ways to achieve this. It lets the community know that Emerson cares, and gets the community to care about Emerson as a result.



However, I feel that service learning shouldn't be made a component of more classes. I feel that volunteering for service learning, rather than making it a mandatory part of a grade, is critical. People who want to give their time to assist communities will likely have more drive and dedication toward their service rather than those who are forced to complete service, which should also result in better relations with a community. Yes, making service learning a component of classes could get more people involved, but it could also bring out less dedicated people.

Response: I believe that Emerson should team up with the City of Boston and Suffolk University to help make the Boston Common and surrounding areas between our campuses safer. I feel that there is a shared interest in trying to make our college area, and a major city area, safer. My idealistic goal is to have a Boston Common where no one has to worry about whether or not to walk through it based on the time of day. I know there will always be crime where there is an opportunity for crime, but I hope that one day we won't have to worry about being in the Common late at night, especially since the Common is a part of Emerson's identity.
All of the above

I see innovation happening all over the place at Emerson. Whether it's an approach to solving issues and opportunities on campus (the Conversations on Creativity), the Emerson Accelerator program, the amazing concepts and businesses that come out of E3, or even this game.



If you want to be deeply invested in the surrounding community, innovation is key. The hardest part of innovation is going outside your comfort zone, and trying to get everyone else involved out of theirs.

When I'm in Boston, I usually like to attend Red Sox or Bruins games. These are quite pricy, so it's pretty rare that I attend those. I love going to concerts in the city as well. So many venues to see a concert exist in the city! My favorite concert venue was the Somerville Theater at Davis Square. I saw Natasha Bedingfield there, and the atmosphere of the show was amazing. I've also been meaning to go to an ArtsEmerson event.



The Museum of Science is always amazing and fun to visit. It's so well known for how great it is, that Walter White referred to it in the last season of Breaking Bad! I also love eavesdropping on the various historical tours and trolley tours while I'm walking through the city. I feel like I have the Boston Massacre details memorized from being outside the Old State House so many times.



As far as dining goes, my favorite restaurant in the city to get something to eat is Jacob Wirth on Stuart Street. It's one of the oldest restaurants in Boston, dating back to 1868, and has some really good food.

Response_ddqual: Of the five factors I selected, I feel the Student-Instructor ratio is the most important factor for academic excellence. This factor helps maintain a relationship between faculty members and students. The more students there are, the less time there is to maintain a relationship. Faculty members have been huge parts of my professional development, and I believe that the fact my class sizes were small helped free up time for my faculty members to meet with us for longer periods of time.

Response:
My best learning/teaching moments are usually with my colleagues. My fellow staff members have taught me so much over the years, especially people like Joyce Andrews, whose number I've memorized because of all the times she has helped me. My fellow staff members and I are usually able to solve problems together, putting our collective knowledge together to find the best solutions.



I've also had some great mentors while I've been here. Richard Zauft, the former Graduate Studies dean, gave me so much professional experience and lobbied for me for so many things. Donna Heiland and Tim Edgar are continuing to mentor me with specific projects.



Finally, the Graduate Student Association and my office have a very informative relationship. We learn what we can do to better assist graduate students in our conversations with the GSA, and we inform them of what they can consider for various events and projects that they are putting together.

I would also like to connect Maria to the Office of Student Life to find out how she can get more involved around campus. Becoming a member of a student group connects you to so many people that she is likely to make new friends. She will also have a great activity that interests her through that office, which could become a leadership role if she wants it.

I am most excited about being part of the Emerson Community when working with people who are excited about making Emerson a better place, and are open to ideas and assisting staff to make these ideas a reality. I really like working with the Graduate Student Association, as they do their best to support and advocate for graduate students, making sure they don't get looked over at the College.



I also love being a member of the Conversations About Creativity committee. Instead of having a "get this done" mentality, the group seeks to educate Emerson community members about creativity at the College, and works as a group without titles to find out how to promote creativity at the College.

Computer Science and/or Software Engineering.  There are hardly any real CS or programming classes now, or faculty that know how to actually program, so with the increasing demand of technical skills if the school does not offer a program like this they will see themselves becoming irrelevant.
replies_ddqual: Agreed.\\ totally agree! it's good to see that a lot of people feel the same way.

Response:
Technology is intertwined with most things we do in 2014.  In 11 years, that relationship is going to be even greater. I don't think anyone can really predict exactly how it is going to change, only that it will. However, the expectation is that faculty members will increasingly adopt new and innovative technology in the classroom and online education will most likely help push them in that direction.



The technology demands of students, staff, and faculty are already significantly higher than what they were even a few years ago, but their knowledge and understanding of that technology has not necessarily grown at the same rate. It is going to be incumbent on all of those groups to increase their technical skills to be more aligned with their own demands. The institution itself will also need to provide additional resources (funding, staffing, etc.) to stay competitive with other schools who have already taken bold steps towards the future. You can only do "more with less" for so long.  "Cheap" technology solutions get expensive really fast.

Response: My graduate class in Interactive Communication works with local organizations interested in sustainability and social advocacy, and helps them to build community engagement plans to better invest in dialog with the community. Emerson is all about bringing innovation to communication and the arts. I think we have to find where communication and the arts intersect with the surrounding community and how we can use our talents to better and improve the community around us. Whether that be volunteering at the local shelter, getting the campus together for a food drive, or something else, it should include students of various disciplines and highlight their talents. That's when we get the best results!

This is something that I really want to work on personally, because I don't really take part in the culture of Boston. However, it is incredibly accessible for students to go to many of the plays, musicals, and museums on campus--it's also great that at events like Orientation and Family Weekend that we usually give out discounts and such to take advantage of these opportunities!

Academically, I suppose you could make the argument that Ansin is, but I think the Little Building is a more accurate representation of the "center" of the student body.

Response_ddqual: Is anyone else still not a fan of the "tap and go" system? I get the merits of safety, but as a student who live on campus for the past two and half years, I never felt unsafe with the doors open. I think the best argument that I've heard against the "tap and go" system is that Emerson is all about inclusivity and engaging with the community and being a part of the community; the "tap and go" system literally separates us from the community. Doesn't that go against President's Pelton's initiative of "to engage and assist nearby communities"? (Mostly to engage)
replies_ddqual: Definitely not a fan, particularly during class-switching. But it's probably cheaper than having a uniformed guard on every floor during all open hours. We also don't have the space to support a more open campus - even the grad students usually can't fit in the library or find an available space to work for more than 20 minutes. we all suffer with Tap&Go, but no one mor than the poor entryway guards, who hear that horrible beeping all hours of the day. \\ After hearing stories of people (homeless people, irate Bostonians, etc) chasing students into the dorms/buildings from the streets/sidewalks, I definitely feel the uptick in safety by using the Tap & Go system outweighs the slight inconvenience. If people just keep their IDs in-hand as they're switching classes, it doesn't take that much extra time. You can still mingle with non-Emerson folk in the Common/outside class, or sign them in if you already know them or anticipate their arrival.\\ I've had a lot of unsavory experiences in the area surrounding Emerson, so I appreciate the effort to keep us safe. What bothers me is that the use of the system isn't consistent between guards.

"Socially responsible" to me would mean in two particular dimensions: outward-facing and inward-facing. Outwardly: are we addressing sustainability, not just environmentally, but socially? When we train media producers, do we train them to think reflexively about the structures they'll join or will create? The problems of global climate change, war and violence, structural racism/sexism/name-an-ism are intimately tied to what gets covered in the media, who gets to cover it, opportunities to engage with it. I would hope an Emerson student doesn't learn just to join the machine but to question what that machine is encouraged to produce explicitly or implicitly going forward and decides to go where the silences lay (or better yet, create mechanisms to address them entirely). It would mean a campus that also takes a realistic view of its effects on its surrounding community and maintains active communications with those it affects and holds itself accountable. This can extend, obviously, well beyond Chinatown.



Inwardly: upon arrival I was pleased to see the steps that have been taken to address power-based violence on campus. These were really progressive steps which are ongoing. A socially responsible campus doesn't just foster an environment in which we operate in terms of mutual respect, but recognizes that constant dialogue is necessary to address how we replicate structural inequalities even when our best of intentions results in otherwise. Here structures of accountability are key as well.
Elma Lewis School of Fine Arts

I frankly don't know how to answer this - I can't imagine speaking for our neighbors. I would say that from conversations I've had with old friends (and given my partner used to live in Chinatown, albeit before the Ritz went up) basic life has changed dramatically in the area in recent years, and I imagine a squeeze is on for whoever remains. I don't have actual data, so this is off-the-cuff, of course. Our presence certainly will have an effect on the policing of the population around the nearby shelter. Emerson brings a great deal to Boston in so many ways, as well, surely, to the local community; I'm certainly terrifically pleased to be a part of it and wouldn't have come here if I felt otherwise. Its interactions with the political economy of nearby areas will simply be complicated and are likely considered by our neighbors via implicit mechanisms rather than overt communications from us. Engagement and open channels with the community strike me as paramount, and I assume that behind the scenes this has been a longstanding concern.
No opinion
Response_ddqual: I'm agnostic. It truly depends. "Service learning" can be a positive experience for all involved, or it can result in stop-start short-term relationships, little reflection, an 'individualization' of the issues addressed by an organization as opposed to tying the filled need to broader social/structural issues. The broader context needs to be considered and real partnerships need to be established (with deep reflection of the organization's/community's needs alongside the structure needed by the school), otherwise more harm than good can result, with voluntarism-as-a-solution taking precedence over a realization of possibilities of broader policy or political change.

Innovation will hopefully involve reflexive examination of 'innovation-hype' that is all the rage today: it's certainly part of a broader paradigm. This is in the cards, however, which makes me happy: as a part of the Engagement Lab we're looking to explore all sorts of possibilities ranging from the practical to the more theoretical; this excites me a great deal. An innovative college these days is both a space for invention and a space for reflection of the implications of such invention.

I tend to seek out art (I have yet to visit the ICA since its transplant onto the water, but will be making a point of going soon) and off-the-beaten-track music. Noisier the better, and the northeast is a treasure trove of experimentation in this regard with electronic, freak-folk and noise artists pushing every boundary imaginable. I love finding pop-up shows here and in Providence/Lowell/they're sprouting up in Vermont too. I am a devout listener to noncommercial radio in Boston - no other place has so many amazing college stations: KLXU notwithstanding, LA doesn't hold a candle to what we have in the Boston area.

Response_ddqual: 'Academic excellence' is about laying the foundation for (at least) two things, in my view. One is an instillation of a critical outlook - that is, one doesn't just _do_ what they're training to do; one continually questions the assumptions behind what they're doing. Another is learning how to learn on one's own; the undergraduate/graduate program is only the first step in this process.

Response:
This one is a little obnoxious, but I still think it's both funny and is representative of Emerson. 



When I was interviewing for my job here, long ago, I mentioned that I had applied to Emerson as an undergrad and was accepted but didn't end up going, to illustrate my longtime, unfulfilled desire to be a part of the Emerson community. Someone asked where I went for my undergrad instead. I responded Harvard, and most people at the table nodded and seemed satisfied with that answer, but one staff member looked at me squarely and asked, "and why did you choose them," with the clear challenge in her eye that there had better have been a really good reason that I didn't choose Emerson over Harvard. And I said that Emerson didn't offer my most-wanted choice of major. She nodded, mollified.



I was impressed by that level of staff loyalty to, and belief in the value of, Emerson.
replies_ddqual:
I love this story!

and love how you answered!

Response: Africa

We do service days and other volunteer work. We work with schools to provide opportunities to younger students. We craft lots of public service announcements and host programs to provide information about local politics. We've got the office for Sustainability, the Elma Lewis Center, the Office for Diversity and Inclusion, the Engagement Lab, and the Face Lab. We have our rep, which I think is reasonably well-earned, for LGBTI friendliness. And we shape public attitudes through the entertainment industry (sometimes for the better). We educate. 



I think we should keep on with those things, but I think one good focus for us would be too really tackle the issue of the rising cost of higher ed in a meaningful way in our own backyard. We need to increase financial aid for our students. Really, really, really.

Response_ddqual: Ok, in large part just because I want to visit friends there. Lots of interesting stuff going on in those parts. But there's a lot of exciting thinking about academic libraries and higher ed in Sydney, as well, and they would have some very different perspectives.

Response:
The philosophy class is inspiring him to contemplate the nature and purpose of higher education. So that's good. :) Philosophy is useful, if he's approaching this strictly from a "useful" orientation. It tackles non-lazy thinking head-on, which is very important in film production and can set him apart if he adapts its principles to his work. It will also help him understand the complex results of emphasizing and prioritizing efficiency over everything else.



If he is, as some students are, struggling with financial issues and needs to spend those tuition dollars elsewhere, I might recommend Michael Sandel's Justice free online course: http://www.justiceharvard.org/

The phrasing of this question hurts my head a bit - it's a bit hard to interpret the intent. But, let's say the question is, if I'm still staff here in 2025, how is my job different? (Technology is in my job title, so this might be fun.) 



Well, maybe I'll no longer have a desktop but rather a portable computing and communications device. (A tricorder would be lovely, but I'll take a phablet or whatever term they come up with.) Ebooks will be the dominant publishing format of books, so our physical collections will be smaller, with all the attendant issues and workflows that go along with that. I'll support fewer general-purpose kiosks and focus more on speciality workstations. There'll be less printing, so fewer printer issues, please, thanks. And maybe we'll get bracelets or some gadget to tap and go that will support not just our Emerson IDs, but also other forms of identification/credit. The access that tech appears to afford will mean that LA and Kasteel will be in touch more. Eh, I could go on for hours, but I want to see other people's comments!

Response_ddqual:
My profession is within academia, and I sometimes feel that at Emerson, working on acquiring the skills to use in a future career or profession is equated to academic excellence. That can make me uneasy, even when discussing graduate studies. Professionally-related academic excellence is part of the experience Emerson seeks to provide, but that should not be perceived as the entirety of it. There is a liberal arts component here that needs acknowledgement. 



I didn't go to Emerson as an undergrad, and I just didn't have time for extra-curriculars when I was a grad student, so I don't think of extra-curriculars in quite the same way that I know many Emerson undergrads and alums think about them. My extra-curriculars were enormously important to me, but they were never promoted to me, and I never viewed them, as essential resume- and portfolio-builders for my future career.

That's a very good question - I don't deal with the technical details of major-switching, so I don't know what kind of process it is. We do struggle with being stuck in silos a lot, so I hope this particular kind of change isn't too difficult for students. 



My sister switched majors her senior year in college her last semester there, and graduated a semester early. But all her electives were in her new major. That was at MIT - I'm really interested in hearing from the students on this question about what the experience is like here.

At my last job, many, many years ago, I asked a guy from IT to come over to my office once because I was nervous about cracking the case or electrocuting myself when I was adding memory to my workstation. At Emerson, I just started taking computers apart to repair, upgrade, or scavenge for parts. By spending some time to understand how hardware works (and reading manuals, and asking around), I felt confident enough to deal with it myself. 



It's affected me on a philosophical level, because it made me think about when and why people are willing to look under the hood of the technology they use, and how people interpret technology's behavior as "transparent" - when they are not really thinking about using the technology, they're just "doing it," even if what they need to do to accomplish what they want is actually really complicated. Really complicated technology can be transparent when relatively simple tech can be completely opaque, depending on a person's familiarity with, desire to use, and expectations about it.



My job title is long, so I sometimes summarize it as "people call me when something breaks" - when the technology is no longer transparent to them. That's more wisecrack than it is accurate, but it's illustrative of a mode of thinking that I get into.

Response_ddqual: Part of my job is being a liaison - it's listed in my job description. So I collaborate a lot. I work with the vast and sprawling empire of IT a fair amount. Off the top of my head, recently, I've worked with the Disability Services Office, Josh (for Spacebook stuff), Office for Student Success, Office of Diversity & Inclusion, and ITG. I work with staff in our library consortium(s) and at other libraries. I also work a lot with other departments within the library. And I'm a member of EmCares. Finally, I'm a long-standing member of the Faculty Technology Policy Committee, and I look forward to meeting with them this year. (I feel like I'm giving an awards speech - sorry if I left out anyone!)

Response: Charles Wesley Emerson, founder of Emerson College

I created Tech Talks, which was a library/IT/ITG collaboration. Emerson is so results-focused that I wanted to create a program for just talking about something - technology, in this case. We've discussed PowerPoint's good and bad points, tech on the cheap, and other topics over the year. And sometimes we just watch TED talks and eat pizza and talk about what that makes us think about.

Response:
As a staff member, it may have been my first year here, back in 2002. I didn't know where anything was or who people were yet and it seemed like I had a million things to do all at once, but everywhere I went, people helped me.



As a student, one best moment was a short story workshop taught by Ben Brooks. I took it through Professional Studies before I started the master's program in Publishing and Writing (and the credits transferred in, thankfully). My classmates were a great mix - Emerson students and staff, and people who were taking only this one course and brought with them a gorgeous diversity of life experience and careers. We created a tiny, ephemeral community. We were honest - sometimes brutally and sometimes gently. I very much admire Ben's wisdom in guiding the class. I learned from every person there, with every story they brought in and every comment they made on mine. And I still miss those folks and that class, years later.
The primary communal & meeting place for Emerson students at the College's Back Bay campus (130 Beacon Street)

She needs the library! (Of course I'm going to say that, I'm a librarian.) We provide course reserves, materials for papers and projects and extracurriculars, and people to help her navigate all our resources. We can loan her an iPad to take notes in class, she can print here, and she can get a museum pass when she needs a break to go see some amazing art. And if she needs to relax between classes, she can sit and daydream or talk with friends and fellow Marketing students in front of our huge picture windows overlooking the common. 



But she also might need some support from the Office of Student Success, as well. As the first of her family to attend college, she may not arrive with as much of an understanding of higher ed expectations and environments as some of the other students whose families might be better able to prepare them and help them navigate this experience.

I am most excited about being part of the Emerson Community when I talk to people who are completely engaged in trying to solve a problem, small or big. I greatly value academic exploration and artistic expression for its own sake, but Emerson really emphasizes, and is especially good at, focused teaching and learning with a specific goal in mind.

Response: Colonial Building

Firstly, go to International student affairs. You can look for experienced student assistants on the front desk to help you out. If you wanna know more,  try asking them if you could go in and just talk with Susanna or Virga, they may have or may not have the information that you are looking for. They will also redirect you to other department in the office to ensure that they meet your needs. Thirdly, try going to the departments that you think may have connections to outside organizations. There's no harm in asking. Lastly, try going to the dog park in Boston Commons around 4-7pm where there is a patch of grass that dogs can be unleashed and play together. There you may meet members of the community that need students like you to help out. Here are some options that I found at the park; photography projects for a non-profit organisations, volunteering student teachers for pre-school students, dog care assistant, peer tutoring, and others. There are a lot of options there that language do not act as a barrier. These people just need your interest and enthusiasm. =)

If you want to be invested deeply in the surrounding community, you have to come up with something new or improved for them. Take the LA campus for example, it has a state of the art design. As an outsider few years ago, driving along Hollywood Boulevard, I came across this campus in its construction. I was like, this is a unique building, most definitely a high-ranked business company or somewhat. Then a few years went by and I applied to Emerson, I was like, wait a minute, this Building belongs to Emerson College???? What?? If this school shows how invested it is to provide the resources, knowledge, and experience, I bet the hard work would not lay unnoticed. Providing a whole new experience accessible by both internal and external parties gives Emerson the support it needs by a various new community to innovate and push further and also the support the surrounding community needs; which Emerson can also provide.

Response: Thom Mayne

I think Emerson is perceived to be a great educational institution, but that's not enough (and Emerson shouldn't accept that as being enough). I want Emerson to be perceived as a global, cultural, and professional hub (as alluded to in the previous question) that companies, employers, and other educational institutes recognize.

Emerson.edu is a go-to resource, Steady stream of international artists, communications experts, and scholars visting our camupus, Higher percentage of international students, faculty and staff, Regularly cited in the press about our specialty fields
Response_ddqual: Everything listed would definitely signal Emerson's presence as a global hub, but I don't think the college is quite there yet from a student perspective.

Response: My ideal Emerson would enable my education in the ways I see fit for myself. I'm not a piece that fits into a puzzle; I'm a puzzle looking for my own pieces to fit regarding my college experience. While Emerson has fit in some of those pieces, there are a lot that I had to go seek for myself and some that I won't find while I'm here.
Africa

Emerson has lots of groups that the college that reach out into the local and global community, which is great. But I think that these opportunities should be more easily accessible to Emerson students. For instance, Alternative Spring Break is a fantastic opportunity to actively generate change, but not everyone at Emerson can have that opportunity. The college should consider looking into opening up those opportunities to create a more socially-aware community of students.

Response_ddqual: Emerson has the Kasteel Well program in the Netherlands, and I think it'd be really great to expand the college's European presence (starting in the Netherlands) instead of gearing students towards existing domestic programs in DC and LA.

Response: In 2014, I think it means that you've applied yourself and completed your studies, which many people can and can not accomplish (for various reasons for and against). In 2020 or 2030, I'd like to hope that a degree from Emerson is something valuable, whether you've just graduated or you graduated years ago. I think it's tough right now to fully assess what a degree means, though, considering the price of education and the overall economy.

I think this is a very real worry for a lot of Emerson students, but after talking with other Emerson students with similar thoughts, I think what it really comes down to is how a student applies themselves in the classroom and how they take what they learn to other aspects of their education and lifestyle. Some of my gen ed classes at Emerson have provided better insight into myself and my my studies than some of my major classes have.
Some but not all
Response_ddqual: I've had some incredible opportunities through Emerson to interact in a global network, and I think that while I have some skills and some educational background in how to work best, I haven't had the practice yet and therefore can't fully assess my skills. I'd like to think that I do, but there's not way to be completely sure.

Response: I can't think of a specific major, but probably something related to media in everyday; not typical media majors like film, radio, journalism, etc. but media in the sense of applications, online, social use, etc. Considering how smart phones, Facebook, Twitter, and the like are utilized by news, entertainment, and other industries, it'd be hard to ignore the rising interest in studies incorporating these every occurrences.

Technology has probably revolutionized how classes are taught, how professors interact with students, how students interact with administration, and everyone basically interacting with each other. Hopefully, these interactions are more beneficial to all with these advancements in technology.

First of all, I'm impressed that Dawn was able to add a marketing minor her senior year; wish I could've done that. Second, I would suggest that Dawn gives examples of how her different classes have involved things outside of the course content. Since she's a WLP, I'm sure there are times when Dawn had to think outside the box with her approach to a project that could be related to marketing.
Liberal arts college
Response_ddqual: Emerson brands itself as a liberal arts college, but sometimes that conflicts with the very focused and professional nature of some majors. I think if the liberal arts component is to be a "brand" of Emerson, it should be given more value instead of just being gen ed requirements for people to fulfill.

We've done it in LA with a glorious building-- now let's invest in our home base!  How do people think students can best innovate here using the face of our corner in Boston?

The culture that surrounds Emerson in Boston extends throughout the state of Massachusetts, down to New York ("The City") and up north into the more rural areas for cultural alternatives to the urban events that we find close by.  For example, a short and beautiful drive out to the western part of the state, past forests, rivers, and farms, brings you to the Fresh Grass music festival, where Emersonians could see Valerie June earlier this month.  We are so lucky to have such cultural riches all around us!

Response_ddqual:
I think that academic excellence relates in part to Universal Design, so that there is a focus on offering students multiple ways to learn and acquire knowledge, and also multiple ways to demonstrate what they've learned and can do with their new expertise.  Ideally, courses are designed (content and process)  to include/invite diverse modes of presentation and approaches so that students can have access to material no matter what learning strengths and weaknesses they each bring to the learning process. 



 In my opinion, learning how to learn, and adding multiplicity of learning capability is a crucial part of what students gain in college.  We all need to be adaptable lifelong learners in our current, rapidly changing society.

Response: Common Ground

Ideally, the College has streamlined processes and polices that support Joanne in changing her focus of study, so that she can be self-directed as she progresses through college.  College is a time of change and transition for students;  the College needs to support them as they redefine their goals along the way and then work towards acquiring and creating knowledge in their journeys towards their new goals.

I take risks often in my role at Emerson.  I find myself reaching out to people and asking them to collaborate on projects related to access for students, well, almost every day.  Often, I don't know the faculty or staff very well, if at all, yet I need their help to make something happen for a student to have access to academics, technology, or residence life. 



At first, I worried that I would not receive a response, or that people wouldn't be keen to step up, but pretty quickly, I realized that everyone DOES respond, and everyone is keen to collaborate.  That's the Emerson way, so it encourages me to take more risks and venture out of my area, for example, last year, I took the lead on having Emerson be the opening night host for the Reelabilities Film Festival.  I was way out of my comfort area, but I pulled colleagues in to help, and it was a great success!
Almost every day
Response_ddqual: In the Disability Services Office, we collaborate with faculty, staff, and professionals from outside of Emerson almost daily.  The work of the DSO crosses into most areas of the College

Response: Charles Wesley Emerson, founder of Emerson College
Many many years ago, I worked in the Costume Shop at Emerson.  I made elaborate headpieces for a production of "The Birds."
Almost everyday
Response_ddqual: I learn from the students every day.  I also communicate with parents, and I learn from them, too.  I learn about current culture, music, fashion, technology, film, etc. from my colleagues.  I learn a lot from our Graduate Assistants because they are super-smart and hip!

Response: My best learning moments happen when I meet with individual students and their professors for the upcoming semester.  We meet so that the student and I can hear the details about the course from the professor and determine what particular accommodations the student will need.  It's a joy to hear about the courses from the professors; they are so creative at designing the activities, the approaches, and the assessments-- and they're always totally passionate about their subject areas!  I end up wanting to take every course--  The students have a chance to advocate for what they need, and the professors can learn what will be supportive to them.  I am privileged to have a window into these interactions!

She needs to know that there is a lot of support here for students, and that her faculty will be engaging and helpful.  She needs to know that there are many things going on at Emerson, but to be a "success" does not mean that you have to be super-involved, just that you know (or come to find out over time) what your own goals are and that you are working towards those goals.  



She also needs to know that Boston is a wonderful place, (even in the winter) and that there's a lot to do within the range of the MBTA; she should grab an fellow adventurer and go out and explore.   It can be great to have adventures with new friends early on in the semester before people get too busy.
I hear about the exciting projects the students I work with are doing.

Response_ddqual:
The first part of this mission asks where the center of Emerson is, and people are mentioning both the LB and the Boylston/Tremont crossing area.  In the spirit of discussing EC's Center, we must critically consider the wrap-around public "art" that is at Emerson's heart: a faded, droopy, spatter-painted, and has-been piece of fabric.



How about giving students an opportunity each semester to create public art that represents their work and ideas about Emerson?  



Surely department/courses could collaborate on this: VMA- use stills from films, WLP-blow up powerful phrases from student poetry, theatre-recycle painted drops with dynamic lighting, Journalism -curate images to represent our goals of diversity, sustainability, innovation, etc.   



Students will think up better ideas than I can-- the point is that the heart of Emerson should visually represent OUR HEART!



Whatever funding this would require would be immeasurably worth it!
replies_ddqual:
I LOVE THIS IDEA! :D What better way to embrace Boston than to create beautiful public art for our city?! \\ Hey!  Someone identifying as "Emerson College" created a cause for a new banner in the Causes section!  Do you think they read my Soapbox post?



\\ What can I say smart people think alike! ;)

Response_ddqual: The students at Emerson deserve to have dogs come to campus for stress relief the same way that students at Suffolk, Tufts, Harvard and BU have it!  We can make a whole event out of it and walk the walk of caring about mental health and stress reduction at Emerson!

The current banner that wraps around the LB is an eyesore and damages our image in the community.  This corner is commonly identified as the center of Emerson; it's our opportunity to show ourselves to, interact with, and enhance our community.  I'm supporting this cause because it is a fantastic opportunity for the students to collaborate to create public art.

This cause speaks to the heart of Emerson's desire to be involved with the local community.  How wonderful will it be to know that Emerson students have helped others who would not otherwise have had the same opportunities to go to college?

Seems like a great idea.  One wonders why such a space does not exist already-- or maybe it does, in pockets?  Where do faculty and staff who teach currently gather, and if there truly is not a space for such a meetup location, then what's the cost in terms of fostering community, inclusion and cross-pollination?

I am pretty sure that students and staff would be surprised at the lack of technology to be found in Boston Public Schools as well as schools in the surrounding districts.   sharing our technology as well as staff expertise to get things started in those districts is a great way to further our values of community interactions, diversity and sustainability.

Craft groups are a great way to build community, and they promote mental health.  If staff/students/faculty were supported in gathering to create things, it would be resources well spent in terms of giving back to the community (charity projects), de-stressing, and meeting each other for sharing ideas in an informal setting.  Crafting is egalitarian and inclusive-- anyone can play!



Maybe most importantly, for students in the transitional period into adulthood, it's valuable for them to develop/persist with/take risks towards/gain satisfaction from-- hobbies!  it sounds mundane, but the happiest adults I know enjoy hobbies and other pursuits outside of their work.  What better place to explore/share them than here?

replies_ddqual: This seems so important that it's hard to believe that it has to be a cause.  The college is places a lot of emphasis on connectivity, community, and technology.  Electricity is the currency behind all that.\\ Thanks for the donation!

Response: I'm not sure how this question defines "meaning"? Perhaps a better word would be "value" (in terms of how the degree translates into a paying job). If that's what the question is asking, then I do think that a degree from Emerson will continue to increase in value, and perhaps have more value in the job market in 2020 or 2030, as the college continues to become more selective, engage with the city of Boston, and hire more full-time faculty.

Some but not all
Response_ddqual: One area that Emerson could improve on is language study. This is a crucial skill needed for success in the global world. Certainly nobody is going to learn every language, but simply being fluent in another language can open many doors, and also add to intercultural competency (the new buzz word at Emerson now). People want to see that you've made the effort to learn about them and their language, even if you are not perfect. Emerson could offer a Linguistics course that gives students the background in how different languages work, featuring different types of languages, such as Asian, Romance, Germanic, etc. It's true that translation programs are growing stronger, but with travel likely to become easier and more frequent, having a background from which to draw and the ability to make connections and learn will be crucial to success in the global world.
replies_ddqual: absolutely agree!

Response: Perhaps a major in Non-profit management, arts organization management, or non-profit consulting or fundraising. Boston has the highest ratio of arts organizations per members of the population in any city in the US. Emerson has, and will continue to be a leader in the arts, and a very high percentage of our graduates work in arts organizations (many in non-profits). For us to really be a leader, a major in arts organization management would help keep the many organizations that our alumni currently work for alive.

One hypothesis for what Emerson might look like in 2025 is that the classroom way of learning (with a professor physically lecturing) might be replaced by "pods" of students who watch video lectures by multiple professors from other schools, and then come together with several Emerson professors for a discussion and collaborate work, either in a common area or in a lab. As a staff member, I imagine there will eventually be faster, cheaper ways to travel by air, so that more staff will be going back and forth to Emerson's other campuses in LA, the Netherlands, etc.

I would answer that marketers must be persuasive writers and communicators. In addition, WLP (and other "arts-related" courses) help build the 4Cs  the new super skills for the 21st century, that is the ability to think Critically, Communicate, work Collaboratively and be Creative. :)

As you can see, the challenge questions in Mission 2 are a good deal more thoughtful (or at least require a lot more thought to answer) than the ones in Mission 1. What are the values of the stakeholders in the Emerson Community.



Even if we don't fully answer these questions, it's good to get more people thinking and talking about them.\\ I find value in the opportunity that the game provides to take some time to reflect on my Emerson experience, the college's strategic initiative and my role in shaping the Emerson's future. In many ways--technocrats cannot and will never be able to solve the world's problems.  Of course, neither will poets, alone, but communications skills linked with intentional and reflective community engagement experiences will go as far as anything.  There may always be a tension between the need to solve social problems and the desire for self-expression, but to the extent that Emerson allows for the latter while making the former an increasingly integral part of its students educations it may be more successful than many schools in graduating professionals who will make the world a better place.

Response_ddqual: The location matters less than the opportunity to have a truly cross-cultural experience.

Response: Presumably Emerson will always focus on arts and communication.  That is, it will never be a liberal arts college per se, and thus will never provide its students with a true liberal arts experience that comes with, say, the ability to integrate scientific study into majors in the arts, humanities and social sciences.  Nevertheless, Emerson today is known as a strong pre-professional school whose education is distinctly informed by many of the attributes of a liberal education, including interdisciplinary work and civic engagement.  This is not a bad niche for 2014 or, presumably, 2030, since social needs are likely to place a continuing value on the type of education Emerson provides.  The trick will (presumably) be continuing to maintain and even strengthen academic rigor as well as the civic engagement and entrepreneurialism that helps make Emerson distinctive and very useful to its students and to society at large.

No!  Philosophy always matters.  Studying philosophy, or the opportunity to study philosophy, is what differentiates Emerson from a trade school.  If Julian wants to become a successful film maker he will want to have a certain expansiveness of mind and educated reflection that classes in philosophy will help foster.
I don't know yet

Response: Classics.  Maybe this is offered now, I'm not sure.  Classics is supremely interdisciplinary and particularly lends itself to arts and communications.  That said, it could also help ground the Emerson experience in a liberal education.

2025 is not very far away--barely 10 years.  I'm going to guess that the tools may be different but the goals will remain the same.  The trick, as now, will be to integrate cutting-edge tools into teaching, learning and administering while keeping the institutional mission front and center and not getting side-tracked by the tools themselves.

Like many fields and professional endeavors, marketing can be very dull and reductive, especially, perhaps, marketing pharmaceuticals (I hope Dawn can find a better job!).  However, even marketing pharmaceuticals is likely to be more successful if the marketer is grounded in the arts.  I would say that the arts probably help Dawn in her verbal presentation skills, her communication skills in general, and her ability to see a larger, more connected and complicated picture of health and drug use (!) that will help her connect with potential buyers.  Also, while presumably her marketing material is designed by someone else, her background may help her move into that end of the business which may help with her professional advancement.
Something else entirely
Response_ddqual: Of the choices above, and at a distance (I'm not really part of the Emerson community), Emerson seems to me to be most like a professional school in arts and communication.  However, it also has many of the characteristics of a liberal arts college, including interdisciplinary investigation, civic engagement, critical analysis, etc.  It seems to me that the arts inform a broader educational experience rather than exist as an end in themselves.

The environment to my first six years at Emerson was not conducive to taking risks at all.  I was on the tenure track and was told very clearly by my chair, the dean and the VPAA what I needed to do (and what I should not pursue) to achieve tenure.  At the time of my hiring it had been a very long time since anyone in production had been granted tenure in VMA and so I towed the line.  Since getting tenure I have been able to explore a number of riskier opportunities in terms of teaching and scholarship that are more innovative and exciting that what I was doing previously.  Also the environment at Emerson has changed remarkably in the last few years so that has helped too.

I came to Emerson while I was finishing up my dissertation in anthropology.  It was a dry academic text.  Over the last 11 years I have developed my scholarly writing style.  While I still publish articles in a scholarly "voice" my latest project is a thinly veiled ethnography of the experimental film community -- using a very Emersonian voice.  I thank my students for cajoling that voice out of me.  



This picture is a cover for that book made by Emerson alum (who was my student at the time) Matt Shanafeldt -- he did it completely independent without being asked because he felt like it. Response_ddqual: Learning new things is part of why I became an educator.  I change my classes up every semester, I seek feedback from my students both in the middle and at the end of the semester and I leave myself open to changing a class if it isn't working.  The students are always coming in with different skill sets, different ways of learning, and I try to adapt my content and style to suit.  That said, I try to make the classroom a place where everybody feels invested in contributing so my students begin bringing in their own materials that fit the topics.  A few years back, I was teaching my students how to make pinhole cameras and my student created a digital pinhole set up.  I'm a silver process gal, so this was new to me then, but now i've expanded my pinhole experiments to include video and digital technology.

Response: It's hard to say.  I am a sucker for collective experience.  I love when students share their final projects, especially at the junior and senior stage.  There is such a sense of accomplishment.  I'd have to say my favorite moments are these culminating experiences when a class has been really really challenging and yet somehow all the students managed to make exceptional and/or inspired work -- and they know it!  It feels as though all the effort has paid off.  I also love when classes become really close communities of learners, with students helping and supporting each other.  This also feels like an accomplishment.

Maria is facing two huge hurdles.  It might seem like Boston and Philadelphia are both big east coast cities, but they couldn't be more different.  From the food to the accent to the weather (it is much hotter there in the summer much colder for longer in the winter).  All of this can seem overwhelming.  The first thing she could use is people from home who have been here a few years - other folks from the Philadelphia area to connect with who can tell her where to get a hoagie (you call them subs) or a decent bagel or whatever other treats from home she is craving.  They can also share their own experiences of relocating.  Then she will also need a mentor or two who share a similar experience of being the first in their family to go to college.  This could be a faculty member but it would be better if it was a junior or senior student as well as a support group of students like her.  There are a lot of things we take for granted, that students will have digital literacy for example. A support group run by advanced students could help incoming students navigate these kinds of differences.

I also love being connected with my students via social media and hearing about all the amazing things they are doing out in the world. Response: There's a certain Emerson way of solving problems that can be infuriating but can also be wonderful. Emerson's systems are, well, odd and cumbersome at times, but so often the people I meet who are behind those systems are really great. I find the staff at Emerson, many of them every bit as creative and talented as the faculty and students, are a great asset and frequently the reason why things get done. I appreciate that the current administration is looking critically at outmoded systems and starting to replace or refine them. It gives me confidence about our ability to meet future challenges.

Because I regularly teach Chekhov's short stories at Emerson, I would love the opportunity to have a deeper understanding of landscape and culture that informed his life and work.

Response: Unfortunately, this is a question far smarter people than I can't answer. As one of the characters in "The Spinning Heart" by Irish writer Donal Ryan says, "The future is a cold mistress." We do our best to anticipate, to hedge our bets for the future, but in the end, it's unknowable really. Perhaps the best thing we can do is be mindful of our current resources, thoughtful in our undertakings and commitments, fully present in our decision-making and responses, and willing to assess in a way that goes deeper than tradition dictates. It's easy to become complacent, to think the world will conform to our notions of it, but that's not how it usually works. I work in the fast-changing world of publishing, and I've watched as those who resist change get left behind. At the same time, I've also observed how those who mindlessly adopt new trends also make costly missteps. It takes courage, vision, caring, and keen insights to adapt to inevitable change.

Not at all. No matter how much changes around us, the human condition remains the same. People don't change that much over time. Things around us change, but the ways we're programed, our needs, desires, disappointments, don't. We read and appreciate ancient texts because they're stories about people. No matter what else Julian may be doing as a filmmaker, he'll be engaging deeply with what it means to be a human being and hoping his films succeed in communicating that to his fellow humans.
Yes

Other colleges have invested in labs developing sophisticated artificial intelligence and they've made astonishing progress in many ways over the last few years; however, as these "helping machines" mature, and we are living more deeply with them, as many people predict will be the case, there will very likely be another, more subtle layer of research that needs to be done to make those machines more sensitive, more capable of solving problems, more truly helpful in ways that technical advances alone can't fully address. Emerson, with its deep understanding of communication (and its disorders) and the creativity of its diversely talented populace, may be uniquely positioned to be a leader in such research. A major in developing the humane machine. Instead of Artificial Intelligence, Artificial Communications.

What campus? Shortages of space, costs of heating and cooling those spaces there are, congested roads, costly fuel, combined with the ability to communicate in a virtual space, may lead all of us to be working and meeting together on screens (and from across great distances) in the future.

The arts, in this case specifically writing (and reading), are disciplines that require empathy, a valuable characteristic for anyone who plans to work with other people. Learning to read a story or a novel is a complicated act, and it requires many abilities: discernment, close observation, understanding subtleties of gesture and tone, thinking critically, following nuances of character. Writing requires an even deeper engagement with the skills required to be a good reader with the added ability to put complex thoughts into language that can be clearly understood by others. It requires a high level of communication and should be valuable to any company that has a service or  a product to sell.
Something else entirely
Response_ddqual: I've given this question a lot of thought over the years since I've been employed here when trying to describe Emerson to people who don't know the college. It's all of the above and more. It's a place that provides cutting edge, hands on, applied knowledge of fast-changing industries. It's an incubator for creativity and performance, it's a place where professionals are trained, and, if students want a more traditional liberal arts undergrad, it's that, too. But it's also a place where very focused students come to gain not only knowledge, experience, contacts, networks, and skills, but also to acquire what I've come to think of as the Emerson patina, a certain confidence, a stance in the world that I find admirable.

Response: I'm prejudiced, of course, but I would be very happy if more of the Emerson Community knew about PLOUGHSHARES its internationally acclaimed and award-winning literary journal. Established in 1971 (at the Plough and Stars bar on Mass. Ave.) the journal found a permanent home at Emerson college in 1989 and merged fully with the college in 2008. In its 43-year history, the magazine has published the work of many now famous writers when they were first starting out (including Sue Miller, Tim O'Brien, Jayne Anne Phillips, and Robert Pinsky). It's been guest-edited by prominent writers like Tobias Wolff, Lorrie Moore, Charles Baxter, and Seamus Heaney, among many, many others. The magazine has subscribers on all seven continents (we just got our first subscriber in Antarctica this past year!) and is frequently cited among the top five most influential literary journals in the country.
replies_ddqual: Ploughshares actually got a shout-out from Stephen King in Under the Dome (the novel, not the show)

Response: As someone who minored in Philosophy, I believe that the ability to break down an argument and determine its merit is an incredibly useful skill to have. Also, the ability to see (or come up with) different perspectives of a situation helps not only in the workplace and in social situations, but also when writing characters in film, TV, or fiction. Knowing the motivations behind a character's actions is incredibly important to creating well-rounded figures that audiences will connect to. Look at something like Breaking Bad. Philosophy plays a HUGE part in the way that Walter White navigates his life, step by step. There are motivations behind his actions that we may not necessarily agree with but we can understand. (He may operate under a warped mentality of Kantianism while BrBa's viewers may identify more with Utilitarianism.) TL;DR: Philosophy/ethics IS important. As long as you have a good professor you will get a lot of out the subject. Don't brush it off just because it's a gen-ed.
replies_ddqual: I totally agree. I have a friend who's a Psychologist, but his undergrad degree was in Philosophy of all things.  But he took that to "learn how to think," so he says. That kind of flexibility is so critical in any highly-competitive field.\\ I completely agree. I had no idea what I was getting into when I took my first philosophy class sophomore year. I was nervous that I wouldn't understand it, or would be bored, but it opened my mind so much and pushed myself to think critically. Took 4 classes and a directed study in philosophy as a result. \\ Petra, what a great answer!\\ Thanks, Esther! I got a little overly passionate ...

Response_ddqual: The class size of Emerson was one of the biggest draws when i was applying to schools. The opportunity to have deep and meaningful discussions about, for example, pieces of literature that we're reading are far easier to do when you have a class size of 25 than a class size of 300. It also seemed to facilitate more individualized critique and help from the professors in terms of grading and improvement over the course of the semester. I also appreciated the creative freedom that was often attributed to final projects/etc, especially for gen-eds like science where, even if we won't necessarily be using biological key terms in our artistic endeavors, being able to write a story or make a film as our final project pushes us to use our skill sets in new, innovative ways.

Response: Common Ground

Freshman Year Me was certainly far less assertive and confident as College Graduate Me. That's one trait that Emerson's community definitely fosters -- a drive to put yourself and your work out there to be seen and appreciated, and sometimes critiqued and analyzed. I can't attribute that change to one particular experience. It was part of a process of growth that happened gradually over the 3.5 years I attended school here. On the flip side, the amount of talent, ambition, and drive in the student body of Emerson also forces you to question your own talents and goals. Sometimes this can force you to work harder (I would say in the Sophomore-Junior time frame this was the case), but other times it can be a bit debilitating if you let it (I think Freshman and Seniors who are comparing themselves to others in their first foray into workshop-style classes or the job world experience this more).

From someone who has been in a similar situation as Joanne, I have heard that it is pretty difficult to switch into a VMA program from an outside major (i.e. not switching intradepartmentally, like from Writing for Film and TV to Producing or something) without staying an extra semester/year to catch up on all the prerequisites. However, as a sophomore, maybe she would only need an extra semester or a summer semester to get it done. She could also create her own major or double major (the latter which would pose the same problem), though with either I think some guidance from the college's academic resource center would be necessarily and helpful. Perhaps she could also audit a course or two to get a feel of the new major while finishing off her gen-eds or something.
Almost never
Response_ddqual: I only started working here a couple weeks ago, and prior to that, when I was an undergrad student, we didn't have too many projects that required us to step outside the zones of our majors to complete them. The most collaborating I did was within a group project in a gen-ed class, but by senior year I was done with my gen-eds.

Response: Charles Wesley Emerson, founder of Emerson College

I did a directed study with a philosophy professor and one other student my senior year of undergrad. We each read sections of the books and "taught" them to the professor (and later wrote papers tying in what we had learned). It was a difficult course but it was incredibly valuable in the way that it allowed in-depth discussion on the material we were reading/learning, The one-on-one (or two-on-one) forum allowed us to really unearth the nuances of what we were discussing, and if we didn't understand a concept, we had the opportunity to hash it out from multiple angles until we understood it on a deeper level.

In my undergrad classes, I wrote a fair amount of fictional stories (usually at 10 p.m. the night before they were due) and magazine articles for assignments. In later years, I also did some book designing, which was a lot of fun. Most of those skills have morphed into hobbies and pastimes nowadays, but I still consider them extremely valuable and I'd love to be able to expand on the things I've learned and implement those skills into my current job. My most recent project is attempting to design movie tie-in versions of the Harry Potter books (for fun, not work). I've only finished one so far, but I really like how it turned out!

It depends on what we're qualifying as "completely new," as well, but there were very few times in my classes at Emerson that I was sitting there listening to someone rattle off information that I was already closely familiar with. Even if it was on a topic I already had learned about, there was usually a new perspective or aspect that would be shared, either by a classmate or the professor.

Response: I am most excited about being part of the Emerson Community when we are able to use our collective creativity and ambition to implement positive changes in the community, whether that be Emerson or Boston or underrepresented groups that could benefit from our innovation and inclusion.
An open mind, a willingness to learn, and a drive to succeed.

Response_ddqual: This is sort of a major-specific query, but as a WLP undergrad I heard a lot of rumblings about creating YA-focused writing/literature courses. YA is looking down upon so much as a genre, but it really has become so lucrative, and can induct a lot of social change by directing your work toward young audiences. Also, because we are so focused in engaging in successful business strategies in our respective creative fields, investing in YA and having classes about the genre and its transformation of pop culture over time would be incredibly useful. (This train of thought also applies to the fantasy genres, which of course have a bigger problem in terms of lending themselves to longer pieces of work than writing classes typically allow.)
replies_ddqual:
I believe there used to be a kids/YA lit concentration within WLP...which is why the Library has a children's book collection\\ Yes, at least there were classes.  Jack Gantos used to teach here.  Who else wants to see a childrens/YA concentration here?\\ I mean, there's been such a large insurgence of YA lit in recent years. I think it would be useful to explore what made those books/series so successful and why they resonated so much with young audiences.\\ There has been a start back to Genre styled writing... There is a Noir class being offered, and even the Utopian/Dystopian lit class can be seen as a move towards a more welcoming atmosphere for various genre classes. I speak as a fantasy fanatic...



(Also both classes are awesome.)\\ Kevin Miller is wonderful, and one of the fiction professors I've had that didn't shy away from genre fiction, which I appreciated. I understand that, given the structure of the workshop classes, it's hard to world-build in 15 pages or less effectively, but maybe that means offering more classes based in long-form writing. Novel-writing seems to be the most effective means of generating income, yet the fiction courses are overwhelmingly focused in short story writing. And I understand you need to start small, learn the basics then expand on it, but maybe a move toward more genre writing can be coupled with a few novella/novel-writing classes (which I think would be useful regardless of a genre focused curriculum).
