Response: Charles William Eliot, 19th-century president of Harvard University

Why do you only kiss me when you're drunk?

I remember meeting you for the first time

And thinking that you seemed cool

I remember thinking, "I want to get to know that guy.

We would be great friends."

And that's all I wanted to be...

Your friend

And then we became kind of sort of friends

The kind that acknowledges each other on the street outside and asks how are you

And seems like they actually want to know the real answer

The kind that when you run into them at a party and you're both drunk and I'm "So happy to see you I'm so glad we're friends and let's spend more time together"

But in the days that follow we go back to being polite

Why do you only kiss me when you're drunk?

Flash forward to the night before everything changes

No not the night where you drunkenly kiss me for the first time and I'm confused but I liked it

Not the night when I realize I want you to kiss me after listening to your beautiful voice softly crooning while a guitar plucked seductively by someone else's hands plays in the background

No, flash forward to the night where I see you and you see me and yes you're drunk but I'm not and we run to each other and you pick me up and spin me around and say I'm so glad we're going to be together for the next three months.

No we aren't dating

We're going away with 80 other people on a European adventure

This is the night before everything changes because if neither of us got on that plane I wouldn't be writing this poem

Why do you only kiss me when you're drunk?

That night

When you kissed me

I thought it was a fluke

Yes our lips touched over and over and over But still

I thought it was a one time thing

Something that I should hold onto

But also forget

But then you kissed me again the next week and not just once

And while it was happening all I could think was

This isn't a fluke, he wants to kiss me as much as I want to kiss him

But when will he kiss me sober?

You held my hand that night and for some stupid reason even though I thought I learned my lesson after all the years of heartbreak

I thought it meant something

But then you barely talked to me all week

Why won't you kiss me when you're sober?

And not only sober but even high

It's only when you're drunk

It's like there's something in you that says "It's only ok to kiss her when you're drunk"

You know usually people use being drunk as an excuse to be more honest about how they feel

They use it as a shield to keep from getting hurt

"I said I loved you last night? Lol my bad I was so drunk I had no idea what I was saying I didn't really mean it"

Crisis averted

But you?

I don't know why you only kiss me when you're drunk

Do you like me more than you let on and you don't want to risk what we have as friends?

Or do you only like me when you're drunk?

Because sober kissing

When you kiss someone sober there is more involved

That means you do like someone as more than a friend

Maybe it's just as a fuck buddy

Maybe it's as a potential Significant Other

But for whatever reason

You don't like the idea of only being platonically associated with them

You wouldn't intentionally kiss someone you don't like when you're sober unless you're an asshole

So do you like me

Or do you only think I'm interesting when we're both drunk and our bodies move in unison when we dance

Your hands on my waist, mine on your shoulders

Holding our audience captive because they've never seen anything so raw and intense yet lighthearted and playful?

Would you only sober pity-kiss me?

If you kissed me sober would you realize you actually don't like me as much as you thought?

What if you kissed me sober and it was great but nothing happened afterwards?

What if something did happen but somewhere down the line you get bored with me and I add yet another failure check to my list of former flames?

You know what?

Nevermind

Don't kiss me when you're sober

I don't know if I can handle it

Let's get outta here

And maybe get a drink or two

Response_ddqual: I honestly think we need to amend Tap and Go for who has access to buildings at night. As an off-campus student who spends a good amount of time on campus, if I felt unsafe and wanted to enter the building, I wouldn't be able to because I don't have building access. We need to be better at making students feel like the school still cares after they move off-campus
replies_ddqual:
I like the Tap and Go Program and find the ivisitor site to be very user friendly! I am curious if others think it is problematic to allow students to tap into the lobbies of the residence halls?\\ Another problem is if, as a student, I had a production that went until Midnight in the Cabaret, and I needed that quick bite from the Max around 11PM, I can't get back into the Little Building without someone getting me.



I love what Tap and Go has done, I just feel that for off-campus students that need access past 11PM, whether it's for access to a convenience store or to their workplace/meeting space, it needs to be looked at.\\ Too add onto Jasmine's comment...even for on-campus students, it takes a good 10-20 seconds to actually read your ID and unlock the door at night, which is a long time if you feel unsafe. How can you safely escape someone harassing you if there's a delay getting into the building?\\ The fact that off-campus students (or any students) feel unsafe waiting on the street at night to get into an EC building is out of step with the College's focus on Violence Prevention and Response.  



Could the tapping be adjusted so that they can at least get into the lobby areas of the school's buildings?\\ Absolutely! I just think its completely unreasonable that the school is trying to keep out people who don't go to Emerson by keeping out everyone who doesn't live on campus. Off-campus students are people too!

Face masks for students who are allergic to dogs? We're talking 15-30 percent of the population: http://www.aafa.org/display.cfm?id=9&sub=18&cont=236. 

Why should students wear a face mask? Should students have to suffer with these symptoms: http://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/pet-allergy/basics/symptoms/con-20028932 I speak from experience. I'm allergic to many breeds and when I'm in a room that a dog had PREVIOUSLY been and had been cleaned, I am unable to breathe and I don't have asthma. This is a liability. 

Also, allergies don't work that way. Dander is not easy to clean. Seriously, either consider getting so-called hypo-allergenic breeds or do not do it. Nice thought but not thought out.
replies_ddqual:
This little one would work: http://www.petstew.com/border-terriers.html\\ Or a Cubanito...

http://havaneseri.com/images/havanese_puppies_2.jpg

\\ Cindy, because the organization we're trying to partner with is volunteer-based, it is likely we cannot request only specific breeds. We are working to make sure the dog-occupied space will be contained, and cleaned to prevent severe suffering. We will be recommending persons with allergies invest in medications, but cannot provide medications. Face-masks are likely doable, with apologies available free of charge if this is insufficient. Thank you for raising this concern, and backing it up with statistics. This will affect our planning, but not our resolve to see this come through. (As has been pointed out, many other institutions have solved these issues. We will find a way!) \\ The dog pictured in the promotion for the cause is a hypoallergenic dog (poodle) so I don't think it's outside the realm of possibility to work to accommodate people with allergies.\\ Our hope is that the impact of the therapy dogs on campus would be no more severe than the presence of sight or hearing assistance dogs, who have access to buildings like the Library because of the ADA. That is one of the reasons that we want to hold our program in a non-residence building and in a space that can be closed off. \\ As a dog lover who has allergies, if we can work this out it will be a win-win.

Response_ddqual: Think about what this means. Please put your coins toward something that helps PEOPLE who need our support. Community does not mean your little world. Geez. I'm disappointed with the so-called causes that people have come up with. What's next, our own personal barista?
replies_ddqual: Well...community can also be anything that draws our community closer together.  It's not limited to charities or outside causes.  If it helps Emerson students and/or faculty get to know eachother and become a tighter knit community, then in my opinion it's a worthwhile cause.\\ That's one way to look at it. But I've found that when people work to help others it builds a strong bond that lasts a lifetime. \\ Some causes that were advocating to donate the money to a good cause were rejected because they weren't sustainable/long term, unfortunately.\\ Which "causes" do you find problematic? I know mine is for popcorn (which obviously isn't going to make the top three that get funded) but the idea is to encourage engagement in the cinema where we encourage dialogue on important issues (like the panel you served on for Documented). I would have rather raised funds for a student community engagement manager, but that wasn't likely to attract enough interest.\\ so . . . dragon boat team! we are Emerson people, interacting with people from the larger community, practicing collaboration/teamwork, giving Emerson visibiltity in the community . . . though we're not a charity, I feel we are doing good!\\ To me a cause should benefit others, not just ourselves. I consider concessions and charging stations amenities. The charging stations idea is a bad one because everyone has a way to charge their devices. There are outlets everywhere and most of us have nomophobia  the fear of being without your mobile phone. It's real. Look it up! So why would anyone need it. It will be obsolete in a year, anyway, as there will likely be some new way to power our mobile devices. If it were solar, I'd see it as a cause as it would help conserve energy. Concessions aren't something we should push, either, because it's junk food. Popcorn is an empty calorie snack as are most other concessions. It won't bring more people to the theater. Good programming and a time slot that makes sense for students is more likely to bring in an audience.

Innovation means opening up and being more fluid. It means not getting stuck in the past and stopping new things from happening. There are small pockets at Emerson that bleed into the surrounding communities. I'm thinking of the Engagement lab, the FYWP that works with Emerson staff and high school students, and the theatres. It's a start, but Emerson could innovate more if we could break free from some of the ideas that are holding us back like 4 hour classes in a classroom, divisions between faculty, staff and students, outdated ideas of how learning happens and our physical and geographic limitations.

Response: Africa

This is a tough one. I think that the value of a college education changes from person to person based on individual goals and motivations. Some people have very specific career goals and they expect a college degree to help them along their professional path, while others enter college less certain of what they want in their post-college life. Emerson students have a reputation for being very career-driven and I imagine that many expect their degree to support their larger goals. I think that all educational institutions should strive to help expand the horizons (intellectually, artistically etc.) of their students.

I think that many of the events on campus that are open to the public (like panel discussion and the bright lights film series) engage in discussions of important societal issues. These events give community members an opportunity to learn from artists and scholars and reflect upon their views. I think that Emerson should continue to engage with important issues and provide students with opportunities to engage with various communities (through projects like alternative spring break facilitated by the office of service learning).

Response_ddqual: I wanted to choose not to add a specific point, but I guess that's not an option. While there are many wonderful places in the world that I would like to visit, I think that (for me) learning is more about the people and ideas that I work with than the geographic location. That said, I wouldn't mind sitting on a beach while engaging in professional development.

Response: Student-Instructor Ratio, Opportunities to do original work, Opportunities to collaborate with academic or professional experts in your field, Diversity of student body, Co-curriculars, Diversity of faculty and staff
Response_ddqual:
All of these factors seem pretty important. Many of them are also interrelated and contribute to a positive learning environment. In my mind Academic Excellence is tied to the quality of interactions that take place both in and outside the classroom between and among students and faculty. 

- A smaller student to instructor ratio allows instructors to have more meaningful interactions with individual students. 

- Diversity among faculty, staff and students enables us to create a community that values different perspectives and helps all of us to learn from one another. 

- Finally, providing students with an opportunity to engage in hands on work and interact with experts allows them to more fully explore their own interests and goals.

Response:
My best teaching moment at Emerson was a Film One class.  I used to give these really hard exams that asked students to memorize a ton of technical information about 16mm film, cameras, and lenses. But I realized that all of that information was available to the students all the time and that they didn't have to memorize it at all -- they needed to know how to get the information, and they needed to know how to apply the information to problems they encountered in the field. 



So I gave a new exam that had lots of the same technical questions and some additional problem sets but allowed the students to use any possible method to get the answer.  They could work together, use the internet, call their friends, call film labs, use books they had with them - anything, really.  There was one catch, they had to get all of the questions right before they could check out equipment for a project. 



This was so unusual that the exam day became a real game -- it was fun and lively as students tried to figure out the answers and then shared them.  And they did great!  If I ever get to teach the class again, I'll try this and see if it works out.
replies_ddqual: I love this!  Film One PLUS an exercise in information literacy!

I'm most excited about being part of the Emerson Community when I walk across the Common and see our banners outside our buildings.  Our corner of the world represents promise and potential.  It  is a place of energy, imagination, and creative production.  I feel part of a noble enterprise, helping support the people who create the culture of the present and future.  Writers, performers, artists of all kinds, scholars and critics -- our faculty and students produce our culture, shape our community dialogue, question our comfortable beliefs, and connect us to a wider human web.  It's a great privilege to be part of this community and I feel it everyday.  



And when this community of faculty, staff, and students comes together to make the educational environment richer and more vibrant, that is truly exciting.

I don't think Julian has anything to worry about. To think that philosophy doesn't matter is to say that we, as human beings, have stopped evolving as a species. The idea behind philosophy is often to get a firmer grasp on what it means to be human and how to better connect with the rest of humanity. The next philosophical breakthrough could be right around the corner, and it may yet change everything we thought we knew about how to live, how to act, and how to simply be.

Response_ddqual: If there's one thing that being at Emerson has taught me, it's that being persistent is often the difference between success and failure. So many times I've been frustrated with not getting interviews or not getting into that one production I really wanted to get into, but if I let that get me down, I would never know what it's like to succeed. My time at Emerson has shown me that. With that said, however, I know that there is still a lot more for me to learn, and I know I will by the time I get my diploma.

Response: I think that in the next 20 years or so, college programs will offer a major that has some sort of focus on social media, since it has become a big part of many people's lives.

I would imagine that social technology would allow for more instantaneous communication than ever before, and that there would be more classes taking advantage of Canvas' many features. I'm not sure to what extent technology will dominate our lives by 2025, but I'm sure that by that time, people will find some way of balancing out technology and reality. The campus would probably be more automated, and security would be both tighter and more streamlined. It's an unknown future, but that's part of the fun of it all.

The arts allow people to interact with the rest of humanity at the most basic level. When you learn about the arts, whether it's visual or performing, you learn how to appeal to the widest audience possible. All the world is a stage, after all, and the people who do well benefit from being performers or artists of some kind.

Response: To me, being socially responsible means contributing to your local community in a respectable way. Going out of your way to give spare change to someone standing on the sidewalk, holding the door open for an elderly gentleman on your way into City Place or Dunkin' Donuts, just striking up a conversation with someone sitting on a park bench. All of these things may not seem like much, but they can mean a great deal to the people you meet. I have a philosophy in life: if I can make one person smile in a day, I've had a successful day.
replies_ddqual:
There are lots of ways to think about social responsibility, but at the base, how do we treat and value those who are immediately around us every day?  Patience, listening to others, courtesy, and appreciating differences are habits of mind that radiate both inward & outward.  



No matter where Emersonians go in their lives and how successful they are in their work, if they carry those daily habits of mind with them, then the College has done a good job.

Response: My best learning moment at Emerson. That seems like an easy thing to identify, but in reality, it's not. I guess my best learning moment at Emerson isn't really a moment, but a sudden realization: if you keep at something, you will get somewhere. For example, during the fall semester of my freshman year, I tried out for 2 a cappella groups and was rejected by both. In the spring semester of freshman year, I tried out for the other two a cappella groups; I was rejected by one, and accepted by another. I was actually contemplating not trying out for a group during the spring, but I decided to throw myself at the a cappella wall to see if I would stick. Similarly, I interviewed to be a writer for Reel Reactions 2 semesters in a row, and this semester, with more reviews to my name, I got hired to write for their website. I stuck with it and I was rewarded. That is my best learning moment, when I relearned that if you stick with something, you'll get something out of it in the end.

I live there.\\ Twitter, word of mouth, and emails. Sometimes the tack board too - something will catch my eye.\\ Interesting - lots of people saying word of mouth. Centralizing does make it easier to keep track of what is going on, and probably presents a more consistent and well-thought-out message to the community. Response:
Well I know that the CD department trains speech therapists, and as our society begins to have a larger aging population support for people with speech and swallowing issues will increase.  Emerson has one of the best programs for this.  



Society problems are hard to categorize, would providing excellent journalism, film making, and theater arts solve problems?  It might help create vehicles for transformative thought and ideas, it might help create movements that promote green initiatives, peace, as well as entertain and inspire others.



Does inspiring, and or providing entertainment to others help address society's problems?  I think it can if handled correctly, and hopefully we train communicators that further important causes.

I believe a degree from Emerson College means you are part of a community of communicators, whether it be journalists, speech therapists, film makers, writers, actors, ....  The community is all current students, alumni, faculty, and staff.  Emerson has a strong network that is always growing.



In 2020 and 2030 I don't expect the focus to have changed from communication arts, but the median and the method might evolve.  We will hopefully have a more global presence with campuses beyond LA/Boston/Netherlands.  We will probably have a much higher international student base, and generally have more diversity in Faculty, Students, and Staff.  I think the community base of Emerson will be ever present, and hopefully will become stronger as we grow.

I think learning in general what ever it is a great exercise for the mind.  I would tell Julian not to worry, enjoy being able to discover new things by taking an elective course, hone his academic skills including writing and critical thinking.  Sometimes it is not what you learn, but learning that is important.  Who knows he might even become entranced by the likes of Kant or Rousseau.
I don't know yet
Response_ddqual: The truth is I do not know yet, as I do not know what it takes to succeed in a global world.  As I learn more about Emerson's initiatives globally I think I will be better able assess this question.  I certainly think I am respectful and interested in other cultures, I enjoy interacting with international students and Faculty, and I welcome the opportunity to learn more about this.

Response:
Online Content Producer-



Most of our entertainment will be end up being broadcast across the internet, in the style of Netflix and other companies. Producers who can gear their content to an online audience will be huge.  Online games and movies will become merged, and allow the ability for audiences to become a part of the film.  Content Producers will need the skills to produce this material, market it, and keep up with the demand of the audience.  Which will probably be huge since most viewers will binge watch most series in a couple days.
Liberal arts college
Response_ddqual: I think Emerson is a Liberal Arts school, it provides a well rounded education with a focus on what ever your major is, but with a commitment to produce graduates with a good solid educational foundation.

Response: Technology will be ubiquitous.  Classroom technology will be wireless, high resolution, probably in 3D.  3D printing will be common, and maybe we will be able to actually 3D print most of the technology we need on campus.  Learning will hopefully become more cooperative and socially motivated.  Meaning classrooms will be everywhere, not just in rooms where the teachers hold weekly meetings.  Online activity will certainly increase.  Network speeds and computer processing will increase, allowing for immersive technology.  Maybe our own Holodeck.  :)
replies_ddqual:
One of my grad school profs was someone who had in the past predicted strongly that immersive virtual reality would be huge in ed technology. He played a clip of an old speech of him for us so that we wouldn't get cocky about what we thought was going to be the Next Big Thing. His analysis of why virtual reality hasn't really taken off is that people get unexpectedly seasick! I'd love a holodeck, as long as it's a non-puking one.\\ I can see the ad copy now: 



I-IoloDek.

Now with no puking.\\ Puking costs extra.\\ and we will still be employed - yay!

Wow...that is taking me way back as I got my undergraduate degree here, so we are talking 1983 ish...of course the courses I took meant a great deal to me.  I really loved the video production courses as well as the poetry writing.  I worked in the EDC at the time on Beacon Street and really loved the people I worked with and for.  We even had a cat Gizmo that lived there, (I guess he scared away the mice).  I guess I would say I learned to be committed to and responsible on the job, and really enjoyed helping others working in the EDC.



I also really loved and still love how GLBT friendly Emerson is.  Coming to school in the 80's, recently coming out, it was great to be in an environment that embraced you as who you were.  It was very freeing.



When I came back to Emerson as a staff person I learned a great deal from the current students, who were doing amazing things, and were (and still are) so creative and talented. I continue to love how gay friendly Emerson is.  Emerson is becoming so very vibrant and even more open, which I really love.



So--regarding taking risks....I would have to say Emerson lets people take the risk to be who they are, and find their talents.  I know it allowed me to do that.

Response_ddqual: I really love when students dress up for Halloween.  It makes the day so festive.  Question to those that will partake in costuming, what will you be going as this year?  Also where do you like to trick or treat in Boston.  I hear Beacon Hill has some great places to go.
replies_ddqual:
When I was a student at Emerson I went trick or treating on Beacon Hill once. I dressed up as the Statue of Liberty. (Bonus: my last name is Liberty). 



I felt awkward trick-or-treating though. Every time somebody opened their door and saw it was 20 year olds, you could tell they were exasperated. They gave us candy, but it was clear they'd rather be giving it to kids, and thought what we were doing was pretty silly.



In retrospect, it was.\\ Beacon Hill is amazing for trick or treat. People there start planning in August.



Unrelated story: when I was a kid my babysitter told me a story of when she went trick or treating as a teenager. She knew that no one wanted to give candy to a teen, so when the door opened she was ready as a ghost: sheet draped over her as she knelt down. Once she got the candy, she stood up, waved, walked away.\\ As a trick or treat hander-outer, I hate when adults go trick or treating. They should be giving out candy, not taking it from, well, babies.\\ I always respected idea my freshman class council came up with a few years ago.. ..the students went trick or canning. They would get dressed up in costumes,  went to Beacon Hill and asked for donations of non perishable food items for the Greater Boston Food Bank.  They got to dress up but for a good cause!  They also got lots of candy too for their good deed. \\ I went trick-or-treating on Beacon Hill two years ago and some guy refused to give me and my friend candy about 20 minutes into the ordeal. We were so upset that we didn't want to knock on any more doors so we just went to CVS, bought our own candy, and went home.



I'm not really big on parties in general so trick-or-treating was really my only means of celebrating. College is such an awkward in-between time for people who don't have their own houses to give OUT candy to trick-or-treaters, but if you don't like parties you're kind of stuck sitting at home.



Sharon, I like the idea of trick-or-canning! Though I'd imagine those cans would get really heavy really fast, haha.

Dawn's knowledge of writing shouldn't only be applied to meetings, she can also craft persuasive advertisements or scripts for advertisements so that her marketing firm can have a leg up on the competition. Response_ddqual:
Many of the classes I have taken have stressed the professional/business qualities of their respective fields; in the WLP workshops we stressed craft, and how to write a great literary manuscript/great play and etc. In my radio classes, we either were producing our own packages every two weeks, or learning about the business, or about overall radio (as an introductory course). So, I view Emerson as a professional school.



Even the workplaces at Emerson treat you as professionals; working in the Campus Center I've collaborated with numerous colleagues and we (attempt) to maintain a professional atmosphere to what we do, while still connecting with our clientele. One of the things I try to inform people about at the Campus Center is Spacebook.



What is Spacebook you ask?



It's events.emerson.edu !



Which is our online booking portal; almost every room on campus can be booked through that website, and you can check the availability of the space you want; imagine checking to see if anyone is in a piano room before going to Piano Row on a cold winter's night. You can stay in your PJs with your blanket and hot cocoa instead of being grumpy and sad that a piano room isn't available after walking from paramount.

it was a lot of fun learning about deconstructing a bike. I love using my hands to create or make something, and I've never learned about bikes before.



I think if Emerson partnered with anyone, it should be someone who creates something with their hands. I'm all for writing, as a WLP, but I personally love woodwork and carpentry, and using my hands to build or make something, which is why I like bikes not bombs.

Innovation means constant reviewing of policies and procedures, and challenging the norm. We look at policies and our established materials every year in the Campus Center and the Cabaret; we also challenge the norms with what we produce and always challenge groups to do the same. With how we use the Cabaret for the Haunted House or Laser Jam, we show how the space can be utilized in creative ways. We saw this last year as a few student performances utilized a sort of tent for their performances, which was awesome to see.



I love how we look at previous designs, and see how we can improve upon them.

By working in the campus center and the Cabaret, I see numerous performances, lectures, talks, and anything and everything else go through our spaces. It's awesome to see how culture is transmitted and how we all process that. Not to mention on Emerson's Boston campus there are numerous panels, lectures, and guest speakers throughout the year on numerous topics.



My freshman year I went to a lecture by the (I believe) ex-CFO of a major computer company, and it was a lecture on social media and marketing. I'm a WLP, but that was a great time. While it may not be "culture" as we commonly see it, it is a venue for how culture is disseminated a lot in our technologically advanced society.

My biggest learning experience so far has been helping plan some of the Campus Center events over my three years here. Laser Tag last year had me as the project lead; I learned about all aspects of developing a show and how to put in a non-traditional event into our black box in the Cabaret.



This year the Haunted House has me traveling to places I've never been, such as Assembly Square, and to various small shops all around Boston. Response: My first lesson at Emerson came the day I moved in. I had no idea what I was getting myself into when I stepped out of the car to a mob of guys and girls jumping up and down in tutus and wigs and face paint. But I didn't run, I just turned to my dad and said,"Well it can't get weirder than this." I couldn't imagine what people walking past the school could possibly be thinking. But Emerson College students didn't care what they thought. And that was the lesson I took away. It is ok to be you whether you fit the energetic Emerson mold or not.

Its really easy to fall in over your head at emerson. There are so many great things to do, but understand you have 4 years to experience them all. College is a once in a lifetime experience... have fun with it.

Response_ddqual: I feel that although the ProArts program is a great idea, I feel that it is restrictive to "art." Though I am aware Emerson is a very artistic school, I honestly feel that this sometimes restricts my ability to expand my education. I also have a interest in chemistry and forensic science that I am not able to take courses on. I feel Emerson should do a Pro arts style program with Boston University or Boston College for elective credits.
replies_ddqual:
Also, Emerson is a part of this...



http://www.boston-consortium.org



...Not sure how great it is though.\\ The ProArts Consortium is a great idea but I feel like it isn't as advertised as it should be.  Most of the time when I mention it to students they have no idea what I'm talking about and those who have tried to take advantage of the program have run into a tremendous amount of problems with billing, credits and grades.  It'd be great if Emerson could work out the kinks with the Consortium already in place and work to expand our network to other schools for students with varied interest.

Response_ddqual: WERS is a 24/7 operation with a crew of committed students and professional staff who pitch in regularly to keep it an award winning organization and pride of the community. As an Emerson alumnus, now WERS staff member, I've remained an avid listener. Now I'm able to introduce others to the power behind the microphone with a grand view of The Boston Common to top it all off!
replies_ddqual: Love the photo of "ON AIR"

Response: Thom Mayne

I think Emerson is perceived by the world as a liberal arts college with creative and driven students. A college with a good network of alumni. I like this perception of Emerson but I'd also like the college to be perceived as having an awareness of what is happening beyond our school and that the students have been trained to make a difference in not only their field but in the world.
Steady stream of international artists, communications experts, and scholars visting our camupus, Higher percentage of international students, faculty and staff, Other
Response_ddqual: I think a third main component would be offering more language classes. In order to be actively involved in the global community we need to learn how to communicate. Having a student body that knows other languages and cultures is part how to engage in the global community.

Response: This photo is from the year I was on Core Staff. Emerson is the place that pushed me to be a better professional and broadened my world view. It's the place where I learned to truly grow with the help of an amazing support system. My ideal Emerson is a college where students are supported as they try out new opportunities that push them to become better professional and at their craft.
Africa

Emerson helps to address society's problems by educating students on the world around us. There are always fascinating panel discussions being brought to campus that help to spread awareness which is a first step to addressing a problem. I would like to see more hands on engagement from the Emerson community. We are great at online activism and spreading the word but sometimes not as great with the hands on actions.

Response_ddqual: As a student I wished that I could have studied in Paris to enhance my french skills because the school doesn't offer any upper level French programs and I had taken french since first grade. Today I'd love to go there too to be able to enhance my language skills as well.

Response: I think a degree from Emerson in 2014 means having the connections of the Emerson alumni. Our alumni network is just as important as the education that we received here and that is something that will continue to hold value in 2020 or 2030.

No, he's not right to worry. In order to make a meaningful impact on the world around us we must be able to expand our thinking to different possiblities. A philosophy class allows him to explore other ways of thinking and theories. All elective credits are useful in some way because they help you gain new perspectives on the world and how you approach problems as well as your craft.
Yes
Response_ddqual: In my Intercultural Communications class I learned how to word across cultural differences. I've learned how to interact on a world scale by being shown different cultural aspects around the world at the castle and through art in Boston. For example, I had many class trips to the MFA where we would look at different exhibits that gave me an inside look into other cultures. Mostly Emerson taught me how much there is to understand and learn abut the world around me.

Response: I think in twenty years there will be a publishing design major that focuses on print as well as digital design in publishing. There are so many students who already use the classes here at Emerson to make their WLP major have a design focus it seems like a next step.

Everything is submitted electronically and there is no need for printing. A lot of collaboration occurs online using technology (I'm thinking an even better version of good drive). It changes the way we connect and makes it easier to gain access to information. Students don't come into the office as much to ask questions because they know where to find it online.

My arts related classes helped me to foster my creativity and forced me to come up with innovative ideas. Because of these classes I am able to use different perspectives to help create solutions and foster creative ideas. Marketing is a very creative field, you need to know how to engage people and you can only do this through understanding what makes people stop and think. All aspects of life require creativity and that is where my arts-related background helps me.



Re: The Bio of this Empathy Question

There is not possible way that Dawn could have double majored in WLP and Communications Disorders AND pick up a Marketing minor. I know many students who can't even figure out a way to double major. Especially those who are majoring in Communications Disorders because that is an extremely intensive program. Many of the students majoring in Communication Disorders don't even have time to take on minors.



Also, she would not have been able to pick up at Marketing minor during her Senior year. I know several students who tried to minor in Marketing starting during their Sophomore year and were not able to get into the classes they needed by the end of Senior year and ended up having to drop the minor. There aren't enough classes for everyone who wants to minor in Marketing to do so and while it is feasible to pick up some minors Senior year, especially if you have already fulfilled many of the requirements, Marketing is barely feasible to minor in for those who start ahead. 



I think this question says a lot about how it's very different to be on the student side when it comes to majors and minors. As students we experience many road blocks in what we can and cannot do. Students have a whole lot of freedom but not as much as many of the staff and faculty think they do.
Liberal arts college
Response_ddqual: Emerson is a liberal arts college at heart but it's a little bit more than that because of how Emersonians are always pushing boundaries.

Emerson definitely has a very vibrant community. It is a place where you can challenge yourself and engage in discussion with people who share your interests. The thing about Emerson is that no matter what you love, you will find someone else who loves it too.



I'm unsure by what he means by "college vibe" of Boston. Emerson is near other colleges but you don't always interact with students from other colleges.There are lots of college students to engage with but you need to actively leave downtown Boston to hang out with them. 



I would tell me that you should go to the school that you offer you the very best opportunities to thrive in what you want to do. Response: Working on team projects, Working with mentors
Response_ddqual:
When I was a student most of my knowledge was expanded through working directly with mentors and using their feedback to pursue my own knowledge.



As a staff member working on team projects allows me to expand my knowledge base by getting feedback and hearing solutions of problems from all different perspectives.
replies_ddqual: Working with others is so important for success

Response: Student-Instructor Ratio, Opportunities to do original work, Opportunities to collaborate with academic or professional experts in your field, Co-curriculars
Response_ddqual:
Student-Instructor Ratio - This was huge for me as a student because I learn through discussion. The class sizes make it possible to have meaningful discussions and get personalized feedback from Instructors and peers.



Opportunities to do original work - Original work is the crux of learning to use your creativity. The professors who allowed us to do creative work with a critical element allowed for the most meaningful academic experiences. 



Co-curriculars- How do you let the student figure out what they can truly accomplish? Have them do it themselves. Co-curriculars are what allow Emerson students to flourish. They learn from hands on experiences. It doesn't mean they don't make any mistakes but it does mean that they learn how to effectively problem solve.



Opportunities to collaborate with academic or professional experts- This allows for the professional feedback that students need to succeed when they leave Emerson.
replies_ddqual: Absolutely Jess!

Response: Common Ground

Switching from Writing, Literature, and Publishing to Writing for Film and Television can be an feasible switch especially during Sophomore year when she could still easily fit VMA pre-requisites in her schedule but it also may not be possible. VMA is the hardest of the majors to switch into from what I've understood from people who tried to switch into it but I've known people who have made the switch happen.



The College should allow her to switch because by sophomore year in the WLP department she would just be getting into her writing classes as most of freshmen year is general education requirements except for one writing class. Interests change and the college should allow that to happen. I understand how there are VMA requirements which may make it difficult but for Writing for Film and Television the emphasis should be on the writing anyways.



I have also seen people who were unable to switch use the Writing, Literature, and Publishing courses to their advantage while using extracurricular activities and helping with their friend's projects to get the film background they need. WLP has a screen writing class and a novel into film lit class that she could easily take. She could join THREAD and SPEC to get screen writing experiences while helping with other projects. I've seen people use this method to get what they needed when they couldn't get the support from the academic side of Emerson.



The College should be allowing more fluidity in switching majors. At the present moment it feels rigid and I know some people feel stuck in the major that they come in with. At Emerson we present as a very focused school but even the most focused people can change their minds once they get different experiences. If you've never tried writing a script before, you might not realize it's what you actually love. Emerson is nurturing in many aspects but doesn't always allow students to explore interdepartmentally which is a shame. As I student I minored in Photography which was the only thing in the VMA Department that a student could minor in if they were not within the department. A student shouldn't have to create their own major to be able to explore different aspects of the academic community.
replies_ddqual: I agree! We should be more connected between departments

Response:
This past weekend I was in my hometown wishing my best friend goodbye as she is living in Paris for the next nine months. We started reflecting over how much we have changed over the years and I know that much of my change has been due to the Emerson environment. 



I am from a small town. My high school graduating class was 84 students. The environment was very restricting and it was sometimes hard to engage with the community outside of my town. My teachers tried to foster my need for creativity and knowledge but there was only so much that could be done without the peer feedback that I needed.



Emerson's community help me grow immensely in so many different ways. My view of the world has changed and I think more critically about the world around me. When I go home there are things I didn't notice before but I notice now. Such as how the people of my town use language and word choice. I'm not sure if I'm more of a risk taker because of the Emerson environment but I am definitely thinking more critically about my choices. I allow myself to test more ideas because I know that I can only grow from learning about how something fails. I have learned that my creativity is something that I need to be actively using because only through the creative process can my ideas be fully realized.
Almost every day
Response_ddqual:
When I was a student there wasn't a single day where I didn't share ideas or collaborate with a friend who was in a different major than me. While I often bounced ideas off my fellow Writing, Literature, and Publishing friends when it came to my writing, I also made my friends who weren't writers read my stuff. I collaborated on film projects and helped with marketing research studies. I listened to the ideas of my friends from all different majors and gave them feedback. They did the same for me. Basically every single day of my undergrad career.



As a staff member my collaboration with people outside of my department is again a daily thing but that is mostly because I am working with students. I'm helping students connect with organizations, plan field trips and fundraisers, and giving advice. I also am constantly helping student organization advisors with similar things and most of them are not in my department.
replies_ddqual: I love working with you!

Response: Charles Wesley Emerson, founder of Emerson College

During my Senior year I worked on my BFA Thesis while working on a Photo Practicum project. Both turned into studies of my hometown. While my BFA Thesis was stories of my childhood deeply rooted in place, the Photo Practicum was a visual study of my town. Both where called Thickly Settled.



One of the stronger essays of my thesis:



Saint Denis



Sometimes I feel like I grew up in church. Spending my Sunday mornings kneeling on a hard stool, head bowed, elbows propped up on the pew in front of me. Muttering the same prayers that we said every week, not bothering to use the little red books with their faded gold crosses on the covers because I had them memorized. Walking slowly up the alter for communion where I kneeled and waited as the priest came with the wafers and wine. That one sip of one sweet wine the only alcohol I was ever allowed by my parents, savoring it on my tongue as I made my way out into the small hallway and back into the main church. I grew up sitting up at the front of the church in the childrens choir. Performing for the Congregation as the Angel who told Mary she was blessed with a child in the annual Christmas pageant. I grew up in a church but I grew up in the wrong one.

The lifeblood of any mill town was the church. In Douglas we have a quite a few. The largest is probably the Congregational church that sits in the middle of downtown and down the street is the Methodist church all decked out in red. But the real church of Douglas is the Catholic church, Saint Denis. A large brick church just a few mintues from downtown, past Soliders field and a left onto Manchaug street. A nice white statue of a saint standing outside.



Most of the kids in my school went to Saint Denis but I attended an Episcopal church in the town over. They went to Sunday Mass while I went to the Sunday Service. They grew up in CCD while I went to Sunday School. They ended

 

their Lords prayer with but deliver us from evil while I went on to say For thine is the kingdom, the power, and the glory. For ever and ever. Amen. Our services basically exactly the same, except I am Protestant and they are Catholic.

I am pale and covered with constellations of freckles. My face is round and I have a bit of a double chin when I smile. My hair is light brown with bursts of red. My Irish side is always shining through. My Dad one hundred percent Irish, his ancestors coming from Ireland only a few generations before him. He grew up in a small house with three other brothers and a sister in Pawtucket, Rhode Island. Pawtucket being home to a large Irish population and has an excellent Saint Patricks Day Parade (I know, I marched it with my high school band five years in a row). He also grew up Catholic.

My mother is the cause of my Episcopal upbringing. My father wasnt a practicing Catholic when they got married so they got married in a Protestant church. I dont think my Grammie approved much but since my mother was the one who went to church we ended up Episcopal. We started going to Trinity and after a while my mother even got my dad to start coming.

My dads family jokes with him as they have all remained Catholic. His eldest brothers wife, Aunt Debbie, being the most religious of them all. She used to hoard bottles of Holy Water in her house that she had specially blessed by the Priest (to this day I am still unsure of what she did with it). One anniversary of my Grammies death we went to a Catholic service at Aunt Debbies church that was dedicated to my Grammie. I pretended I was Catholic and got communion. On the way home my dad stopped by one of his favorite bakeries. It felt like a little glimpse into the Catholic life I could have had.

 

I know Saint Denis as well as Trinity. I could make it from one end of the large finished basement to the other in the dark if I needed to. A spent a lot of time volunteering at the church with my Girl Scout troop, at least one of my leaders was always an active member and the rest of my troop spent their Sunday mornings (or sometimes Saturday nights) there. We would clean around the alter or organize the room behind the stage. There were Girl Scout bridging events held on the stage in the basement. The church also hosted many town functions. I went to a Christmas Eve Service on year, staying seated while everyone else went to get communion. My Baccalaureate was held at Saint Denis right before I graduated high school. While I didnt officially go to Saint Dennis it was a central place of my childhood as a gathering place for the town.

I remember the first time I went into the church and discovered the little bowls of Holy Water that stuck out from the wall. Trinity didnt have such things. I splashed my small fingers into one of the bowls and brought them towards my lips. I couldnt figure out why the water was there or its purpose. It was explained to me that it was Holy Water but that was all. Every time I went back I would dip my fingers in the water hoping that something would happen.

When I try to explain being Episcopal it kinda always goes like this: Its as close to being Catholic as you can get without actually being Catholic. We just dont care about the Pope or pray to the Saints or think that the wafers at communion are literally Christs body. Other than that, its basically the same thing. So, I was as close to having the same religious beliefs as my dads side of the family, as the other kids at school, as I could possibly get but never quite there. Always a step removed.

 

Every time I explained how Episcopalian beliefs different from Catholicism to my peers I found it hard to explain my own beliefs. I dont necessarily align with my church either because I believe that there are many pathways to God and every religion is a way to get to him. I dont think it matters if you are Catholic, Protestant, Muslim, Jewish, Hindi, Buddhist, any incarnation of religion or spirituality. I believe that these are all just different pathways. I think these beliefs partially stem from watching Joan of Arcadia as a child as that television show preached a similar message and partially from the fact that I dont believe that a true forgiving God would write someone off for following the pathway to spirituality that fits them. I believe in heaven but sometimes the idea of eternal life is exhausting to me and I wouldnt mind if when my life on earth ends that it really is the end. But there are so many complexities to what I believe that it was always just easier to say that Im Episcopal and leave it there unless someone inquired further.

The priest at Saint Denis for a long time was Father Bill. As Mary says, the man wanted to retire but the congregation just wouldnt let him. He was a strict Catholic priest in a very old school way. The Catholic church was starting to change but on many issues my classmates started to feel uncomfortable. I was told, in hushed tones of horror, that one service they passed around papers to all the girls in the church. They were contracts Father Bill wanted them to sign saying that they wouldnt get an abortion. My friend Madilyns grandmother tried to get her to sign it but she refused.

While this was happening at Saint Denis the pastor at my church was driving away members of the congregation with his anti-gay stand. The Episcopal

 

church had just elected a gay woman bishop and Father Sutton was not happy about it. His sermons made me and a lot of the members of the church uncomfortable. I shifted awkwardly in my seat a town away from my friends at Saint Denis who were in a similar situation.

Because I didnt go to Saint Denis the fact that I was religious often remained unseen by classmates. Every so often it would come up in a class discussion about religion or Protestantism. I would give my spiel about how Episcopal was as close to being Catholic as you could get without being it. But often my peers couldnt seem to believe that I went to church just as regularly as them. My attendance was unseen and therefore unrecognized.

And some days I wish I had grown up Catholic. I often felt like I missed out on things growing up because I wasnt part of CCD like it seemed the rest of my grade was. They bonded over the absurd things that they did during their CCD classes. I got confirmed when I was in eighth grade, I kneeled in front of the church as the Bishop put his hands on my head and shook my whole body. I felt like he was trying to shake all the sin out of me. All of my classmates who went to Saint Denis got confirmed during our senior year. They went on a weekend long retreat and on Monday it was all they were talking about, even the ones who didnt take much stock in their faith expressed that the weekend had been an emotional one. I sat at the lunch table with nothing to contribute. I wondered if their bishop would shake their heads so hard it felt like he was trying to shake out their sin.

I sometimes feel like a traitor to my Irish heritage because Im Protestant.



I want to feel connected to my classmates as well as my heritage. My religion,

 

even though it mirrors my beliefs better than Catholicism, separated me from my town as well as my history.

I had always dreamed of visiting Ireland and I finally got to visit Dublin.



But the entire trip I was torn between my Irish looks and my Protestant upbringing. The tour guide talked about the wars waged between the Catholics and Protestants in Ireland. How Protestantism in Ireland is just a side affect of British Imperialism. I had already read so much about it in an Irish Literature class I took as an online elective in high school but it felt so real being there. I felt like it was my fault. The Protestant part of me wiping away the Irish Culture. A traitor of the heritage I cling to as an American who is always looking towards her ancestors for identity.

When I went to Saint Denis I always imagined what it would have been like if my dad had been a practicing Catholic. Its a weird thing to want to be Catholic when they were historically less powerful than the Protestants. The Irish Catholics having to scrap for jobs while the White Angelo Saxon Protestants took charge. Just like in Ireland. Yet, in Douglas it was the reverse. I was the minority and I wanted so badly to fit in, in some little way.

Living away from Douglas I dont attend a church in Boston. I have my beliefs but Ive never summoned the courage to walk into a church alone, even though most of the churches I pass have the Episcopal sign out front. Church, to me, is about community and while I know that churches want to welcome new members into their folds I always feel like I would be intruding on an already established community. So, on Sundays I worship through doing the things I love and thanking God for all the good things in my life. The people I keep in touch

 

with from Douglas dont often go to church either. In that way we are now the same but many of them have lost their faith, if they ever had it to begin with. I believe in God and I liked my Sundays at Trinity but there will always be a weird feeling about what could have been.
replies_ddqual: Great essay Jess!

Response: Almost everyday
Response_ddqual: I've found it impossible to not learn something every day here at Emerson. It's a community of people who are always sharing their ideas and stories. In that way I am always learning something new. I also find myself discovering something new as I try to find better methods of doing what I do. There is always something to learn here if you're paying attention.
replies_ddqual: I love learning new things from my peers! It drives me to work harder

Response:
My best learning and teaching moments have come from the Undergraduate Orientation Program. As an Orientation Leader I got to hone my skills as a leader of my peers. As a student I got the opportunity to be a part of Core Staff where I was guided by some of the best mentors around. I was constantly challenged to re-think my ideas when I was given critical questions and a few rounds of "absolutely not." Through the mentorship of Sharon Duffy I learned how to think about problems from more angles than I originally considered and how to challenge myself to do better. Through the mentorship of Jason Meier I learned that good ideas can be great ideas if you think about what their purpose and intended impact are. I came into Core Staff thinking that there was only one correct solution to every problem and came out knowing that everyone has their own solutions and that doesn't mean one is more valid than the other.



As a staff member my biggest teaching moment was helping the Core Staff while they worked their way through Orientation Week and helping them understand that just because something was done in the past that it didn't mean it was an expectation and there was always a way to make something more meaningful and have a bigger impact than it had before.
replies_ddqual: #LIO

Response: The primary communal & meeting place for Emerson students at the College's Back Bay campus (130 Beacon Street)

In order to make her way at Emerson Maria needs to know the best places to find information. In order to get involved with Student Organizations she needs to know about the Org Fair that happens during the first week of school and about how the Office of Student Life is full of ways to engage in the community. She needs an overview of the different Emerson Departments and what they offer. The Orientation Program connects her to those resources but the information also needs to be accessible and easily obtained throughout the year. Maria can't be expected to remember every department on campus and where to go, she needs to know the best ways to find the departments she needs.
replies_ddqual: Student Life is a great resource!\\ We try our best!

Response:
I am most excited about being a part of the Emerson Community when I get to experience the wonderful accomplishments of the students. Whether it be seeing months of hard work pay off during Undergraduate Orientation Week, seeing a show written and produced by students, or watching a film created entirely by students. I am most excited when I am blown away by the innovative ideas and concepts that Emerson students come up with an implement. 





My "most Emerson" experience was the time when I got to help plan the Undergraduate Orientation Program as a part of Core Staff and was able to push the boundaries of what I thought was possible for me to accomplish.
replies_ddqual: #LIO\\ #OL4Life is so true, Jasmine!\\ You were great on Core Staff!\\ Jess! Yay!\\ Jess! Yay!

Response_ddqual: Student Life Office - most of my time is spent in here as I'm the temporary staff assistant in the office. Even when I was a student I spent a lot of time in the Student Life Office because of my involvement with the Undergraduate Orientation program. This is a space where students can learn how to get involved with the Emerson community and learn how to use their strengths to make our community better. Nestled in the Student Life office is: Off Campus Student Services, Multicultural Affairs & LGBTQ Resources, Student Activities, and the Associate Dean of Students. Steven, Tikesha, Jason, & Sharon are the staff members of the office and are always meeting with students for a variety of reasons. Whether it be to help them with a program they're working on or just to give some good life advice, the Student Life Office is a welcoming community that was my home as a student and now (temporarily) as an employee of the college.
replies_ddqual: Also, Piano Row in general has always been my building because I lived here as an undergrad for my freshmen year and half of my sophomore year before going to the castle.\\ Best office ever!

Centralizing the location would be helpful and then a running, streaming list by date or category would be great to see.

Response_ddqual: I think academic excellence is achieved through a number of factors, including providing students with the right balance of academic challenge and support. Students need to stretch beyond what is comfortable in order to grow. Educators call it the zone of proximal development. It's space just beyond our comfort and understanding. It is in this space that habits of mind develop that represent true academic excellence. Academic excellence also means bringing learners from diverse backgrounds together where diversity of thought, diversity, of perspective, and diversity thought exists. This is one of the most powerful ways to develop critical thinking among students.

Response: The most powerful learning moment for me at Emerson occurred last Spring when I watched Emerson faculty, the maintenance worker class, Emerson students, and Colombian artists sitting together in Common Ground in Walker 10 during an art exhibit. Regardless of role, we sat together as we listened to a young women sing a song she had written, "Here I am." In that moment, we were all truly present as each individual in that space unveiled their own reality in the world. Truly the best kind of learning experience - when the head, the heart, and the soul are in alignment. A moment that Paulo Friere would call a space in which critical conscientiousness occurred.

Maria needs connections and the ability to gain the cultural capital she will need to be successful in college. Establishing a good rapport with her faculty is probably one of the most important things she can do. Where does support for faculty currently live at Emerson?  Is it in the departments, or is there overarching support in Academic Affairs, or does it live somewhere else?  More importantly, what kind of support would be helpful and focused directly on the issues you and other faculty face?  



I ask because In Disability Services, we work with faculty all the time, asking them to make accommodations to give students access to course content and process.  There is often an accommodation that requires the faculty to go above and beyond, and we make every effort to be available and provide resources.  But obviously, this kind of support is only part of the faculty role.  



What are best practices at other institutions for faculty support?  \\ well Diane..a great question. Some support lives in departments and some in AA. But for me as a Liberal Arts faculty it has been rather limited unto now because we were spread across the college. In terms of what kind of support I'm sure it varies based on the faculty memberfor me Id like more time for research not just a sabbatical but more respect for research time overall. That is what gives my teaching its credibility after all. Id also like more library resources devoted to faculty needs ( I'm sure there is a lot that I don't know about) and id like a good research assistant ( a stunt who could be trained to do research up port). but i know other faculty must have other needs.

thanks for the question tho..its great one!

Response: Common Ground
I have no idea.

My first year teaching I had a very disruptive student in class who threatened my physically. I took it to the proper authorities based on the instructions given. I was told to " be more understanding" in froth of the student and the student was put back in my class.  I lost faith in the ability of the college to 1. Protect its faculty or the students 2. Protect a learning atmosphere 3. Provide a valuable leaning experience. The focus on "good " teaching as a measure of success made me take less risks in pedagogy and curriculum building. The the lack of focus until recently on academic excellence for faculty made me seek creativity elsewhere. Finally, the Gordian knot of administrative and beauracratic red tape at Emerson makes one expend much energy in getting around and through the system, not in other ways. So I would argue that I have become a less daring teacher, a less intellectually stimulated researcher, and a person who is disinclined to take important  and valuable risks.

Emerson needs to grow a lot to be suitable for the demands you should place upon it. \\ God, Tulasi, what a horrible experience. Response:
There is a lot of talk about higher education is a bubble and will no longer be necessary in ~the future~ when we all will teach ourselves things and won't need teachers or degrees. I think that not everyone is an autodidact, so we will still need teachers in some form or another. More cynically, I think humans will always need to create some sort of pecking order / way to categorize people, so we will still need some way to say "I am vouched for by ___", even in 2030. It may not be a degree in the sense that we now know it, but I think there will still be a need.



A degree specifically from Emerson - that depends on the choices we make now! I think Emerson is in a relatively good position: there are not a ton of places that offer the things that we do. I think that our "hook" as creative and artsy will help distinguish us and help us stay relevant even as smaller colleges offering more traditional educations merge or go out of business.

If it's something he is interested in and he has enough knowledge about his chosen field from his other classes, then he should absolutely take and enjoy philosophy. What you study is in the long run less important than the habits of mind that you learn from doing the studying: how to approach something new, break it into chunks, learn it in a way that works for you, and create something that synthesizes your new way of looking at the world.



Besides, from a fully functional perspective, the philosophy class may be the edge he needs in the interview to prove to his prospective employers that he is an interesting person who is always interested in learning.
I don't know yet
Response_ddqual: Not a student, so not sure how to answer. I would hope they would say yes!

Response: If Emerson stays true to its current mission of educating creators, I think they will be creating in ways we cannot yet dream about. Telepathic Opera? Wearable Technological Fashion?

Oh boy. I hesitate to make predictions since futurists are usually so hilariously wrong (where is my damn hoverboard already?). 



I think there are a couple of competing trends in the ed tech industry that can take the future in different directions.



Less favorable:

Apple / Amazon / Google / Microsoft / textbook publishers continue with their battle to create walled ecosystems containing proprietary content. As a consequence of the battle, they end up consolidating so that there are a max of two giant companies that can offer everything you want with enormous convenience... as long as you play by their rules. Targeted advertising is ubiquitous and seen as normal and helpful. You pick a system to use (hardware and software and shopping and etc), and it is almost impossible to switch. In this vision DRM and copyright laws are very strong and dramatically limit the re-use, re-mixing and sharing of content. IT in this vision would be supporting the two ecosystems, probably hiring entirely different staff for each one. In this future, people are largely consumers.



Potentially more favorable:

The push towards creative commons, open textbooks, open source software continues. It becomes normal for every program to have an extensive API (APIs allow you to transfer data in and out of programs). You own your data, and programs/businesses have clear rules about how to export it. In this future IT is busy creating new ways for people to make sense of all this information - but in this vision the faculty and staff also have a lot more IT expertise and take on much of the work themselves. The problems with this vision are a) how will businesses make money and b) it is a lot more work for people to build their own things than to rely on large companies to build for them.



I think in either case, the days of computing/technology belonging only to IT are over. Everyone in the future will have a higher level of technological competence (10 years ago I couldn't have imagined doing half the things I take for granted now). One of the main questions that remains is if we will be competent in using tech to shape our reality, or if we will be competent in knowing what buttons to press from a bunch of pre-selected options.
replies_ddqual: Spoken like a director of instructional technology and TIE alum :-)

Response: Thom Mayne

I think that Emerson is perceived as desirable. Recently, in the news, it was named as one of the top film schools in the country, which is incredible! I am so honored to know that I am able to get my education in film at one of the top colleges in the nation. Emerson is definitely seen as somewhere students want to end up. People know how great of an education students get here, because of Emerson's wide variety of resources and connections.
Steady stream of international artists, communications experts, and scholars visting our camupus, Higher percentage of international students, faculty and staff, Other
Response_ddqual: Emerson is a global hub for higher education for a various number of reasons. First of all would be the steady stream of artists, experts, and scholars who visit the campus. Another example of how we are a global hub would be the high percentage of international students and staff. At any given time, there are Emerson students learning across the global, and sharing their experiences with other people. Lastly, the so-called "Emerson Mafia" which allows any Emerson student access to resources across the globe. Emerson is able to connect any or every student with an Emerson alumni who specializes in their major, which is something not all colleges have.

Response: Emerson to me means not stereotypical. What I like the most about Emerson is that we are not your average college, we are innovative, collaborative, and creative. In my first week here, I was feeling a little under the weather. I was having difficulty seeing my potential in my classes and alongside my peers. I knew that I was accepted for a specific reason, but I was feeling like I wasn't good enough. Then, after reaching out to one of my professors, I was reassured as to why I chose Emerson over any other college. He told me that here at Emerson, everyone comes from a different background, and the most important thing is learning through each other. Nobody has the same exact experience, and we aren't expected to come here knowing everything there is to know about our major. Here at Emerson, we are expected to learn not just from the teacher, but from each other.
replies_ddqual: now THAT is a good teacher.

Response: Africa

Emerson is able to address society's problems in a number of ways. First of all, Emerson has a handful of activist groups which individually support various causes. We are able to educate ourselves on issues in today's society and come together to discuss how we can have an influence over these problems. Students themselves are also able to address society's problems through through the arts and communications. One of the most overlooked ways would be through theater. Plays and musicals are often an outlet in which actors portray characters with serious issues or dilemmas that people face in real life. It is often a way how we learn how to cope with our emotions and problems, especially in Greek theater. Other forms of art, like film and television, writing, and photography are fantastic ways to subliminally address many of today's societal issues.

Response_ddqual: If I could reach out to anywhere in the world from Emerson College, it would definitely be Los Angeles, California. There is no doubt that LA is the center of all things film and media. The state itself has the largest population of film students. This would be the area in which I could thrive, as it has hundreds and thousands of resources for film students like myself. Here, there would be an infinite amount of possibilities for me and would be a possible place for me to launch my career. Although it is far from home, LA would be the perfect place for me to engage in professional development.

Response: I think that in 2014, having an degree at Emerson means much more than people understand it will. A degree from Emerson opens up your world to a whole new set of resources. With the amount of connections Emerson has, any student's possibilities are endless after leaving this school. Many students who go out to L.A. wind up with an internship before they've even graduated; some even with jobs. In the near future, the desire to graduate from Emerson will only mean more and more, with more connections becoming established every single day.

I think he is definitely right to worry about this to some extent. If you're questioning why you are learning something, or even if you're learning anything at all, that can definitely be an issue, especially since Julian is paying to attend Emerson; he should be getting everything that his money is paying for. But, what Julian may not realize is that he doesn't need to be a philosophy major for this information to help him out. As a film major, Julian can take the information he is learning from this philosophy to enhance a film project he is working on. Maybe this class helps him see a different perspective on philosophy he never thought of before. That's the nice thing about Emerson; no matter what class you take, in some way it could benefit you no matter what you major in.

Response: I'm hoping that in the near future that Women's, Gender and Sexuality Studies will somewhat transform more into a major, with more classes about the topics of feminism and gender equality. I truly believe that many people have a misconstrued idea about the definition of feminism and have taken it to completely wrong level. There are many interesting ideas that have become developed because of feminism and the desire for gender equality, and there are many types of branches of feminism that are unknown to most people. Women's studies is a popular topic that more people are becoming interested in everyday. I think that a major in Women's studies would be beneficial and desirable to many Emerson students as we all strive for equality in our environment.

Technology is a huge part of what makes Emerson the school it is. We have completely unlimited resources to any type of equipment we need. If we can't find it here, the school is able to locate us to another school or place in the area that can allow us access to that material. In the year 2025, I can see technology here advancing faster than ever. Whether that means more resources or top of the line equipment, Emerson is always striving to be better and to have more up to date materials. With technology advancing on a day to day basis, Emerson students and faculty are striving to become more familiar with what comes out everyday, and to become masters at handling it.

Graduating from an arts school has better prepared me for any job than any other type of school could. Not only do I have a strong background in my area of focus, but I am a well rounded candidate. Being at Emerson prepared me because I was required to take courses not only that fit my major, but also other classes to help me become a better, well-rounded student. I have been taught communications skills and ways to think more creatively. Not only am I skilled technically after leaving Emerson, but also artistically. I am able to see things more than one way as a result of my education at Emerson college.
