Response: Founded in 1949

Innovation means wanting to be one step ahead of the game. It means exposing yourself to what is happening in the community and finding interesting ways to improve how those cultures or processes are currently progressing. Helping out communities that are in need or starting new programs to enhance the living conditions for certain groups of people are just a few ways that we can be innovative. For Emerson, it means doing what seems to be impossible to others. Emerson kids never back down from a challenge and are never seen settling. They always want to be improving and being one step ahead of everybody else. Being innovation at Emerson is never a challenge because we are doing it everyday.

I participate in the culture of the city I live in at Emerson by exposing myself to people and places away from my school. I could choose to sit in my dorm room all day and only leave  to go to my classes, but instead, I explore the city and the different experiences it has to offer. For example, instead of going to eat at Panera or the Dining Hall, I could choose to go to a local mexican restaurant, or explore what there is to offer in Cambridge. Exploring food options away from campus can help a student become exposed to what the city has to offer. Also, I expose myself to culture in the city by attending concerts and theatrical performances in the city. By surrounding myself in situations that I've never experience before, I am able to get a new perspective on what the citizens of Boston are used to and what their culture is like.

Response_ddqual: I believe that the heart of the Emerson campus is right in the Boston Common, across the street. It is the heart of campus for various reasons. First of all, the Commons is accessible to all students and the public, helping connect the city of Boston to Emerson students in just one of the many ways that it can. Also, the Common is a great background and way for students to engage themselves in their schoolwork. Whether it means interviewing people in the common, or shooting a film, the Common is a great resource for Emerson students.

Response_ddqual: For me, service learning was one of the most important parts of my Emerson career. Service Learning helped me put the skills I was learning into perspective with the real world. How can we use our talents and expertise to have a positive impact on the community? What is it that the community needs? Who/what is our community? How has history impacted the plight of communities today and how can we avoid these mistakes in the future? Can we use our creativity to imagine a better world for all people? These are all questions explored in service learning courses and service-based extra-curricular activities that are essential to our human growth and to our careers after Emerson.

To be deeply invested in its surrounding community, Emerson needs to use its skills and expertise for the betterment of the community. Service Learning classes like Bob Nesson's Documentary for Social Action and interactive projects like Community PlanIt are great ways for Emerson to use its dedication to innovation to invest in its community. Students, staff, and faculty gets hands-on experience in their fields while learning about their community, and the community receives a needed service or product. Emerson's new focus on entrepreneurship is also a great idea to use Emersonian ideas to invest in the community.

I try to attend lots of social and cultural events on campus and in the city. Festivals, movie screenings, discussion groups, lectures, charity runs/walks, free events, and lots of concerts. Response_ddqual: I consider the center of campus to be the Walker Building. It is the hub of campus because it contains classrooms, the library, meeting spaces, and offices. However, I also consider it the physical center of campus because I think our reach as a school goes just beyond the Boylston Street block. Our students work with organizations all over the city of Boston, they live in almost every neighborhood, and the impact of their work reaches every corner of the city. Switching majors is easy, but can put you rather behind track. I switched majors as a sophomore and had to take summer courses to ensure I graduated on time because not every required class is offered each semester. Also, there should be advisers to help students transition to new courses of study. I felt like I had to figure things out on my own.

Being involved with community service, service learning, and civic engagement throughout my time as an Emerson student made me the person I am today. Specifically, getting involved as a Jumpstart volunteer made me realize the exponential impact that one person can have on the world by spending their time teaching or doing something for other people. As a student, I felt encouraged to do and try new things, even if I was on my own. I feel that I've taken that sense of adventure with me into adulthood and do the same now as a staff member. There is always so much being offered here on campus (and in the community) that once I find something that interests me I can just go for it!

Response: Charles Wesley Emerson, founder of Emerson College

I am proud to be a collaborator on many projects during my time as a student and staff member at Emerson. Some of the things I am most proud of include: Jumpstart, Alternative Spring Break, Emerson Action Day, Emerson Peace and Social Justice, and Earth Emerson's Veggie Food Fest.



(This is a photo of my first Alternative Spring Break group in 2008. We built the deck on the house behind us during our clean-up and rebuilding efforts in Waveland, MS.)

Response: My most amazing learning experience at Emerson was being a volunteer in the Jumpstart program. Through volunteering 15 hours per week, I was able to change the life of a Roxbury preschool child that started the school year behind her age's learning benchmarks. Together, we read books, worked on writing our letters, played games, and allowed our creativity to infuse her learning. By the end of the year, I not only helped her be prepared to be successful in kindergarten, but changed my own life as well. It set me on a career path in the nonprofit sector, which led me back to Emerson last year to work in the Elma Lewis Center for Civic Engagement, Learning, and Research to help expand some of the programs, activities, and opportunities I had when I was a student that were so meaningful to me.

Get involved! Attend the org fair and find the groups and clubs that really speak to you and your interests. These people will become like your second family at Emerson. You will also want to get to know your academic advisor and the career services center, which can help you map out your career trajectory by developing a person path at Emerson. Also, take the time to meet with and get to know your professors - they want you to succeed, and they are really cool and accomplished people too!

My most Emerson experience was the time when I took my daughter to Mo's Restaurant in Burbank for lunch and told her that if I stood on our table and asked the 200 people there if they went to Emerson, half of them would raise their hands. She asked me to please not do that. So I didn't. As we left, there was a guy wanting in line ahead of us for the parking attendant to bring him his car. I asked him how much he usually tips, and he answered with a Boston accent. I said: "You are from Boston; I work at Emerson College." He said: "Get out! I went to Emerson!" My daughter was impressed.

When I tell people I work at Emerson College, people usually know something about us--so we have name recognition.  they generally mention WERS, or the film program, or famous alumni, or, lately, Ron Burgundy. I think those are great things to be known for, but I'd also like Emerson to be recognized for our more scholarly and/or socially conscious accomplishments--for example, the Elma Lewis Center, ArtsEmerson, the Communication Disorders programs, and, of course, the Emerson College DRAGON BOAT TEAM.
replies_ddqual: My initials are GMF and I approve this message!

Response: Steady stream of international artists, communications experts, and scholars visting our camupus, Higher percentage of international students, faculty and staff, Regularly cited in the press about our specialty fields, Other
Response_ddqual: If by "global hub" we mean being a center for activity and ideas, I think the website, and all our media outlets, including WERS, can play a part.  But to be a global hub, a school needs to be internationally attractive.  International students, faculty, and staff on the game:  do you feel welcome here?  Do you feel included?  what barriers or obstacles do you face here? Also, a renewed emphasis on Emerson College's original focus on oral communication might make us competitive with other schools seeking international influence.  What if Emerson offered programs in intercultural communication, including ESL and language study and translation, and even going beyond that, with international studies focusing on conflict resolution, negotiation, etc? So, for specific accomplishments I would add innovative and expanded international student and scholar services--language programs--and exapanded international and global studies course offerings and scholarship.

Response: Africa

Emerson is a microcosm of the larger society, so as we work to develop creative solutions to some of our community problems, we can model new ways to address these problems in the greater community.  For example, if we can come up with innovative and effective programs to change our campus climate around the issue of sexual assault, other colleges could follow our example. Our mission is education, so we can have the greatest impact on society's problems by developing resources and strategies for educating people about problems.  Dr. Pelton's gun violence initiative is a good example. I'd like to see us extend our efforts outward also, however. I believe education is the best tool for changing the world, but it has to reach beyond academia. Emerson students could be active in designing programs and workshops for younger area students. This would be a win win for Emerson and for the surrounding community.

Response: I think an Emerson degree in 2014 means you have spent 4 years at a school with positive name recognition--a good "brand". Beyond that, it indicates you have completed your course work--and you've had opportunities to build relationships with faculty, staff, and students, pursue activities and classes that relate to your interests, develop transferable skills via activities and electives, and do some awesome things--like live in a castle, or study in L.A., or  play Quidditch.  or be on a dragon boat team.  BUT . . . these are opportunities.  Did you take advantage of them?  Your degree doesn't indicate that.  That's up to you and your resume. In 2020 and 2030 . . . hmmm . . . I hope the meaning of the degree will be the same.  That you spent time at an institution where you had access to the best resources and opportunities.

Response: Well, now I am the world's oldest practicing media librarian, and a person commanding much respect, even esteem, as I hold the secrets to the ancient media formats, including 16mm film, Umatic video, and those shiny olde dvds. Now that most everything--most, but not all!--is on the Internet, these heritage media formats are valuable artifacts, much in demand by researchers. Emerson College is a busy place, having survived the great collapse of colleges and universities that has taken place due to rising costs and the explosion of online learning.  Since Emerson has its own niche, characterized by a focus on communication arts and sciences, and a commitment to developing skills that require thinking, creativity, synthesizing, problem-solving, and innovating, and a sterling reputation, and incredibly low teacher to student ratios--most of the classes are seminars--we remain a vibrant locus of teaching and learning!  And I have my own media librarian floor in the fantastic state of the art Iwasaki Library!

Ok, really?  If I live in Chinatown as one of the 70 per cent of Asian residents, I think my interactions with Emerson College might be less than positive, for the most part.  While there certainly are opportunities to see Emerson students and staff interacting positively with our residents, like the basketball team members who mentored at Josiah Quincy School, or the (ahem!) dragon boat team, and, of course, the Re-imagining a Village project, a lot of what I see are students and faculty who come to Chinatown mainly to eat.  Unlike Tufts University, who have many well-established programs partnering with Chinatown residents, I don't see Emersonians taking a big role in many of the pressing issues we face in Chinatown.  One major one I really wish Emerson would step up and partner with us on is the effort to try to bring back the Chinatown branch of the Boston Public Library.

This summer I noticed many high school groups at Emerson, and I think they were participating in a program that was community-based. I don't know how innovative that is, but I think it's a good way to invest in community youth,and I hope we continue to do more of this. I consider the dragon boat team to be an investment in the surrounding community.  By participating in a community festival, practicing with teams from the Chinatown community, and the larger Boston community, we are forming friendships, and also collaborative relationships.  For example, the year before last, we invited Boston Chinatown Neighborhood Center staff and youth to join the team, which set them up to race with their own team last year. There are so many ways we could work with BCNC, but it always seems to be a time-consuming hassle to set things up.  Now that the Elma Lewis Center is established, I think this will be easier. I would also love to see us work more closely with area high schools, especially the Boston Arts Academy.

I also go to the Bostix ticket kiosk when I want to see something at a main stage venue.

Response: Cultural Studies

Oh come on, Ken, have you SEEN the campus at Ithaca????  You would be in a bubble there.  At Emerson there's a whole city--made up of diverse neighborhoods--outside your dorm, and you'll have plenty of opportunities to use your talents to engage with them in meaningful ways. You want to make films--so you'll need to connect with people, and not just your peers in school--and you'll need to practice collaboration. Your college experience will be the result of what you put into it, how much you're challenged, and how you engage with the challenges.  Ithaca is a safe place for you--but upstate New York is not that far from Boston, so you can get home whenever you want.  I'm betting, though, that once you find your tribe at Emerson, it will become a second home.

Response_ddqual: A lot of people have mentioned the importance of finding a mentor.  How do people do that at Emerson? I'd be interested in hearing from students, staff, and faculty--your best tips on finding a mentor.  And how does the relationship evolve?  Is it formal, informal, or what?
replies_ddqual: I haven't found a mentor at Emerson per se but I do have a professional mentor.  I have also participated in mentoring programs where you are paired with someone.  In my experience the "forced" pairing doesn't work as well as the organic pairing.  I found my mentor just through networking and mutual interests.  I'm currently reaching out to someone outside of my department to learn more about her work which closely relates to my work so we'll see how that goes!\\ Hey Maureen! Someone from Career Services just came to speak to my class on Thursday about a database on their website of all Emerson graduates and where they work. She spoke as if this was a great way to get in touch with people in our fields.\\ I think mentor/mentee relationships form organically and maybe without you even realizing it. You want a mentor that you connect with and can have conversations about meaningful things. Eventually, this is the person that you will go to whenever you have decisions to make or obstacles to overcome. Mentors are the people whose advice you trust and that you look up to for what they've accomplished in their professional and personal lives.

Response_ddqual: What do people think of the changes at WERS over the years?  when I'm out in the community, WERS is something that people always mention about Emerson, and usually in a very positive way.  Having been here for  . . . awhile! . . . I've seen lots of changes . . . like the switch to underwriting, the professional AM host, programming changes . . . do you think they have improved the station, or watered down some of what made it unique?
replies_ddqual:
The changes make me a little sad. I miss the gritty college radio vibe that WERS used to have.\\ Me too.  I also miss the diversity of programming we used to have.  I've heard similar remarks from non-Emerson listeners.\\ I like the current mix of music, it definitely fills the void that was made when WFNX went off the air... they are trying to make inroads to the Boston radio scene rather than just continue to be the best College Radio station (which they have been for a while). I found the old "Rockers" show un-listenable, and would switch stations immediately.\\ I only started listening to WERS a year or two ago after WFNX went off the air. So I can't speak to the past. But I do love WERS during the week and particularly love George & Tory in the mornings. As long as students still have the chance to be on air and run things, I don't see how having one professional personality in the morning is a problem. I think George brings a great vibe to the station and if it raises the overall visibility (not to mention listeners and donors) to the station, i think that's a good thing.\\ When I mention I work at Emerson people usually first mention WERS, an how much they love it. It still has a huge following regardless of the changes. \\ hmmm . . . but some people may have stopped listening . . .(I know one person who did, because she hates the AM radio banter between George and Tory)  I wasn't a huge Rockers fan, but it made our programming much more diverse and unique. \\ I thought WERS was at its best about five years ago in terms of the music they played. Right now they're basically indistinguishable from The River most hours of the day. I liked it more when students were doing the programming. But if the station is more successful now, who am I to complain?



\\ I guess it depends on our definition of successful radio.  Do we want to be uniquely Emersonian or do we want to be, as Sam L says, "basically indistinguishable from The River"?

8.  Dragon boat paddling is a TEAM sport. There is nothing more exhilarating than feeling the boat fly through the water. It doesn't just happen. It is the result of practicing technique, rhythm and synchrony that meld our bodies and spirits together as a high-performance paddling TEAM--but also, Dragon boat is an INCLUSIVE sport.  Paddlers dont need to be particularly strong or athletic (though, of course, they may be!)  Its working together that produces the synchronization resulting in speed.

My "most Emerson" experience happens everyday at work.



I'm constantly met with insane amounts of unwarranted aggression for things that simply aren't my fault. My job at the Help Desk is make sure your technology (in any form) is working well.



I would love for everything to work 100% of the time, it would make my life incredibly easy. The facts are that technology is imperfect and is going to break from time to time.



All I ask is that the community take a breath before contacting IT or any other department with their issue. I didn't break it, but I'll make sure I do everything I can to get it working and ensure that it doesn't break again.
replies_ddqual: so say we all\\ I count on the help desk's dedicated staff to understand I'm using them as a proxy for the rage I'm feeling toward the machinery bringing out my worst qualities. Without fail, they receive, measure, and respond to my frustration and pain with patience and dedication - though not always with the perfect fix I have in mind. The help-desk staff is great, the campus equipment is adequate on its good days... but for all of us who use you to offload our stress and pain and frustration - big, big THANKS! \\ I am always appreciative of the time, patience and care the IT Helpdesk provides to everyone in my department!  We recognize the burden of being a sole source solution provider and it makes me sad to think others don't show that same appreciation or understanding!  You allhave always come ththrough for us! THANK YOU! \\ I try to not take it personally. I feel peoples pain when technology is being diificult haha. \\ We breathe before we call you.  But we breathe so much better after you've left and fixed out problems!\\ The Help Desk staff, along with the rest of the IT staff behind the scenes are amazing.  Shout out to Matt, Mike, Hana, Frankie, Bret, Sophie, Carlin, Peter, Bryce, Zach, Cyle, Dennis, and the rest of the crew I failed to name.

IT has formed a Service Excellence agreement that we are trying extremely hard to hold ourselves to.

These are some base guidelines that will keep our department accountable for the work we do, and the services we offer.

Simple.  Communication.  Large scale, many people, medium scale, a team or small group, small scale, one on one.



Communication is at once the most important and hardest thing to accomplish globally.  Language is a barrier, but not an insurmountable one.  Communication involves more than just talking and listening. Non verbal communication and written communication are needed to complete the picture.

Response:
Who knew that CD's would become obsolete?! Who knew that iTunes would be come obsolete (at least this is what I hear.) so predicting new technologies is tricky.  However, human beings will always seek entertainment and the arts, no matter what the format.  We may see:



The Art Book - with the advent of ebooks, physical books will take on a new form and be elevated to the status of art object (think of painting after photography) and there will be a demand for fiction and non fiction books which are stunning works of art as well as literary delivery systems.



The Media in your Brain - virtual reality and AI will make entertainment a more internal action. Games, visual storytelling (film? video? probably not!) and information can be accessed via brain chemistry making a physical screening device unnecessary.  Emerson alumni are on the cutting edge of this technology.



Theater of the Streets - as our society becomes more polarized between the haves and have nots, expect to see the end of live theater as we know it as it becomes entertainment only for the 1% who can afford to see live theater.  Emerson alumni have recognized this problem and have created the "Theater of the Streets" movement.  This movement works with local community leaders to support formal theater productions preformed on the street.  As this movement has been going strong for 10 years, the main goal of the movement was to advocate and agitate for more public funding for classical theater, which has begun to happen, however, the TOS has now established itself as a going concern and many cities, towns, and states across America and indeed the world support this theater experience for all.

Response_ddqual: Young widows and widowers.  My husband, Adam Brooks '85, passed away in 2012.  we were together for 29 years (met in Joan Brigham's Modern Art Class!).  I am 49.  I feel this is a broader national issue, and I have been talking about it to anyone I can, this forum seems like a good place.  It is not necessarily and Emerson issue, but I wonder how many staff, faculty, and students this does effect.  Anyway, as a young widow, there are very little support services available to me. Case in point, I am eligible for his Social Security survivor benefits unless I am 60 and not married.  Well, frankly that is not helpful. My retirement is secure, but I am financially hurting now.  Only one young widow and widowers support group in MA, and it is in Andover (which I can't get to as I had to give up my car to save money.  Anyway, if there are other young widow and widowers out there, I would love to hear from you and maybe we can get together for support.
replies_ddqual: For the rest of the Emerson community, how can I help raise the profile of this issue which effects millions of Americans who are invisible to the mainstream?\\ Karen, this is omething Boston ought to be particularly well equipped to address. I'd reach out to the surrounding schools - Suffolk, Tufts Med, MGH, MIT, etc. to see if there would be interest in creating an email list or online forum or physical meetup of some sort. I'm sure you're already aware of http://widow.meetup.com/cities/us/ma/boston/ and similar support services from the wider community, but if academia doesn't have a group of its own, I think it should.  \\ Great suggestions, thanks!

Response_ddqual: Emerson strikes me as a professional school with a liberal arts bent. Students who graduate from Emerson, if they know what they want, graduate with the skills and experience to launch their careers. The drawback of that, of course, is for students who are exploring or who come in thinking that they know what they want, but then wanting to change course. There doesn't seem to be a lot of flexibility to try out various paths and get a more general liberal arts experience -- coming away with a core body of knowledge and critical thinking skills that will serve them no matter their next steps after graduation.

Response_ddqual:
We represent a geographically and racially diverse student body, and I commend admissions for constructing a group of students who look so different from one another. That said, ideologically, we are anything but diverse. There is certainly an Emerson mentality; the college's habit of handpicking such similar students year after year prevents discussions from having many different viewpoints. Not to say that everyone here thinks the same way... But most people here think the same way.

I've encountered far more diversity in the community at large than within the few blocks of Emerson.

The gates that mark the edges of Chinatown sometimes end up being more literal than simply metaphorical. I don't hear much of students going through Chinatown except to eat pho or dumplings, or to walk to South Station. Even though we're so close geographically, we're very distant from the Chinatown population. Those residents probably benefit from Emerson's students by the business that we bring to their establishments. I think Emerson could further a relationship with Chinatown's residents by incorporating some service projects into curricula. We have such a unique, rich culture literally next door, we should take better advantage of it.

Response_ddqual: I wish faculty better utilized Canvas. When I started at Emerson, we were still on WebCT; now that we have the resources of Canvas, only one of my four classes is on it. Even if all of my classes' syllabi were on one website, that would be a big help. Some professors post additional readings and video clips. It's an easy way to turn in assignments and track what's going on in the class. I don't know what faculty's end looks like, but it shouldn't be too hard to at least get the class and some basic information online, right?
replies_ddqual:
Can any faculty or anyone who sees the faculty side of Canvas comment? Very curious, thanks\\ Joshua, I can tell you that the faculty side of Canvas is MUCH better than the late unlamented WebCT. 



Faculty have a variety of reasons for not using Canvas - but if you have profs that are interested and want help, have them contact ITG@emerson.edu or call x8090. We will do one on one trainings and help them build their Canvas course. \\ I use Canvas for my classes and I found it has been a great way to share relevant articles, links to online assignments, etc. I'm also using it for students to submit assignments for the first time and really like it. All of the assignments are in one place rather than clogging up my email. (I don't see the value of printing submissions and prefer to do things electronically).



Don't get me wrong, there are a few quirky things I hate about Canvas, but I'd much rather have it than not.

Response_ddqual: Can we figure out quiet and social areas in the library? The former will and grace set is a perfect spot for holding loud meetings; the carrels are not.
replies_ddqual: Don't forget about the 6th floor quiet study room. Oft-forgotten, always silent. 10/10 would study there again.\\ In addition to the 6th floor study room, the Presidents Room on the third floor is often quieter than other parts of the library. The areas closer to the Library's entrance and service desks are naturally noisier and as a result tend to attract group study and socializing.  Given the tight quarters in the Library, sometimes  these boundaries overlap.  If you want to be far away from the activity, check out the quiet study tables and carrels in the West Stacks,\\ The west stacks of the library are designated quiet areas, so if you want some peace I'd definitely recommend heading there (or the aforementioned 6th floor). The study rooms (especially the ones upstairs) lend themselves to loud meetings since you can close the doors, but you can only fit a maximum of 6 people so for big meetings it's not ideal. People have been keeping the former W&G set a quiet area for the most part so I've seen some people utilizing the white boards for meetings and stuff. I think it would be difficult to label it a social area, however, because having 4 different meetings in there could get chaotic. \\ Just a caveat--at night the west stack "quiet area" can be pretty noisy, due to noise from the alley.  \\ but Billy the 6th floor doesn't feel like it's part of the library!!!\\ Emily, do you have any suggestions for what we might add to our 6th floor space to make it feel more like part of the library?

I love Emerson's A cappella competition, and also listen to All a cappella on WERS.  WERS is one of my two go to stations when I'm driving, and has exposed me to new music as well as let me enjoy show tunes on Standing Room Only. I love plays and musicals, and we are lucky to have so many options in Boston. I've attended several plays featuring Emerson students and directors and a few of the professional productions on stage in Emerson theaters. I'm also a big fan of the ART, the Lyric Stage, the Huntington Theater.  With so many choices, I spread my time between them but usually see at least six plays a year.  I usually attend at least one Boston Ballet performance a year ( and it's not the Nutcracker).  I go to the MFA and ICA about once a year. I like to eat good food so combine any cultural outing with an interesting meal, and eat out often in Boston and Cambridge.

Response_ddqual: Teaching is a live, moment-to-moment, experience and the best classes that I teach are the ones where I am, what I call, 95% prepared. If I'm, in my definition, 100% prepared, then I can be on autopilot and I don't need to listen. If I'm 95% prepared then I need to be present for what might happen, for the possibility of discovery of something new. That is the best feeling.

Response: Africa

Emerson helps address societies problems by giving a few volunteer opportunities. The school always tries to reach out to the community, through different portals and help when they can. However I think they could do better. While there are a few classes about Diversity and Inclusion topics there could be more, and in some cases I wish that one class on gender and one class on racial issues were mandatory at Emerson - you have to take a class on civics (if I remember correctly from 7+ years ago) but that's a bit different to me. I also think there should be a general day of service, not just for staff but for students too. Where a list of places to go out and volunteer were given and both students and staff would have to (if they had the time) go out and do their part to help with the community. There is also a large lack of places to go for trips abroad and study and that weakens the program substantially too. The Castle is great and so are the few options given, but it could be so much more.

Response_ddqual:
I've traveled a lot, and been to many different places and honestly I can't say I could choose. London was beautiful, and exciting but so was Tokyo, and so was Florance. Not to mention I have a home away from home in Conway, New Hampshire - and that I would love to do TV and Film Work in LA (even if that isn't what I studied and I don't like LA much). So, in saying that I don't think I'm going to choose to lay ground-works anywhere quiet yet. I'm 25 and there is still much of the world to see and explore. Can I put a marking pin on the world instead?  



... Just discovered that I have to put a pin down. Frustrating. I'll put it in Boston for now since that's where I live but it's not even close to my answer.

Response: Because Emerson prides itself on being forward thinking in rational and creative thought, I would like to think that the degree one got from Emerson College would mean even more in 2030, and that because ours is a growing community would lead to even greater success. However I'm not so naive to realize that 2020 is not so far away, and so I think that in 2020 it might have mostly the same weight, while in 2030 it might be greater.

No. You don't know where life will take you or if he'll even end up in LA. All sorts of experience are important, and it might turn out that it's his philosophy class that he ends up following a path to not his film career. And if he's doing all he can do to learn his film craft, why worry. It's your final year bro, have fun.

As a staff member I've gotten better, but I still have to wonder why.
replies_ddqual:
A big part of what college is about is the transition into adulthood.  Students arrive with differing developmental levels, various strengths and weaknesses, and part of the role of the institution is to look out for individual development, and foster it starting with what each student each brings.  



To my mind, if a student spends most of the time at EC developing the skills needed for adulthood and navigating that transition with grace and integrity, that's at least as important as being hyper-busy with orgs, co-curriculars, and buzzing phones.

Response: I'd love a WLP class that focused on fantasy, and doing fantasy right. There is so little focus on that. Also I think, or hope that WLP and Screenwriting will not be exclusive to one track or the the other. As a WLP student I always wanted to take the Screenwriting classes but couldn't because of how separate the two courses seemed. The same goes for Journalism and WLP. In this case the classes wouldn't be new but perhaps the category of learning would be. Breaking down those sort of barriers are important.

Technology has changed in a way that out of classroom it is easier to have contact/access to professors and the material. In the classroom it has lead to more ways to explore. However it hasn't replaced one on one conversations with the professors, nor has it replaced professors in the classroom. I think many cases the old ways work best. I don't like lectures much but I LOVE in classroom discussions and I wouldn't want technology to hamper that.

I think in order to market properly you need to be creative, and while marketing can teach you this art related subjects can teach you this even more. Writing gives you a good idea on how words can have an impact, and how to string them together in a way that they have the greatest impact. Knowing what to write and communicate to draw people in important, know HOW to do those things as well is just as. Both together? Well, that's a deadlier weapon that most.
Professional school
Response_ddqual: I think Professional school is best (Art School without the s at the end of Art sort of implies only ONE kind of Art and Conservatory ignores the Communication side of things). I do think that it's changing and growing and attempting to become a school where The Professional Arts and Communication meets Liberal Arts, and I think that will work in it's favor. However right now the school is easily heavily more one-sided to The Arts and to other Communication based ideas and training you on how to grow in those areas for your profession. There is also a lot of networking involved which comes with a school of Professionalism.

This is something I wrote for my final thesis, came back to, and edited in a way that I think betters it:



+ Death of an African from the Amistad +



The pond is a longing,

(longing) deep in his feet,

(deep) in the long walk home 



been too long goin on,

(goin) lost to hard blind winters,

white hands (blind) tugging him away 



into foreign lands,

into distant ground,

where distant, his original language is lost 



until submerged, the water kisses his lips,

(lips) drinking water with thirsty lungs.



He tastes death (freedom).

Response: I can't think of one "moment" of learning but I can think of the collective of moments. These were all the classes I took on race issues and feminism in my final year. It was how they all intersected and lead to me discovering a lot about who I was - how I saw myself in both my race and my gender. And then how those two things connected, on a greater deeper level. Having that clarity of self, that was an important time period in my life.
The primary communal & meeting place for Emerson students at the College's Back Bay campus (130 Beacon Street)

Things change so much in the first year that the only real advice I can give is to know the important buildings in the school (where to go to get career advice, where to go to change classes, where to go if your sick, or need a shoulder to lean on etc), to never be afraid to talk to teachers, to join clubs if that's your thing, to explore the city whenever possible, and to know which websites sell your textbooks cheapest. Everything else is so up in the air, and so open to exploration, I know pretty much everyone says it but college is what you make of it. So, even if you never actually end up following any of that advice anyway (because it might never apply to you), you still know that it's something you can do, if you want to. Finally never get so caught up in work that you don't make time to just enjoy yourself.

I love the Boston Common and walking through it, however work makes it hard to go and just stroll here most of the time. The common is beautiful in the summer, and while yes during the winter things can get a bit frosty I love the lights that eventually go up to decorate the walkways. I have many found memories of going here just to plot out a story or work through a paper while I walked, listening to music for moments of inspiration. Or, during important events that are cause for celebration, this is where all the students would gather, their cheers crying out into the night (and they all happened at night). The Boston Common really is a special place.

In the Boston area, we have a new "Arts Czar" in Julie Burros.  Emerson should work closely with her in the ability to move arts grants forward in a more timely fashion.  One thing for certain, Emerson has a lot of creative people in all campuses.  Boston could certainly use some new art installations (enough of the statues already, how about some color?) around the city and some performance art that pops up spontaneously when you least expect it.  How about getting more involved with Boston Public Schools...in particular working with them on after-school programs or summer programs to keep kids engaged in something positive and creative.

Belong to New England Aquarium, MFA, ICA, ArtsEmerson.  Walk the Boston Common and Public Garden.  Attend the symphony once or twice a year.  And, then, of course, there are the restaurants.  Choices abound with seafood, steakhouses, vegetarian and all sorts of ethnic restaurants.  New ones are opening all the time as Boston is a foodie town.  Walk to the North End and follow your nose.  Stroll into Chinatown with a crowd of friends and do dim sum.  (Yum!)  You could pick a different restaurant every day and not hit the same one in a year!  (and you'd also be broke!)

I think it's highly feasible; with the opening of the LA campus, she could spend a semester or two out there and get an internship on a TV show to see if it is really what she wants to do.   Her adviser could give her some guidance; she could talk to others who have done the same thing.  Then weigh the pros and cons and even if it takes her a bit longer to graduate, it might be the better thing to do in the long term.

I came from a high tech private sector environment; so the culture here is VERY different...in a GOOD way.  What was "difficult" for me to adjust to was getting out at 3 pm on Fridays in the summer!  (I enjoyed having that "problem.")  The major impact for me was the work/life balance...you hear it "talked about" in the media, but I think Emerson lives up to that and it's been a huge benefit for me.  It allows for time for creative thinking, doing other things (hobbies, taking classes, spending time with family) that I otherwise would not be able to do.  Sometime those things that seem unrelated end up helping with a project or helping with someone in unexpected ways.

Response: Actually, it was a little of both learning and teaching.  A project I was given and enthusiastically accepted required me to do some tasks that are in my "wheelhouse" and some tasks that I really didn't have a clue about how to accomplish.  However, sitting in the next cubicle, my esteemed colleague had written a wiki on how to do the tasks about which I hadn't a clue.  Then we started to work together on the project and co-developed a newer, better method --- he had some knowledge that I needed and I had some knowledge that made it all worth together.  Result:  Developed a new way to make our user community more independent and self-sufficient.

Response_ddqual: As I became more involved within the Emerson community, I was given the tools and knowledge of how to become engaged with the greater Boston Community as well as the various communities I experienced while studying at Kasteel Well. Specifically in Boston, I have really familiarized myself with the intricacies of the community and what organizations have been established in order to give back. Now, I consistently volunteer at multiple shelters and food kitchens such as St. Francis House, Rosie's Place, MassEquality, etc. It's important to educate yourself as to what is out there so you can dedicate your time to a certain cause or two that you really feel passionate about. That's when really effective change occurs.

While the Emerson boast being a school for COMMUNICATION and the arts, I feel like the communication students have for a while been getting lost along the way.

Since my sophomore year I have struggled to get into required marketing courses due to the high amount of VMAs who are able to minor or double major in various communications studies. 

I also find it unfair that while, as previously mentioned, VMAs can minor in areas in the communications department or at least take classes there, that the reverse is not possible. 

I came here to study entertainment marketing. If that is a focus you can take, wouldn't it be beneficial for people like me to be able to take some VMA classes or be able to minor there? 

I have nothing against the VMA department, if anything I would like to be more involved, but lets stop trying to pretend that COMMUNICATIONS (listed first in our slogan) and the ARTS are treated equally here.

Response: Thom Mayne

I'm really making a huge assumption here because I have no idea how we are seen but I would guess they see a small, quirky, American, liberal arts college that has a major presence in the film, television, and comedy worlds.



Personally, I had never heard of Emerson College when I applied for my job back in 2007 and I grew up on the East Coast (not New England though) and had visited Boston several times growing up, so how do people find out about Emerson outside of the U.S.?  I'm going to guess Google or word of mouth. As a smaller institution we are not going to have the same visibility as a NYC, UCLA, University of Michigan, etc. because we aren't flooding the market with our grads.  Hopefully our quality is greater than their quantity.  



I think what we really need to do is increase the visibility of our other programs outside of PA and VMA.  We should also have an AMAZING library.
Other
Response_ddqual:
Some of the above, specifically more international students (faculty and staff probably not due to visa issues) and a steady stream of international artists, experts and scholars.  



Don't get me wrong, I'm all for becoming a more "global" institution but I think we have plenty of work to do in our own back yard before we start expanding too much, too quickly into the global scene.  The reason I'm saying this is because we have all seen what happens when an institution, company, etc. tries to expand too quickly or get ahead of themselves and Emerson is no exception.  We've come close to bankruptcy three times in our history, not all for the same reason, but the most recent incident was because we went from reasonable expansion to unreasonable expectations.  Let's remember our history and take things one step at a time.

Response: I often hear alumni talk about how they could never get into Emerson today and how easy it was way back when.  I think it will be true going into the future.  Not only has our application and acceptance process improved and become more rigorous over time so has the curriculum.  Right now students getting their degrees from Emerson are well suited for specific careers which suit our students who seem to be highly focused on their dreams and life goals.  In the future, students will still need those same skills but the parameters will change.  There will probably be a more "digital" component to their careers that Emerson will need to support.  Back in the day our students were using typewriters and physical library books to get their work done.  If they didn't have access to those tools or information it limited not only their abilities but the curriculum as well.  That isn't the case anymore as we are now bombarded with information. Students will need different tools on how to sift through all of that information and have the skills to navigate it. Students and faculty will need to rely MORE on reference librarians than at any other time in history.
replies_ddqual: You post great pictures, Christina.  If there's an award for that, you've definitely earned it by now.

Response: I think we've all taken those required classes in college.  I once had a professor who said that they should teach us more practical skills such as how to survive a lunch/dinner interview with a potential employer rather than take a  required social studies class.  Personally, think that is a very narrow world view.  You need classes, even math (I hated it too), to get along in the real world.  Those required classes teach you skills that you can't get anywhere else.  At the time you may find no value in those courses but over time in your career some of the information and skills you pick up will come in handy!

Response:
We should definitely partner more with the other small colleges within and beyond our consortial partners to leverage our limited resources.  By partnering with other colleges and universities we can "barter" for services while accomplishing larger goals and getting better visibility for all parties involved.



As for other organizations, we need to continue and expand opportunities for high school students on campus to engage them and prepare them for college.  We should also partner more with local organizations, some of which are practically on campus.
All of the above

Innovation means that we are allowed to take risks and hope that we succeed but learn from our failures.  Ultimately, innovation disrupts the course of normal events or causes a change of course in the way things are "usually" done.  Sometimes our innovative ideas don't go beyond the walls of academia and other times they do. This game is a good example of diverging from the normal strategic planning process but it doesn't really expand to the larger surrounding community.  I think the example I would choose for a successful innovation that does involve the larger community is ArtsEmerson.  It is not unusual for a college to have performing arts centers that produce their own shows and bring in outside acts but it is unusual for a college to purchase, renovate, operate, and program two historic theaters in a major city to the point that the renovation and opening of the theaters spurred the larger community and surrounding neighborhoods to become revitalized.  It was a major risk for Emerson to take and they not only succeeded but exceeded expectations.

My time in Boston is somewhat limited as I'm here to work and then I'm back to the 'burbs to my other job as mom.  When I do get a chance to hang out in Boston I love to go to the theaters to take in a show or go shopping.  I know it is in transition but I find Downtown Crossing to be a hub of activity with Opera House and Paramount on Washington Street along with plenty of stores where I can grab just about whatever I need in a pinch or on my way home.

Response_ddqual:
If Emerson continues and expands its support of staff and faculty research, scholarship and external professional activities it will only bolster Emerson College as a leader in many fields.  Right now Emerson College is emerging as a leader in the realm of digital preservation and archives among small private college.  Through the support of ORCS and other offices on campus we have been able to stretch our limited resources to do some pretty great things in the field and serve as a model for others with limited staffing and resources.  



Expanding diversity among our staff, students, faculty, and even interns also improves our academic standing.  The variety of backgrounds, experience, and knowledge that a diverse population brings to this institution expands our breadth of knowledge and again makes us a leader among our peer institutions.

Response: Common Ground

I'm not sure about the paperwork or other logistical hoops she may need to jump through to change her major but it seems like a very reasonable move for her.  I think the best thing for the College to do is get out of her way!  She is a woman going places and if there are any barriers (credit transfers, paperwork, advisers, etc) in her way those obstacles should be removed.

The institution I came from before I arrived at Emerson was very insular and resistant to change.  When I got to Emerson it was a breath of fresh air until I realized how departmentalized we were at the time.  Over time this has changed dramatically.  I now have more opportunities to collaborate across the college in so many ways that there are almost too many options!  I have been able to stick my neck out on some issues but not so far as to lose it in the end.  Sometimes you need to pick your battles and find out what is the most important thing for you to accomplish during your time here.



I think the thing that has had the most impact on me has been the realization that history really does repeat itself.  In my time here I have gotten to know Emerson's history more intimately than most and there are so many parallels to be drawn and similarities that run in 20-25 year cycles.  It is just fascinating to watch the events unfold.
replies_ddqual: Really! That sounds interesting - what are some of the challenges we are facing now that are similar to past ones?

Response: Almost every day
Response_ddqual: I am regularly collaborating with other departments within Emerson as well as collaborating with outside colleagues and institutions.  Rarely a day goes by that I am not working with a staff or faculty member to work on a project.  I have collaborated on exhibits, student projects, records management issues, sustainability, development and donor relations, alumni events, communications/news stories...and the list goes on and on. Response: At Emerson, we tend to be siloed because of the vertical nature of our offices and spaces.  When I attended the Managing for Excellence Cohort in the spring the interaction between myself and my fellow managers took on a whole new meaning.  During the course of business we often just send an email and without a face sometimes we forget that there is a person behind those messages.  By connecting with my peers on a more personal level I, as well as my peers, developed a greater respect for each other and improved working relationships.  Emerson needs to have more opportunities for staff and faculty to interact outside of the normal day to day flurry of emails.
replies_ddqual: I absolutely agree Christina! That would be great!

Response_ddqual: Did you know that Emerson College has an archives?  If you do, then do you know that we are more than institutional records?  The Emerson College Archives and Special Collections (ECASC) contains our institutional memory but it also contains many other collections that support the curriculum of the College.  Interested in Vaudeville history?  Check out the New York Clipper Vaudeville Registry and the Variety Protected Materials Department collections. Here is a YouTube video that a researcher created from the materials he found in that collection.
replies_ddqual: The archives are so amazing!!! It's time capsule down there. Blew my mind when I saw it for the first time. \\ I'm with Paula. I didn't know about it and it was really really cool.\\ Where is this magical place?\\ Jake, it is in the Walker Building, but you should contact archives@emerson.edu to set up a time to see all of the cool stuff! \\ Thanks!\\ Since the video isn't working you can go here http://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_embedded&v=k0rWbnx2SnU and see the video.

Response_ddqual: Maybe someone already addressed this at some point but I know one of the concerns that has come up in this game is that Emersonians seem to always be "too busy" or "stressed out."  There have been mentions of the usual lack of staff, resources, etc. that we all gripe about but when I look around there seem to be so many areas where just a little bit more efficiency would go a long way in cutting costs.  For example, I may be flying around trying to get 50 things done while I see someone sitting at a desk anywhere on campus playing Candy Crush, texting, or too busy on Facebook to say hi.  Can we put these people to work? Also, there have been initiatives and other expenses where it seems no one really thought things through or rushed to implement without considering the strain on our already thin resources.  Rather than add more stuff to our already full plates can we take a look at what we have and see how we can make it work better for us?
replies_ddqual:
Having too much to do is part of the problem at Emerson, being burned out is a corollary. The behaviors irritating you sound a lot like burnout to me. Most of us need to get a certain amount done before we can return to our real lives, where our talents, intelligence, and energy are also in demand. Candy Crush and Facebook and stuff is a means of recharging our batteries as much as an issue of wasting work-time. \\ sure, every once and a while but if everytime I come to an office and the person at the front desk is always playing solitaire, texting, etc. then that isn't recharging batteries, that's someone that could be doing something else while sitting at the desk.\\ I KNOW.  It's an addiction, really.  The school should do something about it--provide educational programs, or something.  It's an incredible time suck, and if the person is supposed to be working, it's really not cool.\\ also, it's not even about time management, it's about work/service ethic!!!! \\ The busy-ness and level of multitasking that I see is exhausting.  I see staff burnt out by it, and I see students with stress-related illnesses due to the frantic pace.  



What can be done to influence EC's culture so that for staff, work is spread more evenly between us, and for students, increased value is placed on simply BEING, rather than producing, competing, DOING?



ECAPS has groups that support this, but how can we enlarge our thinking about what's a valuable use of time?\\ Thanks Diane, I agree completely.  yesterday there was discussion about how the turnover here hasn't slowed down (usually there is turn over with a new administration but after two years things start to settle).  I wonder if some of the turnover isn't due to burn out.  It seems very likely.

Response: Thom Mayne

I do not know exactly how Emerson could be perceived right now, I'm not sure how far the school's name expands past America, but for those countries that have knowledge of the school, I assume people think it is a liberal arts communication school. I think it would need to make its external programs more defined and popular to gain more acclaim in the international world. I do think that is possible, and I think if the school can continue moving forward and adapting to societal and media changes, it can have a reputation as one of the leading communication schools in the world.

Steady stream of international artists, communications experts, and scholars visting our camupus, Higher percentage of international students, faculty and staff, Regularly cited in the press about our specialty fields
Response_ddqual: I do not think the higher percentage of international students should be considered an accomplishment, unless those students are qualified, but I do think bringing in international staff and professors, as well as experts in their fields, would be a great way for students and the school as a whole to gain a lot of diversity and culture.

Response: I can't think of a specific story, but the main thing that I think of when I think of Emerson is community. I feel that I have found a place where I have a group of people and we have common interests. I think it is diverse enough where we can all express our feelings and just broad enough that our shared interests can still have differences. I think the size is great because it is big enough to not feel claustrophobic, and small enough to walk down the block and see a few friends walk by. I also enjoy that there are a handful of professors who are incredibly passionate about their work. I like that I have the ability to meet with them and understand where there passion is coming from, because that gives me reason to have passion too.
South America

I think Emerson has a great diversity and inclusion program, and I think the school does a good job of making people feel like they have a place they belong no matter who they are. I think one problem Emerson has, is that the faculty put on a lot of important and helpful events, but I think that they struggle to market the events well. I am sure there have been some very intelligent speakers and some really cool programs, but the marketing does not catch the eye of an Emerson student and does not draw students in, which is why I think we miss a lot of awesome opportunities.

I agree that it is very dependent on your field of study, but I think that for the majority of students, a degree from Emerson is very impressive. As a television production student, I know that anyone I talk to in the entertainment industry feels that Emerson students are very qualified and capable people. I think that having a degree from Emerson lets people know that you are hardworking, reliable, and able to get the job done.

I personally believe that once you go to the LA campus, you have made the decision to take those classes, and if he wanted to take it, that's okay. Once you are there you are almost done with college, and if he wanted to take a different, more focused class he could have. I'm sure he didn't hurt himself by taking that class, but if he feels like he is not gaining anything from it, then he should try to apply the knowledge he learns to his work.
Some but not all
Response_ddqual: While I feel that Emerson has helped me in so many ways to develop skills to succeed, I don't think it gave me every skill I have, I think some of the people at Emerson were major players in that as well. I think that Emerson advanced my communication skills and gave me opportunities to be a leader. I also learned how to work with diverse people and personality types. I think the most important thing in moving on after college is communication, and that is something I think Emerson can help people with. I think the one issue is that everyone has different ways of communicating and that people are on different levels of skill and sensitivity, that I think sometimes there are situations that are not as productive and helpful to everyone.

Response: I think there will be a major along the lines of "Interactive Media," where students would be able to take VMA and Marketing classing, and maybe even some publishing classes, to learn about transmedia and how different forms of communication work together on a digital platform.

I would imagine that the Engagement Lab has become a vital resource in the school's community. I would expect everything to be digital, and no one would be using paper. I also would think that lessons would be done on something like a Smartboard and there would be a more advanced version of Canvas for everyone to use.
I would figure out how I could apply the arts-related courses to what I was interested in and use examples to explain to the HR rep how they were beneficial.
Liberal arts college
Response_ddqual: I would classify Emerson as a liberal arts college, because we offer liberal arts general education courses, in addition to the specialized courses related to our fields.

Response: I actually don't know exactly what this means to me. The first thing that comes to mind as "socially responsible" has to do with smoking. As a non-smoker, I find it a little frustrating to be inhaling smoke all of the time. I understand we live in a city and that people have the right to smoke, but I feel that the smokers are disrespectful to non-smokers. I am choosing to not smoke, and I should not have to walk through clouds of smoke to open a door to a building I am entering. The idea of social responsibility should continue to this because students should respect other students as well as pedestrians.
